The religious order that founded this college also operated an orphanage in a Canadian dominion's capital, which later became infamous for a scandal. This led to a formal public inquiry, a type of investigation appointed by the head of state within a specific governmental system. In this system of governance, the ruler and their family reside in an administrative headquarters. Within this residence, what is the title for a specialist, such as a poet or artist, appointed to a position that grants close access to the ruler?

Starting at a city's central square, which was modeled on a Venetian plaza and rebuilt after a great fire, identify the major port city it belongs to. This city sits on a major river that flows into a northern sea. Following this river to its lower, tidally-influenced section, we find it splits into two main branches. The southern of these two branches was redirected through a smaller anabranch named after historical charcoal production. This smaller waterway is now crossed by a prominent cable-stayed bridge. What is the full date this bridge was opened?

In a 1996 legal challenge between a political party and a federal commission, spending limits imposed by a specific act were disputed. This act, signed into law by the 37th U.S. president, replaced an earlier piece of legislation that had been the main campaign finance law for decades. That older law itself expanded on a 1907 statute regarding corporate political contributions. During the period this older law was active, a 1941 ruling by the nation's highest court affirmed federal authority over primary elections. This supreme judicial body, established in the late 18th century, can use a rare procedure to hear a case directly from a lower trial court. What is the name of the individual who served as a U.S. Attorney for one such prominent lower court, known by a maternal nickname, and later became the mayor of the major city it serves?

Beginning with a concept for counting non-zero symbols, consider the processor architecture codenamed after a river that reintroduced a simultaneous multithreading feature. This architecture adopted a point-to-point interconnect to replace an older bus system. That interconnect was later succeeded by a lower-latency version used in scalable multiprocessor systems, which often feature a memory design where access time is location-dependent. Such systems typically use an architecture where identical processors share memory, a setup common in a machine providing services to others. In the model defining this interaction, what is the specific term for a program that requests and retrieves pages for display from such a service-providing machine?

Starting with a French TV series where seasons are called "Books," find the name of a divine protector of travelers who is depicted in a specific Japanese statue. This figure holds a mythical jewel, which is itself carried by a symbolic creature from Central Asian folklore. The language that gives this creature its name is an official tongue of an autonomous region situated on a vast plateau. This plateau is the core of a larger high-altitude geographical zone studied by a dedicated team from what American governmental agency?

Beginning with a series of historical uprisings, consider a late 8th-century rebel leader whose female sibling, a warrior-poet, subsequently commanded his forces. This woman belonged to a broader religious faction which later gave rise to a more moderate school of thought, whose modern followers often disassociate themselves from the original group. This moderate school's namesake was a jurist who hailed from a particular Arabian tribe. A town, named after this very tribe, is connected to its nation's capital by a modern highway; what is the length of this road?

Consider a series of luxury vehicles named for a European styling element, produced by a specific division of an American automaker. This division once had a president who later, as a high-ranking defense official, played a major role in escalating a prolonged conflict in Southeast Asia. In the historical annals of a neighboring power that influenced the nation where the conflict occurred, find the chronicle covering the years 6 to 189 CE. This chronicle is a sequel to a work covering a former dynastic period, which itself was modeled on an even earlier, monumental historical record. What is the name of the official who completed this foundational text?

Starting with a cricketer born in a town named for an ash tree, consider one of the county clubs he played for, which is based in a region known for a legendary outlaw. A prestigious trophy, named for a West Indian knight and first awarded four years into the 21st century, is a part of the annual honors presented by the sport's global governing body. A South African batsman, noted for his innovative shots, won an award from this same institution three times. This player competed in the sport's longest format, which has a continental championship that was intended to alternate with another cup founded to promote goodwill. In what year was the inaugural event of this other cup held?

Starting with a Canadian animated series that compiles short segments, consider the general literary term for such a collection. In its narrowest application within imaginative writing, this term refers to a specific lengthy prose format. An annual publication on this format's history was edited by its founder, a British historian who specializes in the medieval era. From the interdisciplinary academic field that studies this historical period, pivot to the study of past economic phenomena. What is the specific name for the quantitative, econometric approach to this latter field of study?

A neighborhood in a major Indian city, named for a Tamil leader, contains a park with a tower that was inaugurated while he was serving as the state's chief minister. This politician was the final premier of that state before its name was changed. The historical state contained a coastal district whose capital city was a famous hub for the spice trade. A river located in this city's district, once notable for its timber industry, is connected by a man-made channel to a longer river. What is the alternative name for this final river, which it acquires as it approaches the sea?

An actress, also part of a country rock duo, starred in a made-for-TV holiday movie, the fourth installment in a series where the main characters were recast. The creator of this film series also wrote and directed a 1985 teen comedy inspired by a classic 1931 monster movie. This movie's title was acquired from a 1950s comic book which was later merged with its sister title to form a new anthology publication. One illustrator for this line of comics, who also contributed art to a 1982 horror anthology film, was born in which borough and city?

Beginning with the concept of a landmark chosen for its global significance by a specific UN agency, consider the European nation that had the third-highest count of these landmarks as of 2019. This agency, which succeeded a League of Nations committee, awards a biennial prize named for a Persian polymath. The prize honors work in a field of philosophy concerned with right and wrong conduct. When these philosophical concepts are formalized by an organization, they create a set of standards. For those working in government, these standards are a branch of political principles. If an individual in such a role exposes misconduct to an outside party, what is one specific channel mentioned, other than government or law enforcement, that they might use?

Starting with the musical era situated between the Baroque and Romantic periods, consider the Italian term for a certain orchestral piece which often served as an introduction to a specific theatrical art form. An American example of this art form, based on a 1985 maritime hijacking, premiered in a city that is the focus of a biweekly magazine established in 1968. A daily newspaper from that same city, founded in 1851, is connected through corporate history to another daily publication from a Great Lakes metropolis. This midwestern paper had family ties to a D.C. publication formed in 1939 by merging two others. What was the name of the syndicate publisher who sold those two papers to their new owner?

Begin with a late-2000s film about 1970s football hooliganism, and consider the actress who portrays the protagonist's sibling. This actress later appeared in a long-running crime drama about two mismatched detectives. The Scottish actor playing the junior partner in that duo also starred in TV adaptations of works by a widely-read 20th-century female author. Many of these screen versions were broadcast on the UK's oldest commercial network, a competitor to the state broadcaster. A one-time controller of this broadcaster's second, more "highbrow" channel went on to study at a college within a famous English university. What was her field of study there?

Starting with the southernmost nation of a certain northern European peninsula group, consider a global problem—a key driver of humanitarian needs—involving gases that trap radiant energy. From the primary examples of these gases, select the one whose concentration has risen 2.5-fold from pre-industrial levels. This gas contributes to a warming process that is fundamental to a planet's energy balance. This balance involves radiation with wavelengths longer than visible light, which is utilized by devices that operate other electronics wirelessly. For the person using it, what is the primary function of such a device?

Starting in the southernmost province of a low-lying country, identify the Walloon province it borders, whose namesake was a semi-independent ecclesiastical fiefdom within a 16th-century union of imperial states. The first person to rule this fiefdom with secular power was a bishop likely from a noble family in a historic southwestern German region. An ethnic group originating from this German region later settled in a city which is now the capital of a county sharing its name. This city is in the northwestern part of a country that borders the Black Sea. What is the capital of this final country?

Starting with the protein filament that is a defining characteristic of mammals, identify its primary protein component. This protein is also the key material in the complex epidermal growths that cover birds. The condition where the two sexes of a species exhibit different traits, which occurs in many animals including birds, also applies to the only extant human species. A pivotal maternal lineage of this species, which dispersed from the eastern part of a continent around seventy millennia ago, is the parent of an enormous, continent-spanning haplogroup. A descendant of this large group, which supports the idea of rapid coastal human dispersal, is specific to what geographic region?

Start in a large business park in the northwest of a city, known for its many food companies. This area is served by a proposed rail project, which extends a suburban network established in 2007. This network, known for its specific color branding, is a companion to the city's older rapid transit system. A pioneering electric line from 1890, which is now part of the older system, originally terminated at a station that opened in 1900. This station is now on a line that was recently extended to serve a redeveloped power station. Plans exist to extend this line further to a major transport hub which, despite its name, is not in the district it's named after. In which administrative borough is this hub actually located?

A Roman statesman who led a campaign against pirates on a Mediterranean archipelago was eligible for a celebratory procession recorded in a special calendar. Such honors were sometimes marked by monuments like a three-bayed arch in the city's main square, which stood near a temple for a deified leader. Both monuments were located in the sprawling central plaza that also contained a major civic hall built over former bankers' shops. This hall absorbed an older basilica. What is the full name of the censor for whom this older structure was named?

Starting with a novel about civilization's collapse from a plague, whose genre often deals with the practical application of science, consider how this application can be embedded in apparatuses. According to one theory, these apparatuses represent the second stage of societal development. When these mechanical structures are evolved to replicate human activities, like a specific "beauty" model from an East Asian country, they can possess a feature that lets them understand verbal commands. What is another three-word term for this feature, describing the conversion of spoken language into a written format?

Start with an autonomous territory tied to Europe whose native people arrived from a nearby continent in the 13th century. Consider a saga, written before 1265, which details a figure's exile there and his son's accidental discovery of a new landmass. That landmass, whose settlement was confirmed by a 1960 archaeological find, was explored by Nordic seafarers of the 8th-11th centuries. The exiled explorer from the saga, whose nickname likely refers to his hair color, belonged to this group. His founding of a settlement exemplifies a process of domination by a central power, which is part of a broader policy for extending national authority. A European empire's first major North American land claim demonstrated this policy, extending over which present-day region of that country?

Starting with an index of book compilations, consider a specific list centered on questioning claims, which promotes a viewpoint based on empiricism rather than dogma. This perspective relies on the human capacity for conscious thought and applying logic. This capacity is used to form a series of statements aiming to prove a conclusion, a structure that can have the property of being invalidated by new information. This property is a concern for the branch of philosophy that studies knowledge and justified belief. This philosophical branch often deals with a general questioning attitude, which can be directed at domains such as the supernatural or the existence of a deity. According to the text, what is another domain this attitude can be directed at?

A German director of an Oscar-winning thriller attended an Oxford college whose full name references a St Mary's College in another city. This city, once a Roman-era tribal capital and home to one of England's oldest public schools, had its capital function described by a Latin term for a "social body of citizens." This term was a key concept in a historical republic that later expanded its influence to include a dominant Hellenistic kingdom. What region bordered this kingdom to the south?

Starting with the nickname for a WWII airlift over a major Asian mountain range, consider the city served by an airfield that was used to attack this supply route. The military force of an island empire captured this airfield. Decades earlier, a different empire's army fought alongside a group of martial arts practitioners in a battle at a mountain pass. This group of practitioners led an anti-foreign uprising toward the end of a dynasty's rule, partly in response to an earlier war where that dynasty was defeated by an Anglo-French alliance. A medal was later created by one of the European nations to honor its participants in that earlier expedition. On what date was this medal established by imperial decree?

Start with a series of royal commendations given to citizens. An acoustician who received one of these is a fellow of an international scientific society that was established two years before his birth. A sub-field of study within this society involves an imaging technique first proposed seven years after the society's founding. An instrument that uses wave interference can measure a particular characteristic of sound, which shares its name with a charity. What year did the public broadcaster, which co-founded this charity, launch its international service, an event that occurred seven years before the charity's creation?

Starting with a Tuscan diocese that is a subordinate part of a more prominent archdiocese, find the city of this superior see, which was elevated to its status in the late 11th century and whose own diocese dates to approximately the year 300. This city's main cathedral, begun in 1063, contains a central area for the congregation, which is distinct from the architectural space providing seating for the clergy. The group of performers who occupy this space are often led by what professional title?

In a religious tradition where the number of precepts is the sum of the days in a solar year and the parts of a human skeleton, consider one of the three ultimate prohibitions, which is an act of irreverence towards the divine. A law that prohibits this act is a type of written rule, distinct from a system of justice based on judicial precedent. This system, in turn, is contrasted with formal enactments by a legislative authority. The body of these enactments, when organized by subject for a particular U.S. state, forms a code of laws produced by that state's legislature. In what city does this legislative body convene?

Start with a defunct professional basketball team from California whose roster included a center. Another player from that same state played the position also known as the four. Considering the position represented by the preceding integer, then returning to the 'four' position, what is the term for a player in this role with an extended shooting range? What is the general term for a player capable of playing two roles, but not perfectly suited for either? A player who received a major defensive honor while on a team named for a feline predator played in the same league as a franchise that had a record-setting home sellout streak. After two other teams relocated, this franchise became the sole team in what bi-national region?

Start with a social unit defined by shared values. For successful interactions within this group, members must visually recognize their partners, a process sometimes impaired by a cognitive disorder. This disorder is associated with a specific brain region, which contains a specialized area often larger in the right hemisphere. This area resides in a gyrus whose name means spindle-shaped, which itself is part of a larger lobe critical for long-term memory. This type of memory is divided into facts and events. What specific example of an event-based, autobiographical memory is provided?

Starting with a 16th-century French literary circle named for a celestial formation, consider one of its chief poets, whose family founder's name suggests a link to the Dutch-speaking northern part of a nearby country. The legislative body for this region convenes in its capital city, a municipality that holds its national capital status by a specific Latin legal term. This term, for what is recognized in law, is related to a social pretense where a truth is overlooked. This pretense is closely associated with the practice of substituting a mild expression for an unpleasant one. The name for this practice comes from a Greek compound. What is the meaning of the second part of this Greek root?

Beginning with a practice involving a plant introduced to Eurasia in the late 17th century, trace the path to the national public health institute in a Georgian city concerned with its health effects. From there, identify the institute's founder, a physician who was an officer in a service originating from a system of maritime hospitals in 1798. That service's legal basis is a mid-1940s act, which falls under a cabinet-level department that was later split, spinning off its educational functions into a new department in 1980. This new educational body oversees a landmark act from a mid-1960s domestic agenda. At what university, the signing president's alma mater, was this act made law?

Start with a sports club in an Argentine capital, known for a basketball team that plays in a venue nicknamed after the club's main football stadium. In a specific top-flight football season where this club won one of its numerous championships, another team was demoted. This demoted team plays in a stadium built in the 1940s, located in a city named after the inaugural general manager of a British-owned southern railway. The industry this manager worked in saw a sharp decline after a major mid-20th-century global conflict. In what year was the state corporation that managed this national industry ultimately dissolved?

Beginning on the continent known for its rising geopolitical importance and southern hemispheric location, consider the early 19th-century independence wars fought there, which intensified after a restored monarch rejected a liberal constitution. These were sparked by a European conflict featuring a protracted siege of a naval base that became a temporary capital. A monument to this siege, a captured French artillery piece, was satirized for a nickname linking it to a royal's physique. This type of high-arcing weapon saw extensive use in a major US internal conflict in the 1860s, notably during a spring 1864 campaign that culminated in a siege at an independent city. On what river is that final city located?

Begin with an ancient Egyptian deity called "the Savior" who is identified with a younger version of another god. This younger god, when adopted into Hellenistic religion as a figure of secrecy, has a mythological uncle who is a god of chaos and deserts. This chaotic god's sister-in-law is a major goddess whose veneration or "cultus" is expressed through ritual. These sequences of formal activities often include acts of religious devotion, a term in English derived from "worth-ship". This act of devotion is a type of spiritual discipline, metaphorically a path. According to the text describing this path, what is a third ultimate goal, alongside salvation and liberation?

An ornithologist received his doctorate from a specific educational establishment, the third oldest of its kind in its country. A former leader of this establishment's student organization, who later became a diplomat serving in the West Indies, held a legislative seat for over a decade. He was eventually unseated by a woman from an opposing political group, who in turn was defeated in the next contest by a man who had once been a research assistant. This assistant worked for a senior government official who began his career as a shearer and served in a particular house of parliament. In this parliamentary house, what was the original designation for the secondary forum used for debating bills?

Starting with a geographical constituency in a North American country that returns a single representative, consider a specific provincial example covering the northern part of a city. The individual elected here in the province's 29th general election later became the presiding officer of the deliberative assembly. This assembly is one of two elements of the broader provincial legislature, the other being the viceregal representative of the head of state. This form of government is also used at the federal level, where the monarch's main representative can appoint stewards to act on their behalf. According to the foundational text that sanctions these appointments, in what year was it enacted?

Starting with the world's largest tropical rainforest, which is an example of a major biological community defined by its shared physical climate, consider the most popular system for categorizing such climates. This system, developed by a German-Russian scientist, classifies one of the coldest permanently inhabited places on Earth, a "selo" whose name relates to unfrozen water. During a major 20th-century global conflict, this location's region was part of an air road, an acronym for the Soviet portion of a system that received aircraft from its North American counterpart. This larger route, a chain of airfields, was planned to connect a northern border with a city that is now its continent's most northerly metropolis with over a million people. What province is this capital city in?

Starting with a township on an island east of New Guinea, devastated by ash from a geological event in its harbor, identify a North American volcanic field formed by crustal thinning. This field is almost entirely contained within a large provincial wilderness area established to protect a prominent waterfall. According to that waterfall's description, identify a taller, continuous-drop cascade located in a different park. This second park was once the southern portion of a larger protected area. In what year was that original, larger park granted its status?

Starting with a material ratio named for a French scientist which measures transverse expansion, we connect to a modulus of stiffness. This modulus is derived from a material's unique stress-to-deformation curve. A simplified mathematical model applies in the domain where this curve is linear. This model is a specific instance of a broader physical property, whose name comes from a Greek term for "ductible," describing the ability to revert to an original shape. This reversion is an example of a concept of invariance, also from a Greek word meaning "agreement in dimensions," which is foundational to a specific algebraic group whose operation is a chaining of functions. According to the text, what is one of the single-word verbalizations for this chaining operation's notation?

Starting with a politically divided island in the North Atlantic, consider the entity that is part of a larger kingdom composed of four countries. This kingdom sends a team to a global multi-sport event and participated in one particular summer edition, despite a boycott protesting the host nation's military actions. The de facto leader of that host nation held a powerful party office, a post which was once temporarily renamed by a specific individual. Following this individual's removal from power, a contrasting model of shared governance was implemented in another major communist state. What two-word informal title is used for the holder of the highest-ranking office in that other state's ruling party?

Starting with a Baghdad-born author of a major religious legal text who journeyed with a colleague that became a spiritual leader for his expatriate community: this leader's ethnic group, which originated on a specific European peninsula, is associated with a Jerusalem religious school named for a fruitful patriarch. A sub-group descended from these people who converted remained after expulsions linked to a religious tribunal. This tribunal was co-founded by a queen who famously sponsored a voyage to the 'New World'. What was the birthplace of the second wife of this queen's neighboring royal contemporary, a woman born six months after her own father's passing?

Starting with the physical process where material viscosity increases with particle density, which is itself a type of state change, consider the phenomenon of reducing a liquid's temperature below its usual solidification point. Polypeptides that inhibit ice crystal growth can mimic this effect. One structure these polypeptides can form, a helical pattern of parallel strands, is an example of a sequentially duplicated protein architecture. A specific instance of this is a repeating 34-unit pattern, which itself is a type of supersecondary configuration. In such configurations, what two-word phrase describes the connection between a biopolymer's primary and tertiary assembly?

Starting with the sea marauders named for their stronghold on Asia Minor's southern coast, identify the ancient region that now corresponds to a fertile plain. In a province within this region lies a small port town that acts as a summer resort for residents of a nearby major city. This major city contains a multi-purpose stadium, built in 1973, which is the home ground for a sports club currently in the second tier of its country's football association. In the overarching league system, certain provinces without professional clubs send a single amateur team for promotion. Alphabetically, what is the first of these specific provinces?

Begin with the unofficial title for the head of the largest political group not in government, a post left vacant after a mid-2018 no-confidence vote. This event triggered a leadership election within the ousted party, the first where members could directly vote. This party's government was responsible to a bicameral legislature, which is also the body that elects the head of government. That head is supported by a deputy, a role held by over twenty people since its creation. The successful 2018 no-confidence motion against a holder of that top office was registered after his party was found to have benefited from an illegal kickbacks-for-contracts scheme. What is the name of the major conservative party implicated in this scandal, which came to light in the late 2000s?

Starting with the list of participants for the 7th legislative contest, find the event itself where one coalition secured a supermajority. From this contest, which was held to coincide with a presidential vote, identify that chief executive election where the same coalition's nominee ended an eight-year rule by the opposition. Now, find a past internal party leadership election contested by that victor, triggered by a retirement. Next, locate the subsequent leadership contest prompted by his resignation, and identify the winner, a man of Hakka heritage. What year marks the end of the era of national fragmentation, which was concluded by a military campaign led by the political party this man once chaired?

Starting with a US county named for a 19th-century political figure, identify the principal city of its micropolitan area, founded as a railroad crossing. A plant from a rail company in this city contaminated a subterranean water source, a condition that leads to a specific land classification. Find a census-designated place with a name similar to this classification, whose border is a tributary to a larger river. This river's name is believed to mean "young" in an indigenous language. The speakers of a language closely related to this one are now centered in what city?

Begin with the Chinese imperial dynasty that introduced techniques for a type of Korean greenware pottery. A Han Chinese commander serving the dynasty that conquered this first one delivered the final blow at a decisive naval confrontation. Before this battle, the fleeing court took refuge in a coastal city, an example of a high-level administrative division governing a smaller jurisdiction that merges a city and a county. This smaller entity is typically overseen by an even higher administrative level, ranking below a province. What is the literal translation of the name of one such city at this higher level, a Special Economic Zone from the 1980s located on its province's southern coast?

Begin with an actor from a state known for its dairy, who played the father of a character portrayed by a frequent co-star of a silent film icon. This actor was part of a movie serial from the late 1930s, based on a syndicated cartoon, where the young man playing the lead was himself the child of performers. That young actor also starred in a drama about a boy devastated by his parents' separation. The author of that drama's screenplay, a former news writer, would go on to pen a film series about a medical professional for a major studio. In the final installment of this series, a doctor questions a socialite's mental health diagnosis. The character at the center of this series later became the hero of a popular television show in the 1960s. The performer who played that television hero, and who was the first to portray a well-known amnesiac secret agent on screen, also starred in an early 1980s miniseries set in feudal Japan. Name that miniseries.

Starting in the Greek region whose largest city shares a name with an Egyptian metropolis, locate a town known for its ancient molded figurines, which is administered from a different settlement. This administrative center lies in the valley of a river that once formed a boundary for a city where a major victory against a Persian army occurred. This victorious city was later destroyed by its neighbor and a prominent military city-state, whose king famously led a defensive stand at a narrow pass during a subsequent Persian invasion. An ancient historian chronicled these events but reportedly declined to be the official writer for a Macedonian leader's Asian campaign; who was this historian's teacher in the art of public speaking?

Starting with an Indo-Aryan language spoken in an eastern Indian state, follow it to a neighboring state where it is also spoken. Within this second state, a certain railway division was integrated into a new railway zone in early 2019, with its headquarters in the state's most populous city. A central residential neighborhood in this city is governed by the area's main municipal corporation, which was itself established by an order from the state's government. According to a list of this government's ceremonial heads, what city contains their official residence?

Beginning with a southern African nation that gained its independence in the final decade of the 20th century, find its capital city, which was re-founded by a German major in 1890. In this city, consider one of its oldest schools, established during the First World War. The headmaster of this school was born in a town nicknamed "Cattle Country." A prominent ethnic group in this region, who are the largest component of a broader nomadic pastoralist population, are an example of a continent's marginalized native peoples. The text discussing the legal rights of such groups mentions that they form part of the national law in which country?

Starting with a list of English laws enacted before the late 15th century, find a specific statute from the early part of that century that made violating a promise of safe passage a capital crime. This statute's name is shared by a historical drama film set during a major mid-20th-century conflict. In the same year that film was released, an actor from a neighboring country won a major award for his role in a different film. That award-winning film, a mystery about a carpenter who mentors his son’s killer, is part of a genre that often uses a literary device meant to mislead. This device, whose name refers to a type of smoked fish, is thematically related to a kind of long-winded, anticlimactic anecdote. What English idiom, mentioned in that anecdote's description, means to tell such a story?

Starting with a list of notable homes in an island kingdom, identify a Victorian house in an English county that serves as the national headquarters for a global Buddhist organization. From there, consider an actress who appeared in a 2006 remake of a horror film by the director known as a "Master of Horror." This director is famous for creating a film series featuring a specific female protagonist who was the first to survive an attack from the franchise's main villain, a dream-invading serial killer with a bladed glove. What year was the seventh installment of this series released, in which the villain is portrayed as a fictional character entering the real world to haunt the cast and crew?

A 16th-century Flemish diplomat's letters provided the only vocabulary list for an isolated Germanic dialect. A bishop from the same ethnic group is credited with translating a collection of sacred scriptures into a related language, for which he created a new alphabet. Centuries later, an Irish scholar's posthumously published work demonstrated that four specific handwritten manuscripts of these scriptures shared a common origin. This group of texts, also known by the scholar's surname, takes its most common name from the numerical designation of one of the four original manuscripts. What is that number?

In a landlocked nation called the "graveyard of empires," a politician who served as its foreign minister advised a military commander. This commander, famed for defending his valley against occupation, once participated in a failed uprising against a ruler from the royal family. That ruler, who had deposed his cousin to become the republic's first president, was later killed in a coup. This event, led by a foreign-backed political party, was a precursor to a larger war involving guerrilla fighters whose name means "struggle." While those fighters were Islamist, another secular guerrilla network later formed in a different country, composed of former state agents. What is the name of this secular network's leader?

Starting with an independent television station in Pennsylvania that utilizes a method for broadcasting multiple program streams, identify the sports division of a station owner that used this method to air events from a collegiate athletic conference located in the South Central U.S. The winner of this conference's baseball tournament earns a bid to a national championship. In the specific year this national championship's super regional games were first televised by a major sports network, what was the name of the head coach who, in his twelfth season, led the winning team to its university's first national title in any team sport?

Start with a list of female sovereigns. From this, find a ruler who took power from her sister in a coup. This deposed sister, whose parentage is debated, was the designated heir of her maternal figure. This maternal figure was the granddaughter of her own predecessor, a long-reigning monarch who helped establish the practice of female leadership in her joint kingdom. Focus on one of the two territories she governed, a state known for resisting colonial powers. A register of its leadership notes that its ruling dynasty was taken over by monarchs from a neighboring power after an invasion in the 1630s. What is the name of the founder of this neighboring kingdom?

Starting with a German shipping company whose speedy liners held a specific accolade for the fastest Atlantic crossing, follow the path to a rival shipping enterprise it merged with in 1970. Next, identify the tangible trophy, created by a British politician in 1935, to give physical form to this accolade. In the most populous city of its commonwealth, where the American vessel that won this trophy in 1952 is now located, there is a non-partisan, non-profit center. What is the foundational document to which this institution is devoted?

Starting with a water reservoir on a major Eastern European river created in the 1960s, consider the larger system of dams it belongs to. Within this system, another reservoir named for a capital city caused environmental changes, leading to the deposition of a specific granular sediment. This sediment is often mixed with a finer material that, when fired, produces a solid like porcelain. This resulting solid is held together by atomic interactions, one of which involves the attraction of oppositely charged particles. What is the thermodynamic term describing the energy that measures the cohesive forces binding these particles, corresponding to their combination from a gaseous state into a crystalline solid?

Starting with a strategic advisor who published works in the early 21st century, identify the publishing house founded by a journalist he is linked to. This journalist also contributed to a daily paper established in the 1970s. This paper, in turn, reported on a businessman who obtained a postgraduate degree from a business school later named for its primary benefactor. That benefactor's father was a high-ranking trustee for a private university that combines secular and religious studies. In which metropolis are this university's campuses found?

In the 39th American presidential election, the incumbent's running mate later became the 33rd person to hold a certain high federal office. The 24th individual to hold that same office was a native of a state whose legislative upper chamber, established in 1844, consists of 40 districts. These districts also elect members to the legislature's lower house. In this fourth-smallest US state by area, what is the name of the administrative center of its second-largest county by total area?

Starting with the process of gathering information to evaluate outcomes, consider the application of this process in a social science focused on the causes of unlawful acts. An example of this application is a national survey on victimization, which is administered by a specific bureau. This bureau, part of a federal statistical system, works alongside a research institute within the same governmental department. This institute, which evolved from an entity established in 1968, focuses on the system for delivering justice to offenders. That system includes bodies whose primary purpose is enforcing societal rules. What is the broad, three-word term for a group of parties associated with this purpose, a term that includes, but is not limited to, official agencies?

Beginning with the world's oldest national governing body for a popular sport, follow its connection to a global federation based in a Swiss city. This international organization was scrutinized by U.S. authorities for corruption in the mid-2010s, which led to the departure of its long-serving Swiss president. An extraordinary session to select his replacement was convened at an indoor stadium, which is home to a sports team scheduled to move to a different city quarter. This quarter, which was on the country's first domestic rail route from 1847, has a station on a main line connecting its home city to what other destination?

Begin with the political alliance whose name in an old Turkic dialect translates to "nine communities". These belonged to a larger western group known to Byzantine sources as the Uzes. A sub-branch of this group, whose name signifies "one who has might and power by relationship," was cited by an 11th-century lexicographer who compiled the first comprehensive dictionary for their languages. His work included the first map of the areas inhabited by this collection of peoples. Today, the world's largest landlocked country is a dominant nation in that region and a member of an organization that hosts an annual military music festival. What is the birthplace of the leader of another member nation's tri-service military band, which was formed the year the British Raj ended?

Beginning with the smallest of the four main schools of Sunni jurisprudence, consider a modern educational institution in Bangladesh founded on a similar puritanical ideology and run by a specific reformist movement. The leader of this movement, a former university professor, is ideologically linked to a historical scholar known as the "teacher of all" who co-founded this same movement with a controversial leader from a particular Indian state. A British public servant, who became the highest-ranking official in that leader's country after diplomatic posts in Syria and North America, authored a well-known book about his travels in the northern ocean. According to the description of this book's literary category, who is the author whose late 18th-century work helped establish this genre?

A midfielder born in Alençon was once loaned to a Premier League team from a French club. A different player, born in Besançon, later joined that same French club's youth system, winning a national tournament for under-19s. This tournament is managed by the country's main football governing body, which in turn authorizes a professional league entity founded in 1944. During the 77th season overseen by this entity, a particular team that has won the second-division title on three occasions competed in the top flight. In what year was this club founded?

In the Swiss city on Lake Geneva that hosted the 34th annual European singing competition, identify the Canadian singer whose prior victory brought the event there. This artist's most significant French-language track from a 1995 album appeared on a live recording released the next year, which also contained a bonus studio song. This bonus track, a plea to a lover, became a number-one hit in an East Asian country. Its massive sales placed it on a list compiled by a data provider established in the late 1960s. This organization's founder, a former promoter for a dairy company, began publishing charts experimentally in November of its founding year. What is the founder's name?

In a European country composed of thirteen administrative divisions and a primary city, this city type is defined as a seat of government. A certain West Asian nation has such a seat of government separate from its technological hub and borders territories run by an interim authority. This authority, formed in the 1990s, later entered a conflict with an Islamist organization, whose military division is named after an individual. After studying in a North African country, this individual led rebels in his northern homeland. Against which specific occupational power's armed forces did his group fight?

Starting with a dynastic order of knighthood founded in the late 19th century to honor personal service, identify the monarch who established it. From an early political incident in her reign that concerned her female attendants, consider the official title for one of these noblewomen. This role is distinct from a similar position held by a woman of genteel birth needing employment. Both roles are part of the wider household that regularly attends a monarch, an entourage which can include a protective detail for special events. What is one example of a personal rite of passage such a special event might signify?

An Anglican bishop, born in an Irish city, served in a northern Japanese diocese. In one of the port cities where he ministered—the first in its nation to open to foreign trade—a nearby strait has reduced territorial waters, reportedly to allow passage for vessels carrying a specific type of weapon. The design concept for this weapon's advanced version is named after two scientists, one a Polish mathematician who also contributed to the practical application of his field. This applied field uses mathematical models, and a related area of study using numerical approximation to implement them is important for what two-word process of examining information?

In a Central European nation whose official language is the standardized form of a Germanic tongue, this standard is one of several codified versions, making the parent language a type with multiple interacting official forms. A linguistic framework, whose name was coined by a Polish-American scholar specializing in the study of dialects, was set up to represent structural differences between such related varieties. This academic field often focuses on the speech variety used in everyday life, which is contrasted with more formal language. A specific abbreviation, used in that formal register to introduce examples, is a contraction of what original Latin phrase meaning 'it is permitted to see'?

Start with a type of religious building with a circular belfry, predominantly found in one English area. Within a county that has only three such examples, there is a village containing one, situated in a waterway's valley. This waterway has a primary tributary that originates near a town whose name may derive from the golden-yellow plants on a nearby hill. The athletic club from this town competed in a particular season of a football competition for semi-professional clubs. In that competition's highest division for that season, one of the newly admitted clubs had won a play-off to secure its position. What is the name of this promoted club's home ground?

Starting with a paper made moisture-proof through a specific coating, consider the artistic medium that utilizes the natural, insect-derived source of this coating. What is added to this medium for coloration? A physical property of this coloring agent, related to light absorption, shares its name with a UK charity that was the first to have its own special musical composition. This type of music is often created for broadcast programs. In a genre of such programs that reuses old footage and became popular in a specific South American nation, what was the Saturday broadcast time for a weekly humorous news show after it changed channels between 2011 and 2015?

In a northern European region of three kingdoms, their shared languages form a distinct linguistic branch. From this branch, a hybrid tongue emerged in cities during a prolonged union between two of the kingdoms, serving as a precursor to a modern standard and sparking a cultural conflict over writing. The resulting language differs from its ancestor mainly in spoken sounds, which can be represented by a late 19th-century notational system. These sounds are produced in a filtering cavity in humans that includes several parts. For the specific part of the throat located behind the mouth and nasal cavity, what is its crucial function related to speech?

Starting with the chronological list of events for a twelve-person apostolic council, consider the highest leadership office in the same religious organization. This leader presides over the church's supreme governing body, whose members hold a title described as being a "special witness." In a separate but related denomination, a similarly named council of twelve is also composed of individuals with this title, who are part of that church's broader system of ministerial authority. This system includes an ordained office named for a biblical preacher, which is also referred to by an alternative title. What was the full name of the first person appointed to this alternative office for the whole church?

A comic book prequel to a video game was released by a publisher that employed an artist who created the second version of a bodyguard character. The initial iteration of this character was co-created by an artist known for being an uncredited collaborator on a bat-themed hero's comics and for his early work on a winged heroine. This heroine's original version was co-created by an artist who was an assistant on a famous alien hero's daily strip and worked for a company that was the direct predecessor to the first publisher mentioned. This predecessor was formed from two entities; what season and year was the first of these entities, notable for publishing the first American comic with all-original material, founded?

Starting with the river that gives its name to a football club in Ballybofey and combines with another to form the River Mourne's parent, trace a different tributary of the Mourne upstream to its source, which is the meeting point of two other rivers. In the county town where this meeting occurs, one source river, which a recent road scheme bridged, joins its partner that flows behind a hospital. From this town, head north about 34 miles to a city whose name originates from an old term for an "oak grove." Locate this city's railway terminus, and follow its single-track line to a station that serves as a passing loop. In the village where this station is found, what was the original name of the estate, meaning "town of the market," that was purchased in the mid-17th century?

During the historical era that transitioned Europe to modernity, the spread of ideas was accelerated by an invention using metal pieces. This led to the art of arranging these pieces, where a set of characters in one style was composed of individual units. A single unit was known by a term also used in an expression for feeling unwell, and which later became the name for a weblog publishing system. This system is a type of closed-source program, whose intellectual property can be protected by a specific legal grant. For how many years are the exclusive rights from such a grant typically valid?

Begin with a film critic whose career at a major west coast newspaper started in the early 1960s. From him, identify a more critical colleague who joined the same paper almost three decades later. This second critic reviewed an art form which technologically evolved from silent to audible. A Swedish-born actress became an international star during the silent era, unlike a leading man known as "The Great Lover" whose fame declined with this evolution. This actor starred in a 1930 film that was later remade into a Spanish-language version. Who was the Spaniard that oversaw the script's alteration for this foreign-language production?

Starting with the fifth installment of a 1990 boxing film series, identify its director, who also helmed a popular martial arts trilogy. An actor from the second film in that trilogy, which is set on an island meant to represent Okinawa, also appeared in a detective series about a family-run private investigation firm. A performer from that detective show later became famous for a mystery series where she starred alongside a male actor known for playing an evil second-in-command in a spy-comedy film trilogy. This male actor once shared the screen with a Golden Age Hollywood fashion icon who studied ballet in Amsterdam and London before starring in a Broadway production based on a French novel. What is the birthplace of this icon?

Beginning with the study of the causes of disease, follow the path to a classification of physical harm where a large fraction of deaths involved transportation. This level of damage requires a specialized center, often at an academic institution like the one that hosted a mid-90s conference on genetics and crime. A surgeon at this institution, a pioneer in using rotary-wing aircraft for evacuations, connects to a controversial field of study whose name sounds like a Pacific Northwest city. What is the specific medical term, found in the final topic on abnormal mental states, for this type of illness?

Starting with the 35th American president, identify his former press secretary who later became the publisher of a daily paper. The parent company of this publication was a defendant in a defamation case heard by a federal appellate court. This court reviews cases from a district court whose jurisdiction includes a county named after an Indigenous term for "big horn." Within this county is a town, established in the late 18th century, that surrounds a city of the same name. What was this town's original name?

Start with an American actor known for horror, who starred in a late 1950s sci-fi film about a scientist whose atoms fuse with an insect's. His co-star, a Canadian-born actress who moved to England, later appeared in a 1950 British comedy alongside a Scottish actor who was once a university elocution lecturer. This Scottish actor is associated with the studio behind a mid-1950s black comedy, conceived from a dream, about a gang of criminals. One of the criminals in that film was played by an English character actor, who also appeared in a 1948 crime drama about a troubled teenager. This drama was adapted from a novel by whom?

Starting with a rare consonant produced by pressing the upper and lower teeth together, consider a dialect of a classical language from an ancient city-state. In this language, a 'false' compound vowel can be formed through a process that creates a hissing sound. This sound-altering process typically affects consonants made with the tongue between the teeth, which contrasts with the first consonant type mentioned. A chattering, percussive noise made in that initial manner lends its name to an annual event. In what city has this event primarily been held?

Starting in a French administrative area created in 1968, consider one of its main cities, which in 2019 merged with a former, flower-adorned neighboring commune. This former commune is situated in a Western European nation where, in its northern half, a particular historical language was spoken until the 14th century. This tongue is composed of sounds that children learn to segment into meaningful units, which are themselves constructed from phonological "building blocks." The branch of phonology dealing with the permissible structure of these blocks gives an example of a language where initial consonant combinations, such as those once pronounced in words for "to have knowledge of" or "a small biting fly," are no longer permitted. What is the current version of this language called?

In a nation containing 94 federal judicial territories, identify the citizen-led investigative body where chief federal prosecutors exclusively participate. This legal body is retained in only one other country, a republic on the West African coast. A topical guide to this nation notes its populated coast is composed of mangrove forests, a subject within the academic discipline that studies a specific planet and its complexities. This planet is the densest of the four terrestrial worlds in its solar system. What is the average density, in kilograms per cubic meter, associated with this planet's standard unit of mass?

Start at a resort on a Black Sea peninsula that was once part of a vast empire which rose after a major northern conflict. The rival power that declined in this conflict is separated from another nation by a sea's northernmost arm, whose name has an Old Norse origin, similar to a major river whose name is derived from a term for a "deep fjord." This river lends its name to a historical province, the core of which now forms part of a modern administrative county. This county also encompasses another province, which in turn is part of a large, sparsely populated northern land. According to this land's description, in what year did two of its constituent regions cease to belong to a neighboring country?

Start with an overview of a fiction genre concerning imagined innovations, then find its subgenre focused on terrestrial settings. Identify the Canadian writer who co-founded this literary movement and the university where he earned degrees. This institution is part of a larger state-wide system, which includes a campus dedicated solely to health science. This health science campus was headed by a pediatrician who became its tenth leader. What is the name of the founder of the medical school where this leader previously served as dean?

Beginning with a phenomenon of shared biological ancestry involving the non-vertical movement of genetic material, a primary factor in spreading drug resistance, consider a specific mechanism for this which, unlike direct uptake, relies on a viral agent for injection. This method was discovered by an American scientist who worked at an institution in the same major East Coast city of his birth. A family of proteins found in the viruses used for this process is exemplified by one from a virus that specifically targets a certain genus of bacteria. What ailment is caused by one of the original host species for this group of viruses?

Beginning with the sultanate known as the "Abode of Faith," consider a native ethnic group from that broader world, who are part of a larger population described by a Sanskrit-derived term for "son of the soil." Policies favoring this population were implemented after a mid-century incident of sectarian violence, which led to a state of emergency in that Southeast Asian nation. This country was preceded by a short-lived union formed from several polities, including a federation of four states established in 1895. An English administrator who served as this federation's acting Resident-General was later sent to report on land legislation in what territory?

Starting with a vitrified ceramic material, consider one of the first English factories that made a soft-paste version of it, known for imitating wares from Chelsea and Meissen. One of this factory's founders was an entrepreneur whose father supplied saddlery for a notable Duke's army. A later man to hold that ducal title, who commanded a raid on a French port city, was the son of an Earl who served as First Lord of the Treasury. This Earl's mother-in-law, an influential Duchess, had a cousin who rose from being a servant to a royal favorite. What is the German term for the official attendant position this cousin held?

Starting with a gene that codes for a subunit of a five-part inhibitory receptor, making it insensitive to a class of psychoactive drugs, consider the type of polymer its product belongs to. Now, focus on a specific version of this polymer that spans a cell membrane, and the term for the orientation of its internal structures. If this polymer is instead a very short chain of fewer than fifty monomers, it receives a different classification. A receptor for two molecules of this class, first identified in the mid-1990s as an "orphan," is involved in fear regulation. One of its two binding partners is associated with feeding and pain pathways. What is the three-letter symbol for the gene encoding this partner's precursor?

Beginning with a Christian restorationist church that originated during the Second Great Awakening, identify its founder. From this individual's family, take his older brother, who was born in a Vermont town whose village center is a registered historic place. Consider the colonial revolt that established the nation containing this town, a conflict that included a significant war for independence. One of the colonies involved in that war, which would later form two different states, had four successive capitals. What was the second of these administrative centers?

Starting with the organization established by a US officer after a prohibition on fraternizing was overruled, consider the social practice of treating enemies like family. This was famously demonstrated during a widespread, unofficial ceasefire in a major global conflict, an event witnessed by a British centenarian veteran. The veteran took part in a ball game, a sport whose modern rules were codified in the 1860s. The regulations for this sport are determined by an international board established in 1886, which is recognized by the sport's highest governing body, founded in 1904. What is the official founding date of the national federation for one of that body's founding member nations, which has its headquarters in a municipality near its country's capital?

Start with the territory known by a specific designation in international sports. A centennial was celebrated for the revolution that established its republic, an event which preceded a civil war and the relocation of a political party. Later, members disillusioned with a major party's moderation formed a splinter group connected to a particular activist's organization. This major party, co-founded by a lawyer who became its first head of state, ended the long rule of the relocated party. This formerly dominant party is central to a political coalition named for its primary color. In what year did the activist, previously linked to the splinter group, become the first presidential candidate for the major party that opposes this color-based coalition?

Starting with the celestial outburst discovered in Japan a year after the first moon landing, this event's "new star" classification sounds like a particle physics experiment that observes subatomic particle oscillation. A separate project studied these same particles by directing a beam from a European research organization to an Italian mountain lab, using an accelerator to generate the positively charged nucleons that define an element. These nucleons are found in the dense center of an atom, a structure confirmed via a gold foil experiment. The force binding these nucleons also holds together the core of a hydrogen isotope, whose name prefixes a vulnerable Australian shrub. This shrub's genus underwent a taxonomic split. What new name was given to the lineage that includes the original type species described by the father of modern taxonomy?

Start with an author born in a major East Coast metropolis in the mid-1970s. Her literary partner, whom she met while they were students, attended the same private university in Lower Manhattan. Now consider a public research institution on the opposite coast, founded in the late 1860s and associated with three national laboratories. This institution is linked to a variant of a multitasking operating system whose development started in the 1970s. A pioneer of this system, known for developing its pipelines, later became an adjunct professor at an Ivy League college established before the American Revolution. A former fullback who played for this colonial-era school was selected in the seventh round of a professional draft. What was the name of the team that drafted him?

Starting with an Azeri folk musical composition that is contrasted with a certain type of performer, identify the narrative genre they perform in coffeehouses. From an anonymous romantic example of this genre that inspired a 20th-century opera, consider the broader oral history tradition it belongs to. This tradition includes a famous collection of epic stories of the Oghuz Turks, whose cultural heritage is recognized by a UN specialized agency that succeeded a League of Nations committee. What is the current administrative center of a West Asian member state of this organization, whose claimed territory has been occupied since a conflict in 1967?

Beginning with a Cold War crisis involving a blockade of a former German capital that was countered by an airlift, consider the unified American military command formed from two service branches that took part in this operation. A heavy transport wing within this command, formed a year later, operated a cargo plane that was a derivative of an earlier heavy bomber. This bomber's development program was more expensive than the WWII research undertaking that created the first atomic weapons. The Army officer who directed that weapons project also commissioned an official report on its history. What is the pay grade designation for the military rank held by this director?

Start with an East Midlands football club founded in the 1880s and identify its Jamaican international captain. This defender spent most of his early career at his boyhood club, a team that was managed to European glory by a famous partnership. One of these managers, a former goalkeeper, coached a Scottish midfielder celebrated for a legendary goal in a 1970s global tournament. This Scot later managed a team from England's second city, which was the inaugural winner of a league division. Highlights from this division were featured on a BBC show that concluded in the mid-2010s. Which broadcaster acquired the rights thereafter?

Beginning with the series pilot that introduces a female CIA agent, follow the path to another government agent who specializes in a terrorist organization. This specialist makes his debut in an episode where the protagonist's doctor brother-in-law is mistaken for a spy. This protagonist, whose university career was sabotaged by his roommate, is later forced to confront this same individual in a first-season episode where the supposed traitor is found alive. What is the codename for the hostile intelligence splinter faction that attempted to recruit that very roommate?

Consider the geometric problem of fitting three tangent circles inside a triangle, a puzzle also explored by a Japanese mathematician from a historical period. In a certain city, a "festival marketplace" was later planned as a joint effort with a prominent financial high-rise. This skyscraper, known for its distinct color and for replacing a failed development, is the tallest in its state outside the principal metropolis. The project it replaced, a proposed retail complex, had received state economic bond approval along with another planned tower. This second tower, promoted by a future state governor on the site of a razed hotel, was never built. Today, the location is home to a 21-story apartment building. In the county where this city restricts urban growth to preserve its pastoral landscape, what is the minimum lot size requirement, in acres?

Starting with the Mercian commander who defeated a Danish army at a village near the River Severn, consider his predecessor, the last independent king of that realm. An even earlier monarch of this same kingdom is said in a certain historical text to have had a dozen sons. This monarch's child became a powerful pagan king who was eventually killed in a decisive battle against a northern rival. The text that mentions the king with many sons also serves as a source for a legendary British leader who resisted Saxon invaders. What early poetic work is also cited as a source for this legendary figure?

Consider the nation's first chief executive, who presided over an assembly in 1787 to create a foundational legal document. A key proponent of this assembly, later hailed as the "Father" of that document, also belonged to an earlier group of colonial representatives. A particular session of this group acted as a de facto government and adopted a declaration of separation. One signer of that document, a physician, was born in a state known as the southernmost in its northeastern region. Within the modern boundaries of that state, a small English settlement that notably lacked a legal charter was established. In what year was this settlement founded?

Starting with the academic discipline that analyzes the production and consumption of goods, consider the economic history of a certain Asian nation before its imperial era ended. This leads to the economic history of the succeeding republic during its period of mainland control, an era which saw an internal conflict follow a war with an island nation. A military division formed near this conflict's end had its regiments transferred to a particular army corps. A division within this corps, which was also established in the same month of the same year, suffered heavy losses in a key battle of that same internal conflict. According to the description of this overarching civil war, in what year did it first begin?

Starting with the duchy ceded by a French monarch to his younger sibling in the 11th century, identify a separate territory that evolved from the same ancient kingdom, known as a "free" county. This county was part of a larger, multi-ethnic imperial complex. A ruler of this complex, once labeled an "Antichrist" by a pope, had an only son from his second marriage. This son's death contributed to a period of imperial vacancy, which was concluded by the election of a Swabian count who founded a long-lasting dynasty. What was the date of death of this count's grandson, who became the ruler of three separate kingdoms?

A British writer on human prehistory, also a paediatrician, practices a profession that involves communicating ideas using various techniques. This professional's expressive manner, which is distinct from foundational rules, is governed by influential guides, including one for American English published by a university press and another from a psychological association aimed at reducing bias. The foundation for this communication is the set of structural rules for language, which, while providing a framework, allows for different ways of expressing the same idea through pronunciation or word choice. What term describes the specific language variety whose speakers are sensitive to the boundaries of these acceptable differences?

Starting with a motorway that connects a London suburb to a major southern port, find the village near its third interchange that was once a staging post. Proceed to a neighboring town, bordered by the same motorway and Ministry of Defence land. Continue to a 20th-century military village that formerly belonged to a different parish, then follow a road to a suburban village known for hosting an international darts competition. This village's boundary is formed by a river that rises in a nature reserve and joins a larger river near a certain village. This destination village contains a protected site of natural grassland, first designated for its scientific importance in 1952. Of the nesting birds found here, which one's name includes a royal title?

Starting with the measure of a circuit's opposition to current, which depends on the temporal rate of a repeating event, and moving to the propagating disturbances this rate describes, identify the European initiative that funded a web analysis tool named for these disturbances. This initiative aimed to unify databases concerning genetic differences, which are catalogued by a specific open-source system designed to display variants. This system often documents a certain alteration in a nucleotide sequence, a process that can be caused by harm to an organism's genetic material. When this type of harm—defined as a change that degrades a system from its initial state—is applied to a physical body, what is its ordinal ranking as a leading cause of mortality worldwide?

Starting with a South Slavic language, identify a letter in its alphabet which is also the name of a protected area in Oceania. This area, that country's first of its kind, is part of a wider national effort to preserve a significant portion of the world's biodiversity, whose extraction industries drive the growth of a key economic indicator. This indicator, defined in an article whose title refers to a famous band's studio activities, is one of several metrics for national output, some of which are adjusted to account for the consumption of natural assets. What term describes the group of resources that are consumed faster than they can be replenished?

Start with a historic residential area in a nation's capital that is a metonym for its legislature. This type of designated place is the focus of preservation endeavors, a pursuit which in one European country led to gentlemen's societies. An English officer, whose ethnological collection founded a university museum, practiced a related discipline. This discipline lent its name to a learned society that later split, leading to a new society co-founded by an explorer. This explorer undertook a famous disguised journey to a holy city. The successful completion of this pilgrimage grants a specific honorific. What classification is given to this term?

Beginning with a Welsh author who once worked as a teacher after his university graduation, follow the path to a television adaptation he wrote about a war-traumatized veteran who takes up a teaching post at a fictional school. An actor in this series, who was born in a Warwickshire city, performed for a company at a Royal Court, a career step connected to a major publicly-funded performing arts venue on London's South Bank. The man who would become this venue's artistic director, born in a northern English city in the mid-1950s, is the son of a theatrical fundraiser. This director's father was a Queen's Counsel who held a judicial title on an island dependency. What is the full name and title of the first person appointed to this specific judicial position following its creation by a 1918 act?

Start with a country singer known for a comedic hit about running unclothed in public. The term for this act is a homonym for what a British Academy Award-winning performer, who once played a character nicknamed "the Phantom", does for a living. This actor, a former army lieutenant who appeared in a wartime film about a specific fighter plane, shared his nationality and profession as a writer with another multi-talented artist who served as a diplomat and a children's fund goodwill ambassador. This ambassador's father, a journalist, was born in a port city then part of a vast empire founded by a Turkic tribal leader. The list of this empire's dynastic rulers notes its second-ever capital city. What is the modern name of this city, which contains the mausoleums of the empire's early sovereigns?

Consider a pioneer of systematic archaeological methodology who held his nation's first professorship for the study of an ancient North African civilization. A female novelist, who shared this academic passion and co-founded an exploration fund for that same region, pursued the same discipline. A French curator and academic in this field belonged to a specific titled family, which was part of a hereditary upper class whose privileges were later formally abolished. This class was historically supported by a rural economic system where a lord held power, enforced through local judicial bodies. During the feudal period, in which country were these bodies, which handled matters like land tenure, considered the lowest courts of law?

A 1996 film about an artist's assailant features a real-life indie rock trio performing as an unnamed band. This band's second album, released in 1987, was later reissued on a single disc with their third full-length recording. Two live tracks from that third album were recorded at a famous Manhattan music club known for punk. A menswear designer, who opened a boutique at this club's former address, attended a university in the state where he grew up. That state's oldest university includes a graduate school whose stated mission is to help people use a certain concept, combined with technology, to build a better world. What is this core concept and field of study?

Starting with the American rock multi-instrumentalist who fronted a band from its late-90s formation until its mid-2000s breakup, consider a type of musical ensemble, whose members are already famous, where an example is given featuring three opera superstars. Identify the Spanish member of that trio, who is known for his versatility and has performed almost 150 roles. This singer shares a vocal profession with a younger French/Mexican artist who was famously discovered after being overheard singing in his apartment. This artist's vocal range is a specific type of male voice, which has a lightweight, flexible sub-category suited for roles by a leading composer of the "bel canto" style. In which city was this composer, who was taken under the wing of a mentor who enrolled him in a special school, born?

Starting with the European conflict in the early 19th century that involved a decisive naval victory in 1805, consider the discipline for planning war at sea, and then its corresponding land-based counterpart. A multiplayer game, whose name evokes both the internet and this kind of conflict, was reviewed by a magazine published by an American media corporation. This American firm is owned by a British parent company, which was founded in a particular town in 1985. What is the name of the English county that shares its name with this founding town?

Starting with a famous NFL rivalry between two northeastern cities, consider its parallel in the NHL mentioned in its description, which in turn has a counterpart in professional baseball. Within the division that houses this baseball rivalry, find the team with the most championships. This team competed against their rival from the baseball matchup in a specific league championship series during the year that division was formed. What year was a notable pitcher from the victorious team of that series, who later enjoyed a record-setting career with four different franchises, inducted into the Hall of Fame?

Starting with a web-based service for managing open-source software, consider the adoption of such software by public bodies. From there, move to a specific German-origin operating system, and identify the general category of OS it belongs to.
