An international route, connecting a Belgian university city to a historic German one, uses a section of this southern motorway and briefly enters the southernmost province of a neighboring country. What is the name of the river that forms a significant portion of this province's western border?

Beginning with a regional artistic movement in a Spanish community, follow a key architect of this style who became a municipal official in his hometown, where this artistic expression was prominent. A different architect, who also served as a municipal official in the same city, designed a private residence there for his own family a decade into the 20th century. In this industrial city, which is home to a cultural institution for entrepreneurs founded in the mid-1800s and is crossed by a river, there was a historic church that was demolished. If its reconstruction began four years after it was torn down, in what year was the new building officially blessed?

Start in a North African kingdom that regained its independence in the mid-20th century. Move south to a neighboring Islamic republic whose name derives from an ancient Berber kingdom. Within this republic, consider a practice it was the last in the world to formally abolish in the early 1980s. This practice is a key part of the country's broader record on fundamental freedoms, which is noted for discrimination that led to a border conflict. Now, shift focus to a prominent reformer who was a noted opponent of a man that would lead a revolution, overthrowing a 2,500-year-old monarchy. This revolutionary leader then founded a special military corps to protect the new political system, a body distinct from the nation's conventional military. What is the three-letter acronym for this conventional military?

Starting with the body's strongest ligament connecting two specific pelvic bones, find in an anatomical overview a nearby strong band which is a primary bond between these same bones. This band helps form the larger skeletal structure of the lower trunk. From this structure, a ligament extends from a lower back vertebra, forming the thickened border of an investing membrane. This membrane, in turn, covers the group of muscles responsible for straightening the back. These muscles attach to the rigid organs that constitute the skeleton. What is the name for the organic component of the mineralized matrix of these rigid organs?

Starting with the type of UK governmental body that is treated as managerially separate, find a specific example which acts as a global forum for discussion and was once located on an estate in Buckinghamshire. Identify this forum's current home, a 16th-century listed building, which was constructed for an MP who was also a High Sheriff. This builder's second son was an adventurer whose imprisonment prompted a declaration of parliamentary privilege. This adventurer's elder brother was a soldier who also served in the House of Commons, representing a notorious "rotten borough" in Sussex. What legislation abolished this particular constituency?

Start in the capital city that contains an independent state within its boundaries. From there, navigate to its only district on the Tyrrhenian Sea, where a notable saint passed away in the 4th century. Identify the type of basic administrative division this district is part of, a division headed by a mayor. Next, find a specific example of this division located south of its provincial capital in a northern autonomous province renowned for its mountains. Consider the broader category of first-level administrative divisions to which this province belongs. Now, refer to a list that ranks these divisions by economic output, which notes that one region's data is split between its two constituent provinces. What is the capital of the northernmost of these two provinces?

Starting with the American document that codifies personal freedoms in its first ten modifications and was inspired by an earlier English charter, consider the legal system of that English nation. A landmark case within this system involved a contaminated beverage and was adjudicated by the nation's highest court. A Scottish judge who was a member of this court also held the position of principal legal advisor to a national church. One of his successors in this advisory role, who later headed a law commission, studied a classical humanities course. At the university where this course is famously taught, a conflict with townspeople led to an academic exodus. In what year did this pivotal dispute occur?

Starting with the legal process that dictates who inherits a particular European crown based on a key act from the early 18th century, consider the ceremonial body that proclaims the identity of the new heir. This new sovereign, as a lifelong head of state, then receives a sworn pledge of loyalty. Focusing not on a female who rules in her own right, but on one who becomes a consort through marriage, identify an empress consort who was born in a famous Austrian city and whose father was a Holy Roman Emperor. Her full name referenced a combined dynasty, the first part of which refers to a house that held the imperial throne for centuries until its male line ended. The second part refers to the house it joined with via a mid-18th-century marriage. What was the original house from which this second house descended as a junior branch?

A noble title, first created for a man who became Duke of a nearby island, was later recreated and then forfeited by a nobleman who fathered a 'Nine Days' Queen' and was descended from a queen consort through her first husband. Following the legal principle of ruling 'by right of one's wife', a German prince became king of a different nation. His wife, the queen regnant, was born in a South American city, daughter of an Emperor whose realm was previously a constituent kingdom. This kingdom was elevated to its rank by her grandfather while he was Prince Regent. This regent later became king and, after the kingdom's independence, its titular Emperor for life. What was this final monarch's nickname?

Starting in a U.S. city on a major river, named for a chief's first-born daughter, follow the type of steam-powered vessel common on such waters to a specific European paddle steamer named after a celestial event. This ship was built in a Scottish town that originated as a hamlet and became a port for a larger city due to a shallow river. Such a port would house a building for overseeing trade, a specific instance of which now sits on the north bank of a river in a major European capital. An architect famous for rebuilding over 50 churches in this capital after a great fire is connected to a particular college there. At this college, which has the largest undergraduate population of its university, how many Nobel Prizes have its members won?

A 1948 film portrays a famed slugger who was later named an inaugural member of his sport's Hall of Fame. This player was honored on a team chosen by fan vote in 1999, which followed a similar team selected two years prior by writers in conjunction with the annual "Midsummer Classic". One television network that broadcasted this yearly event also produced a "Game of the Week". During a season aired by such networks, a Chicago team, featuring the league's MVP and top pitcher, made its first postseason appearance in nearly four decades. Who was this team's general manager?

A military intervention was launched in 2015 to support the ousted leader of a specific republic. The southern part of this republic was once a separate country, which emerged from a federation of states under British protection that grew to include 17 members. A particular sheikhdom was a founding member of this federation's predecessor, and it had separated from a sultanate from which a 'lower' sultanate also split in the 18th century. The 'upper' version of this sultanate was the last state to join the 17-member federation. This sultanate was a constituent of a larger protectorate that initially comprised agreements with nine tribes. What was the capital of another state within this same protectorate, which signed its formal protection treaty in 1895?

Starting with the type of word that conveys action, which can be altered to show when it occurs, consider a different alteration that describes how the action unfolds over time. From there, isolate the form indicating a 'completed' event. If this form is combined with a future reference, the resulting construction in a certain language requires a helping verb. This helper often belongs to a small class of defective verbs that express concepts like obligation. These verbs help realize a wider system for conveying a speaker's belief or intent. What is the two-word concept, mentioned as being equivalent to this system, that describes a speaker's general intention?

Starting with the organizational concept of a military unit containing four main regimental parts, find a specific division of this type that was based in the capital of a former southern German kingdom. From this European force, shift to the official ground army of an Asian empire active until the mid-20th century. A key founder of this empire's modern government was a warrior from a southern province. His second son, who was adopted into another family, went on a diplomatic mission to the U.S. Now consider a different statesman of that era, a noble who became prime minister twice and was a childhood friend of a future emperor. The political era he thrived in was shaped by a feudal domain whose leader made a disastrous alliance before a decisive battle. What was this domain's capital city?

Starting with the process of adapting foreign words, as exemplified by a term from a Romance language, identify the country where this language is officially spoken in its southern region. A monarch of this nation who reigned during the first great global conflict of the 20th century was succeeded by his son. This successor later had his brother serve in a specific regency role while he was declared unable to reign. This role connects to a title for an heir apparent in an island kingdom, which is always granted with a specific earldom. This title is an example of a dignity held by only one person at a time. What is the first name of the specific person cited in an example distinguishing this type of singular title?

Starting with the discipline of designing human tools, find a term for a unified whole derived from Greek. This term is part of the title for a British scientist who designed a specific apparatus for nuclear plants. That apparatus's name is shared by a rap album whose promotion mentioned a legendary quartet, a clue leading not to them but to the unfinished project of an American guitarist. A posthumous compilation of this work featured a drummer from a West London borough who gained experience as a session musician. This connects to a contemporary English performer, unique for having all three of his top-ten hits reach number one. What was this final artist's birth name?

Starting with the theological viewpoint that a divine being provides all people a chance for salvation, a concept within a larger debate about the destiny of the unevangelized, follow the path to a strategist who coined a term in 1990 for a global region with little access to this message. This man, who attended a theological seminary, once led a movement that ended in 2001. A different seminary, born from a missionary training institute, is affiliated with a denomination that was formed from an 1897 merger of two organizations. A college that shares this affiliation is home to a waterfall. What is the English meaning of the indigenous word that gives this waterfall its name?

Start with an ancient primate group from an island nation, known from remains up to 26,000 years old. This group belongs to a larger order that includes a family whose genus name was created by adding a Latin prefix for 'pleasant' to an existing primate genus. One species within this genus is named to honor a foundation, while another, found in a specific biosphere, resides in a type of natural environment that provides food and shelter. A specific example of this environment is a coastal wetland formed by sediment from tides. When this wetland and its inhabitants are viewed as a system of interacting components, by what process does energy first enter the system?

Beginning with the physical law describing a black body's radiation in a state of thermal balance, navigate to the concept of that balanced state itself, where no net flows of matter or energy occur. From there, consider a type of system completely sealed off from its surroundings. Next, identify the fundamental principle dictating that a certain property of this system never decreases. Then, pivot to a related system type that can exchange energy but not matter, a concept used in a broad professional field focused on designing and building. Within this field, what computer-based method aids in design, and in a comparison of its software, what specific example of a two-dimensional drawing is mentioned?

Starting with the actor known for portraying a fictional character since a British soap opera's 1960 debut, an achievement noted by a global record-keeping publication founded in a major English city, identify an entertainment complex in that same metropolis. This venue's abbreviated name was used in a poem by a man who later became his nation's Poet Laureate. This poet belonged to a Christian tradition whose Catholic-leaning branch was influenced by a group of theologians from the era of two identically named kings. These thinkers lived through a period of civil strife involving monarchical loyalists. In another country, centuries later, what term described a loyalist who supported a particular imperial dynasty?

Starting with a silent film from the late 1910s about two mining partners, identify its director, who also trained a famous canine actor originally bred in Germany. This dog's breed is a modern one, developed for pastoral work, placing it in the broader category of canines that perform tasks for humans. This larger group includes dogs specifically trained for managing livestock, a behavior derived from predatory instincts. A breed with a misleading name suggesting an Oceanian origin, but actually developed in the US, is an example of such a dog. According to the set of guidelines that defines breeds like this, what entity is explicitly mentioned as *not* being responsible for devising these standards?

Consider the first pontiff to formally canonize a saint. A Norman leader who died in the same year as this pontiff commissioned a writer to chronicle his people's history. A later chronicler from that same Norman land hosted a French monarch at his abbey. This king's chaplain on an eastern expedition was a confidant of an abbot from a noted religious house. The commune containing this royal burial site is a subprefecture within a larger administrative division. What is the official number colloquially used to refer to this final division?

Starting with the historical capital of the Savoy region, consider a military adventurer from that duchy who organized a native Indian army that was the final resistance against the global power known as 'the empire on which the sun never sets.' A movement within this empire to abolish human servitude later inspired a Jamaican uprising, also called the Christmas Rebellion, led by a preacher from a Christian group. This group produced a mid-17th century confession of faith championing a doctrine that requires a spiritual rebirth for church membership. What is the name of the American musical group that shares its name with this spiritual concept?

Beginning with the 1955 act that established the professional head of a major Asian army, which replaced the previous supreme commander position from the colonial era, consider the command structure that leader oversaw. This structure had responsibilities for a colony in the Middle East, which published its own official government periodical. These periodicals are typically established by a formal written enactment of a legislative body, which governs by the principle of voluntary agreement. What is the assigned vulnerability identifier for a security exploit that subverts this principle of agreement by using data compression to reveal secret web content?

During a specific collegiate gridiron season where one team won a game on a last-second deflected pass, a different team dedicated its season to its starting signal-caller. This player of Pacific Islander heritage tragically succumbed to a fatal illness while participating in a sport often considered the tier below the professional level. Decades earlier, another player in this sport, notable for his very light weight, was a quarterback for an institution led by his own father. What is the number of championships won in a now-defunct athletic conference by a different historic program that was founded in 1893 and was once coached by a three-time national champion?

Starting with an architectural style prevalent across a vast Asian region, consider a grand congregational mosque built within the capital province of that style's modern heartland. The dynasty responsible for this mosque's construction can be genealogically traced, via one of its short-reigning rulers, back to the son of a famous Mongol conqueror. This conqueror's grandson founded the precursor empire in that nation. A later, significant dynasty in this same nation established a specific school of faith as the state religion. What is the inaugural year of a quarterly academic publication dedicated to the study of this particular faith?

Start with a list of people sharing a common surname and find a jazz percussionist who played with a certain hard bop keyboardist. This keyboardist, taught by his mother and influenced by a famous piano-playing singer, released an album in 1978. Now consider a contemporary trumpeter who played a custom-designed horn and relocated from the West Coast to the East. He played a style popularized by a showman known for his bent instrument. This showman often worked with a saxophonist also known by an avian nickname, with whom he co-authored a composition based on another popular song's harmony. On what date was this piece first recorded?

Starting with an Italian artist known for prints of both a famous city and imagined jails, consider the profession of his architect relative. An ancient empire's version of this profession adopted the style of an earlier culture that flourished in a specific sea. Of the two largest islands in this sea controlled by one of its bordering nations, identify the one noted for its wine production. The treaty that established the modern borders for the nation controlling this island also impacted a diverse city north of another country's capital. An ethnic group with historical claims to this city has an autonomous governing body. What are the armed forces for which the president of this body serves as commander-in-chief?

Starting with a London-based mental health trust founded in 1920, consider a term it studies, coined during a major global conflict for a condition resulting from intense bombardment. A modern military term for acute behavioral disorganization is historically linked to this condition, which can precede a more severe disorder developed from prolonged trauma in inescapable situations, such as certain internment facilities. One such facility, operated by a European colonial power in North Africa, existed during a subjugation campaign that concluded in 1932. This campaign ended with the execution of the primary indigenous rebel leader. Now, consider a different secular, anti-occupation organization that emerged in a Middle Eastern country in 2003, composed of former regime loyalists. What is the birth year of this organization's leader?

Starting with the memory system that combines personal experiences with general world knowledge, consider the phenomenon where the 'personal experiences' component cannot be retrieved from one's early life. This type of memory, allowing one to mentally revisit past moments, is distinct from its counterpart dealing with general facts. A progressive disorder defined by the loss of this 'general facts' memory is linked to a pathological process that causes tissue loss in two specific brain lobes. A protein implicated in this process is also central to another dementia diagnosis common in the very elderly, which often co-occurs with the most widespread cause of dementia. For this most widespread disease, what is the typical survival duration after diagnosis?

An American social scientist co-authored a book on a process where community members take collective action. A pan-regional development fund, which shares goals with the professional discipline based on this process, was established by a specific council within a league of nations. While this council coordinates economic integration, a separate non-governmental union represents the private sector of the same league. The economy this union promotes has a burgeoning telecommunications industry which has fostered globally competitive companies. A major construction firm, founded mid-century at the core of one of these groups, was established by a businessman who was prevented from leaving his country under one leader but later thrived under another. In what year was this patriarchal founder born?

A railroad formed in the early 1900s ran through an Ohio port city. From that city, another rail line operates, named for a Michigan municipality it serves. That municipality is home to a major university whose men's basketball team won its conference's postseason competition when it was held for the first time on the East Coast. A key player on that victorious squad had previously been named the top high school player in a neighboring state. A team from his home state's university later celebrated the four-decade anniversary of an undefeated national championship season. Who was the head coach of that unbeaten team?

Beginning with the Californian educational institution established in the 1880s by two siblings, focus on the elder brother, a Canadian-born engineer, and then his younger brother of the same profession. One American city they developed later hosted a motorsport venue for four dominant racing sanctioning bodies. Now, shift focus from the racetrack to a musical mixtape released in January of a mid-2010s year by an artist known for pioneering a particular hip-hop subgenre. This rapper's debut album includes a contentious track featuring two other performers. What is the title of that debut album?

Starting with the subordinate of a railway company's Superintendent of Locomotive Engines, consider the engineer who succeeded this subordinate. This successor designed an express locomotive class for service in a southwestern English region. Inside such an engine, a key component travels within a chamber. This component is attached to a rigid member by a pin. In some very large engines, that pin is housed in a sliding guide mechanism. Besides transferring force, what additional function can this traveling component perform by covering and uncovering ports in its chamber?

Starting with the philosophical concept of a conscious individual who can act upon an 'object', consider the capacity of an actor to perform such actions. When multiple individuals exhibit this capacity together to complete a task, it's a form of a broader phenomenon where a group acts to achieve a common goal. A 1965 book analyzed this phenomenon, explaining how concentrated interests prevail due to a type of market failure where some benefit from communal resources without paying. This problem is relevant to the benefits humans freely gain from natural environments, such as forest ecosystems. For a specific woodland plant community that is an example of such an ecosystem and is found in a western U.S. state, in which northwestern territory of a neighboring country can it also be found?

Starting with one of the initial four military parks established by federal authority in the late 19th century, find another of these original parks that commemorates a struggle over a strategic rail intersection. The battle it is named for involved a surprise attack launched from a Confederate base in that very city. In that same city, a subsequent major engagement occurred later in the same year. While a different Union force named for a major river was formed earlier that year, consider another Union army named for a geographical region, which was created on a major holiday the year prior. The principal commander of this regional force, a hero in a different confrontation, passed away in his historic home. In what year did this occur?

A process for deforming metal creates an 'ultrafine' grain structure, which can be altered using a specific thermal procedure. This procedure shares its name with the second album by an artist, which followed his acclaimed debut record. The creator of that debut was inspired in his youth by an iconic English rock band. This band later released a compilation album featuring their chart-topping singles. One of these hits was the first song released on the band's own record label. According to the compilation's description, when was its most comprehensive, multi-disc deluxe edition reissued?

Starting with the study of geological expulsions that are often named for famous locations, consider the island state formed by such activity, which was the last to join its nation. In a high-elevation park on one of its main islands, a specific type of vehicle drivetrain is suggested due to the terrain. A part used in such vehicles transmits power at a constant speed, but a different type of mechanical coupling, which does not, is named after an Italian polymath. This Renaissance scholar is known for introducing a specific set of numbers to the West. What is the name of the triangular array formed when these numbers are arranged in successive rows?

Starting with the general concept of a government body tasked with intelligence gathering, consider a specific Middle Eastern agency founded in the early 1920s that was later placed under an interior minister. This agency, like others, utilizes various collection disciplines, one of which gathers information from people on the ground. Another such discipline, using aerial photography, was greatly advanced by a British air service's innovation in the late 1920s. This technique was vital to a WWII Allied campaign targeting a long-range weapons program. One nation involved in that campaign had an air defense command established in the mid-1920s, which was later reformed into a more specialized unit that achieved fame in a 1940 air battle. After a wartime split and re-establishment, in what year was this famous unit permanently dissolved into a new command?

Beginning with a deadly terrorist incident on an Indonesian island, find the capital city where one of three devices exploded. This city is near the tourist district, a former fishing village, where the main attacks occurred. A global chain of music-themed restaurants, later acquired by a Native American tribe from Florida, has a venue there. A hotel from this chain is part of a Singaporean resort complex whose aquarium was surpassed in size by a newer Chinese theme park. An arctic mammal found in that park also inhabits a sea whose principal port is what city?

Starting with a synthetic element named for a science benefactor, which has twelve known variants, consider another element from the same series named for a pair of radioactivity researchers. The general term for the variants mentioned in the first element's description was coined by a Scottish doctor who also authored a novel about a student in her field. Among the non-radioactive type of these variants, one element possesses the most, with ten. This type includes a subset of ancient nuclides that predate our planet, numbering 286. According to a comprehensive list of these entities, what is the specific count of those currently considered observationally stable?

Starting with the random leaping of suspended particles in a fluid at thermal equilibrium, consider the branch of physics that explains such behavior using statistical methods. A view within this field sees it as an inference process, applying techniques from an interpretation of probability where it is treated as a state of knowledge. The laws for this interpretation are justified by a theorem that derives them from postulates. These formalizing assumptions define a probability space, which is one example of a more general mathematical object from measure theory. If the measuring method is removed from this object, what is the alternative name for the resulting pair, composed of a set and a collection of its subsets that is closed under complement and countable unions?

Starting in a Greek town known for its ancient mysteries and a long-running arts event, consider the goddess of the harvest who was central to these rites. Within the same mythology, there is a goddess of the hunt, a protector of young girls. This mythology also tells of a woman whose father's city in modern-day Turkey was reported on by a Roman author and naturalist. This author studied natural phenomena, like the type of event that occurred undersea in the Pacific, sending ash into the atmosphere. Such events are studied by specialists like a particular New Zealand seismologist whose father was also a surveyor and astronomer. In what location was this father born?

On the world's second-largest island, consider the administrative province covering its western half. This province contains two notable peninsulas; from the one described as being south of the other, identify its northern counterpart. This avian-named landmass has a similarly-named counterpart on the island's opposite edge. This second peninsula represents the easternmost extent of a major highland chain. Within this chain, a specific mountain range is found in its southeastern section. A famous foot thoroughfare, the site of a significant military engagement during a global conflict, passes through this range. In what year did this engagement occur?

Starting from a city at the junction of a tributary and a larger river, follow the tributary to the second-longest waterway in its nation. Identify the commission that administers this waterway's basin, then find its parent ministry responsible for the country's water resources. This ministry belongs to a group of over twenty similar executive departments. From the general term for such a governmental body, pivot to the executive organ of a former superpower, which was once called the Council of Ministers. Who was the leader of this organ's final administration?

Starting with the concept of failing to meet loan obligations, which led a major company to file for a specific legal status, consider the process that is a less expensive alternative to this status. This alternative process aims to improve a debtor's ability to pay debts, for which a simple calculation method, a type of ratio, is provided. This ratio is an indicator of a firm's ability to meet short-term obligations, and these indicators are a type of mathematical comparison used to evaluate a company's financial state. In an example for one such comparison that measures assets provided via borrowing, what is the value of total liabilities?

Starting with the leader of a 1794 Polish national uprising, consider the political event that his actions followed, which ended his country's sovereignty. During the era of a renowned French emperor, this emperor's forces won a battle in a German city, but the victory was hindered by a lack of mounted troops. These troops were historically named for the shorter firearm they carried. A specific Soviet-designed semi-automatic example of this firearm class, created in 1943, used a particular cartridge. This cartridge remained the standard in its country of origin until the 1970s. What is the designation of the cartridge that largely replaced it?

Start with a football team from Spain's southernmost autonomous community, founded in 1971, which played over a dozen seasons in the nation's fourth-tier league. A founding club of the top league, based near Bilbao, once played in the division directly above that fourth tier, and this same Basque club won a specific national cup final by scoring five goals. Now, consider another historic club, founded in the early 1900s, that plays in the country's oldest professional stadium and competes in the main national cup. During a civil war, a special one-off cup was held, but one invited team chose to tour North America instead of participating. This touring team is known by a three-word motto in its native language that reflects its cultural symbolism. What is this motto?

Starting with the language family first classified in the early 18th century, consider its insular branch named after a term for an indigenous Briton. A language evolving from this branch, spoken in a South American colony, is native to a country that borders an English county. Within this county's main town, the birthplace of a famous naturalist, is a school named for a romantic poet. This institution was originally an example of a certain type of establishment, which was itself part of a larger, three-part educational structure. Besides the selective schools and the type the poet-named institution originally was, what was the third type of school in this structure?

Within a major city park, which once accommodated a global exposition and a summer athletic event in the same year, lies an animal attraction. This type of facility is popular on a continent traversed by the world's longest motorable road system. This road system is famously broken by a wilderness gap that requires an all-terrain vehicle to cross. A specific British automotive brand known for such vehicles produces a luxury sport model that was first imagined as a show vehicle. What is the name of the individual credited with inventing this category of show vehicle?

Starting with a post-WWII financial agreement negotiated by an economist who founded a new school of economic thought, consider a macroeconomic model that uses this thinking to explain changes in national income. A key measure in this model, representing the monetary value of goods, is also used to rank the sub-national divisions of a particular commonwealth country. Beyond its mainland administrative areas, this nation possesses an external territory containing its only two active volcanoes. These related geological features form a specific type of landform. What is the alternative two-word term for such a collection?

Starting with a set of four geometric postulates from 1932 that were later modified by an academic group, follow the path to the educational reform this group created after a mid-century satellite launch. This reform had a UK counterpart, a project developing textbooks for secondary schools where pupils work towards a qualification linked to a performance indicator whose name suggests a university passport. In the country whose state schools do not use this system, education is overseen by a legislative body established through a 1998 act. Within this unicameral body, how many members are chosen via the plurality system to represent individual geographic areas?

Start with the English cleric nicknamed the 'Profound Doctor' for his scholarship. Follow his work on logical puzzles, which were inspired by an ancient philosopher's treatise on faulty reasoning. From that treatise's topic, consider the specific error of assuming a whole's properties apply to its parts, and then its inverse fallacy where a part's properties are applied to the whole. This second error is related to a Latin concept for 'the whole for a part,' a type of a broader rhetorical device using association. Within the description of a specific subtype of this device, what distinct field of writing is named in a final section?

Start with the longest written supreme law of a certain South Asian nation. Within one of its schedules, find the list detailing shared legislative powers, which in turn mentions a second list pertaining to regional governing bodies. These lists delineate the authority to levy financial obligations on specific commodities. Consider retail outlets at international transit points which are exempt from such obligations, a system that is part of a wider commercial practice attracting tourists. This practice is popular in a US state notable for having the fewest counties. Within this state's most industrialized county, there is a city on a river that was originally founded, later lost to a Scandinavian colony, and then reconquered by its founders. What name was given to this settlement upon its reconquest?

Beginning with a vocal delivery style that mimics speech rhythms and is often used in sung vocal works, consider a renowned German composer who was a student of an opera composer and conductor. This musical art form was also the medium for a Russian innovator, part of a famous group of five, who wrote a "national music drama" depicting a historical rebellion. This drama concludes with an event where a group takes their own lives simultaneously. What year is found in the title of the final subject, which discusses such events in a modern context?

Beginning with a Portuguese knight who served a famous navigator and co-discovered an island with a fellow commander, consider that this island was known before his country's claim, as shown on maps from the mid-1300s. The knight's companion in discovery later governed a region on a nearby archipelago, which eventually hosted a professional men's golf competition that was dually-ranked with a developmental tour. This second-tier tour is a fallback for those who pass an annual qualification tournament but do not secure a top-25 spot. The generic name for such a tournament is associated with a women's professional tour, whose inaugural season included fifteen events. What was the end date of that first season?

Starting with the world's largest Christian church, consider its central administration and the administrative institutions through which it operates. A former council within this structure, which dealt with non-clergy members, was part of the same organization where a South American cardinal served for over two decades from the mid-1970s. In his home country, a city that is the seat of a Catholic archdiocese is located 100 km west of the nation's capital. In a town within that capital's urban area, which is home to a National Military College, what is the name of the national Air Force's aerial unit based there?

Consider an ancient governor's territorial unit, whose name, derived from a classical empire, became a common term for an administrative division. A medieval Central European equivalent of this unit was governed by a voivode. One such administrative unit, existing between two specific years in the late 20th century, was named for its capital city. This city was the seat of a ducal line from a dynasty that originated from the 12th-century fragmentation of a kingdom, receiving a certain province. A 14th-century congress later transferred this province's sovereignty to a different crown. A modern country, containing a remnant of this province, is bordered to its south by what nation?

Starting with a vast undersea mountain range in the Pacific, consider the flat-topped volcanic mountains within it, first described by a geologist who served as a naval officer during a major 20th-century conflict. This 'founding father' of plate tectonics based his theories on a dense, ultramafic rock from the mantle, which is a key component of geological sequences representing ancient oceanic lithosphere. Following these sequences to a 'Peri-Arabic' country in Western Asia, navigate to its third most populous city, a former capital under a 16th-century dynasty. Within this city lies its oldest minaret, dating to the 11th century. What was this minaret's original height in meters?

Starting with the major religious council that addressed its institution's relationship with the modern world, find a decree it issued on social communication, whose title translates to "among the wonderful." Move from this document's literal text to the interpretive "spirit" of the council, a concept embodied by a term meaning "bringing up to date." This interpretive approach was deemed so important that a senior cleric proposed a committee to protect it. The pontiff who initiated this renewal once served as a delegate to a transcontinental nation. In a modern province of this country, a decisive battle led to an emperor's capture and enabled a significant cultural shift in the region. What year did this battle take place?

Starting with the top football division in a Baltic state where the climate halts play in winter, find a club from its capital whose name recalls a historic battle. A "Golden Player" from this team later moved to a Central European nation, the home of a club he previously faced in a continental competition. The official language of this mountainous country is a standardized form of a West Germanic tongue. A group of its upper dialects, named after an ancient tribal alliance, is spoken in a neighboring country. A specific dialect from this group is associated with a Swiss canton's plateau. What city's formal speech provides the de facto standard for the pronunciation of this language?

Starting with the topic of a person's death while detained by authorities, consider a North African nation where such incidents and discrimination against religious minorities are documented. An international advocacy organization, which has noted growing intolerance against a native Christian minority there, was also a founding member of a campaign that won a major peace prize. This organization's work promotes the body of global law made up of treaties between states. A specific review process, established by a global body's resolution, periodically examines all member states' performance under this law. This process complements other bodies, including a former continental group of institutions that was superseded in 2013. In which city did its successor network establish its permanent secretariat?

Begin with the premier French art institution of the 18th century, which was modeled on an academy in a major Italian city that hosted winners of a prestigious national prize. One recipient of this prize, a famed neoclassicist painter, admired a High Renaissance master who died young. This master belonged to a trinity of great artists; consider the member of this group who was a polymath and created the most reproduced religious painting. This artist's patron became duke following his nephew's demise. The nephew's city, before becoming a dukedom, saw a coup establish a new hereditary rule. What Italian term is used for this "Lordship"?

Starting with a glossary of mathematical topics, identify the study of algebraic structures once called "modern". A branch of number theory uses these techniques to study objects including a specific type of field. Meromorphic functions associated with these objects generalize a more specific function, which was extended to complex variables in a 19th-century paper linking its zeros to primes. A famous conjecture about these zeros, which belongs to a list of 23 problems, can also be generalized. These generalizations are proven only for function fields, not for another kind of field defined as a finite extension of the rationals. In field theory, what theorem, which is also known by a specific mathematician's name, characterizes these finite extensions when they possess a generating element?

A Malayalam film from the early 1980s features a lead actress whose younger sibling, also a performer, comes from a village in a district. This district is the most southerly administrative region of a coastal state formed in the mid-20th century. Within this state, identify its most densely populated city. This metropolis contains a downtown area known for housing the state's largest stadium. The major junction in this downtown area leads east to a nearby region. From this final region's four-directional highway signal, what is the name of the junction located to its south?

Starting with a cleaning product that became popular in homes during the 1990s due to a specific chemical additive, identify that controversial antibacterial agent. Next, consider the class of substances that halt bacterial reproduction, and from there, identify its lethal counterpart mentioned as a contrast. A protein belonging to this lethal class, which is a key part of the body's natural defenses, was a research subject for a Dutch physician who later became an emeritus professor at a medical college established in the 1840s. This institution operates a pioneering rehabilitation center named after its founder. What is the birthplace of this founder, a key figure in a mid-20th century international health movement?

Start with the WWII aerial supply corridor that moved American aircraft to the Soviet Eastern Front. Find an airport that was a stopover on this route and now serves as a hub for five regional airlines, one of which was formed in 1997. This airline is based in the world's largest subnational governing body by area. Off the northern coast of the Siberian region containing this republic lies a marginal Arctic sea named after two related explorers. Within this sea is a large tidal estuary, which is divided into two straits by an island of 1764 km². What is the length of the smaller, elongated, granitic island located 15 km north of this dividing landmass?

Start with a list of a Commonwealth nation's bilateral agreements, then find the section on legal instruments within a list of that country's satellite ground stations. Next, from a broader catalogue of the nation's treaties, identify a specific non-governmental land agreement mentioned in the section on compacts with Indigenous peoples. This agreement was nullified by the holder of a state's viceregal office. Find a person who held this office and was also a former air force commander. Now, consider a different senior officer from a major 20th-century conflict who was educated at a related military college and later became a Commander-in-Chief in the Middle East. What was the name of the light infantry unit, renamed in 1908, into which this officer was commissioned?

Starting with a leadership post created in a Greater Manchester city, consider the political party that petitioned for its creation. This nationalist party is often contrasted with a Scottish equivalent but is on a different part of the political spectrum. A broadcaster who later became a Member of the European Parliament for a different party championed a similar ideology critical of continental integration. This political stance was a key factor for a future president of a Central European nation. In the two-round election that brought this man to power, the incumbent was defeated. During that same year, a female activist with a degree in classical philology, who held a senior post in the national legislature, was known for co-founding an organization advocating for state neutrality from religious influence. What is the birthplace of a fellow politician and businessman who shared this anti-clerical focus and founded his own party after dealing in distilled beverages?

Start with the palace mayor who governed a northeastern Frankish land, and later allied with the king of a western realm against a queen regent. This western king's son, who became the last truly powerful ruler of his dynasty, married a woman of Saxon heritage. After the king's death, she became regent and co-ruled with an official who was eventually succeeded by a relative of the king's mother. What was the location where this successor's own son, while fleeing with a monarch and the royal treasury, was ultimately murdered?

Start with a biographical text by a Roman historian about his general father-in-law. A famous commander wrote a different text about campaigns against Celtic peoples, and a second one about his conflict with a rival. This conflict's narrative was continued in a supplementary work, possibly authored by a subordinate of that commander. This subordinate served during the major internal war that led the commander to pursue his rival to a foreign kingdom, where he fought a battle on a major river. According to the text describing the urban siege that preceded this river battle, through which city did the defeated rival escape en route to the kingdom where he was ultimately slain?

Starting with the first individual to hold the title of "national chief of programmes" for a Nordic public broadcasting service, identify his successor in the director-general role, who was previously a school principal in a specific coastal city. This city, once part of an electoral district of market towns and noted for a distinct architectural style, is situated on an island featuring a popular scenic hill. A peak in an Arctic archipelago, with a name that sounds very similar to that hill, is located to the east of a mountain named after an ancient city's Old Norse name. What is the name of the valley that separates these two final landforms?

Beginning in a Victorian burial ground west of a Scottish city's center, find a man noted for his exceptional ceilings who was dismissed from his post as Superintendent of City Works. He was succeeded by an architect responsible for the northern expansion of a New Town, a project whose stylistic character was later defined by the monarch's official architect for that country. This official was heavily influenced by a designer who developed his own famous "Style" after studying on the continent with an Italian artist. That artist was known for his etchings of a particular city, which is defined as the capital of two states. What is the area, in a non-metric land unit, of this city's centermost hill, where imperial palaces were once built?

Starting with a major oil company whose former headquarters in a Pennsylvanian city featured a color-changing weather indicator based on barometric pressure, consider a European "supermajor" in the same industry. This second company refines its product using a process that operates either at this atmospheric property or in a near-void. The pressure in this void can be measured in a unit named after a French polymath. A related, non-SI metric unit, introduced by a Norwegian founder of modern weather forecasting, is equal to 100,000 of the SI units. This physical quantity, caused by the weight of air, decreases with increasing elevation. Using the formula that models this change, what is the approximate pressure drop, in the SI unit, for every meter ascended within the first kilometer above sea level?

Starting with a nonprofit news organization founded in 1908 that primarily publishes in a non-physical format, consider the general term for this digital distribution method. This method often utilizes a widely-used, human-readable markup language, for which a major web standards consortium has a recommendation on how to formally describe its elements. This recommendation is one example of a broader concept for defining a document's structure. Following this, identify another, simpler schema language whose creation was based on an earlier system with a four-letter acronym. This same acronym also identifies a specific Internet Exchange Point. In which city does this exchange, established in 2002, operate?

Starting with the pressurized vessel that supplies a gas mixture for underwater exploration, consider the two-element gas used to extend dive times. The safe depth for this gas is determined by the partial pressure of its more reactive component. This mixture is a type of respiratory gas, which can also be used in machines that induce a loss of consciousness. Such substances often act on a specific ligand-gated ion channel in the nervous system. This channel is formed from multiple protein subunits, one of which is named for the fourth letter of the Greek alphabet. The entire channel complex is an example of a protein structure with five parts. What substance binds to this type of structure, causing a conformational change that allows certain cations to pass through?

Beginning with a Byzantine ivory leaf from Late Antiquity linked to a Frankish noblewoman, consider another ivory object from a similar period: a throne built for an archbishop. The craft of working this durable material is a key subject at a specialized art institute, part of a major capital city's university. This institute, noted for its collection of French paintings from a late 19th-century movement, was founded by an industrialist whose family's company pioneered a synthetic silk substitute. This man's younger brother, a philanthropist, was born in a country that is part of a larger kingdom. Based on a recent official register of chartered settlements in that kingdom, how many are located within the philanthropist's specific birth country?

Start with an entity dedicated to a social cause, then consider a specific US tax-exempt classification for such an organization. A mid-century legislative provision prohibits this type of group from endorsing political candidates. A recent president, who was a TV personality, sought to repeal this provision. This leader was the subject of an animated satire, which was a spin-off of a segment from a particular late-night talk show. The production company for a competing late-night program, the fourth in its franchise, was founded by a famed sketch-comedy creator. This media studio derived its name from its location on a major Manhattan street. In which historic building was this company founded?

Starting in an English town famed for a specific oval pastry, navigate to one of its interconnected estates where ancient ruins from 200 BC were unearthed. This town also contains a ward, once a distinct village whose manor lands were leased, that has an industrial character similar to specialized suburbs found in a certain commonwealth nation. One such industrial suburb is situated within a local government area that was originally formed as a road district in the late 19th century. A formerly rural community within this district, which became a postal district in 1959, was the original location for a railway station. In what year did this station, later moved 500 meters during an electrification project, first open?

A European volcano is famous for an eruption in the first century that destroyed several cities. One of these buried ancient towns is now located in a modern municipality, which is part of a larger metropolitan area. The capital of this area is the birthplace of an 18th-century architect who was trained by the man responsible for a celebrated Roman fountain. This teacher was also a member of a literary academy founded in memory of a former Scandinavian queen. In that same city, another large palace was later designed for a papal nephew, and it now serves as a museum of the city's history. What is the birthplace of the architect who designed that palace?

Begin with a music radio program produced by a state's public broadcasting service, and consider a folk artist known for protest songs who might be featured. This artist's famous satirical work is about avoiding compulsory national service, a practice modernized after a major 18th-century European revolution. People in such a service might attend a formal period of communal faith gathering. This gathering is a key practice in a specific country's established church, which renounced papal authority during the 1500s. The formal services of this religious body are a type of customary public ritual. This ritual is an act of devotion, whose modern name derives from an Old English word etymologized as a particular quality or state of being. What is this state of being?

Start with a protein filament that is a defining feature of a certain class of animals. Consider a method for its removal that pulls it from the root using a sticky covering. An alternative historical method, compared to the first, is thought to have originally used a viscous food produced by certain insects. Following the trail of how this food is gathered from wild colonies, an ancient activity, leads to the world's largest insect of its kind. This giant insect is adapted to its high-altitude natural environment, the term for where an organism finds sustenance and shelter. What is the full name of the predictive analysis, mentioned in the study of how groups of organisms persist in such environments, that is crucial for conservation biology?

Beginning at the first non-indigenous residence on a fertile Australian plain, identify the river on which it's situated. The source of this river is the highest peak in its southeastern region. This mountain is the fifth tallest in its state, directly preceded in height by a specific tableland. This tableland is part of a continent's primary mountain system, which itself exemplifies a landform that separates drainage areas. Shifting from this geographical principle to a specific river in a northern Italian province, this waterway joins another in a city. This second river, which starts near a major alpine pass and is the region's second largest, meets its final tributary just south of what city?

Starting with a type of quasi-autonomous UK body that functions at arm's length from government, consider a public servant appointed by the Crown who ensures appointments to these bodies are fair. Now, focus on a more localized ombudsman created by legislation in the early 2010s to investigate complaints regarding officials in a specific part of the UK. This official oversees individuals within that region's government-funded organizations, one of which scrutinizes local government and had its staff transferred to an independent body that audits over 220 public entities. This entity performs a systematic examination of records, a process overseen by a high-level executive. Although this executive's profession is unregulated, what is the name of the international standard-setting body mentioned as having over 150,000 members worldwide?

Start with the study of historical writing in an ancient republic that based its style on priestly records. Follow an early writer of this historiography who documented his own military service. Take his family name, which belongs to a large ancient clan with both noble and common branches prominent in the republican era, and from the general term for these clans, find a specific one whose name derives from the Latin for a primary color. Next, consider an ancient town whose origin is attributed to an Italic tribe and was near a villa owned by a famous writer. This tribe, long rivals of the republic, controlled territory that stretched to their capital. What is the name of the mythical founder of this capital city, a site of a major 20th-century amphibious landing, who was said to be the son of a famous Greek hero from myth?

Starting with an imperial estate established around 1140 that was later acquired by an Austrian dynasty, consider the ecclesiastical territory unified with it. The city sharing its name is an educational center with a university that has a department for a particular social science in its urban center. This social science is concerned with how a nation's output is divided, a concept whose inequality can be measured by a specific coefficient. The developer of this statistical measure was a practitioner in a mathematical branch that analyzes data. Within this branch, what is the two-word term, also used in computer science, for a variable that can take on a limited, fixed number of values?

Start with a 17th-century fort on a hill, which is part of a larger cultural heritage site designated as its nation's 31st. This collection includes another military installation whose view was obstructed, sparking public criticism about heritage conservation. Such causes are championed by a pro-democratic political group founded by a man who serves in the region's 33-member legislative body, where several members are appointed by the head of government. According to a text defining this official's role, what international agreement is cited to differentiate it from a "head of state"?
answer: Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties

question: Starting with the concept of specific molecular moieties that determine a molecule's chemical reactions, note that their interconversion is a key transformation in a particular type of synthesis. This synthesis applies to a class of compounds that includes the primary components of proteins. A method for planning this synthesis involves deconstructing a target molecule into simpler precursors. This method belongs to a branch of chemistry focused on building such molecules, a branch that is itself a subdiscipline of a larger field studying carbon-based compounds. Within this discipline, consider a reaction that removes a certain group to produce carbon dioxide, a process found in a famous biological cycle. An enzyme that performs this reaction has several human versions; two of them function outside of that cycle. What do these two versions use as a cofactor?

Starting with a former British colony that was established from a part of a vast French North American empire following a mid-18th-century war, consider the pre-Columbian peoples who originally inhabited this land. Many of these groups practiced a non-monetary lifestyle, a system that contrasts with the development of complex, urbanized societies. A key feature of these complex societies is the hierarchical organization of their members, which can be based on lineage-based units like tribes. Within such groups, customs dictate how property is passed to the next generation. Following this path, identify the traditional homeland region of a Southern African ethnic group whose language is a hybrid of two distinct linguistic traditions.

Starting with a 20th-century English composer famous for an opera that premiered in 1945, consider another prominent English composer of the same period who is noted for departing from the German-dominated style and creating nine symphonies. Of these works, identify the first one he officially numbered, which had its premiere performance led by a British conductor in the mid-1950s. This conductor is most remembered for leading an orchestra that was established by an Anglo-German pianist. Find the founder's Westphalian birthplace, which lies on a river that is a tributary of the Rhine. This river also meanders around another town that is situated near a large nature preserve. What is the name of this nature preserve?

Beginning with the public agency established in 1911 to irrigate a valley in Southern California, follow the path of its water source, an aqueduct that is the area's sole supply. This channel is fed by a diversion dam completed in 1938, which also became the water source for a reclamation project that had started decades earlier. Downstream on the same major river is the world's deepest dam, located in a narrows between mountain ranges in two different states. The range in the eastern state is part of a geological belt that contains an intermountain valley, which itself lies south of a west-flowing river. This river forms a boundary between two counties. What is the county to the south?

Beginning with the historical region known as the "Upland," identify the modern Central European country that now largely occupies its territory. Within this country's capital is a fortification at the confluence of a major river and its tributary. This tributary forms a border with a western neighbor that was once a frontier march of an empire, established near the end of the 10th century. This march was on the edge of a large basin, home to a region named for an Iranic ethnic group. This group's territory was once part of an earlier kingdom established by a nomadic people. What is the timeframe of the well-known wars between these nomadic settlers and a prominent Eastern empire?

An English-language opera was developed at an Ivy League university that was founded as a colonial college. At this university's annual alumni celebration, its own scramble-style band performs. This humorous performance style is shared by the band of a rival institution in the same athletic conference. A different musical act, also blending comedy and soul music, began as a sketch by two actors on a late-night television show and was later the subject of a feature film. The director of that film is also famous for directing a music video for the "King of Pop." Identify the actor who played the harmonica in the comedic band, and name the brand of vodka he later co-founded.

Starting in a Malaysian suburb known for a specific tourist attraction featuring a mid-19th-century fort, consider a recent special election held in that area for a seat in the country's lower house of parliament. This particular electoral district, which superseded one that had existed since the mid-1970s, sends its representative to a legislative body known as the "People's Assembly." An organization for former parliamentarians of a different country's analogous lower house is headquartered in that assembly's building. What is the total number of elected members in this latter legislative body, which meets in a famous palace?

An actress, born in a North American dominion, had a father who was a double agent for a British intelligence service. This agent, whose work involved providing power sources for ships, operated in a country whose capital is a region containing 19 municipalities. In this city's history, a major project involved burying its main river, which was later diverted to flow under an inner ring road. This road surrounds an area named for a five-sided polygon. Certain variations of a twelve-faced polyhedron are constructed by a geometric process, our final topic. This process's name comes from a Latin word. What is the English translation of the root of that Latin word?

Begin with an Ottoman author whose first biography was composed by a historian. This historian's uncle served as a religious guide for a monarch known as 'The Lawgiver' due to his development of a system of dynastic law. This system is distinct from the religious law tradition, whose modern interpretation was a subject of debate for a reformer from a nation in northeastern Africa. This reformer's work re-evaluated the role of the scholarly class who interpret religious doctrine. A poet who later held the title of supreme head of this class was appointed military judge of a large West Asian peninsula a year after being made judge of his birth city. In what year did he become judge of his birth city?

An indigenous language from an island nation is a source for a creole tongue. In the study of a reconstructed proto-language, a distinction is made for the morpheme type placed after a stem. In this ancient language, these were combined with roots to create inflected forms, such as a verb tense whose name means 'indefinite'. This tense, also known by another name for a past historic event, contrasts with a grammatical construction using a present auxiliary verb to show a past event's current relevance. This construction exemplifies a broader verbal aspect. What single English word, derived from this aspect's Latin source, defines its meaning of being fully finished?

Starting with a type of train platform named after a coastal feature and another named for a landmass surrounded by water, identify the station containing the world's longest example of this structure. This station is the headquarters for a railway zone that also operates a smaller, local station in the same city built in 1995. The zone is composed of three administrative divisions. Given that one of these divisions was created on a specific day in the early 1950s, what is the exact formation date of another division within that same zone, which is headquartered in the city it is named after?

Starting with an independent 1990s film featuring a real-life musician as himself, consider the category of performer this "father of Chinese rock" represents. This category of artist is strongly tied to a musical tradition that experienced a major 20th-century revival. A female singer-songwriter from a northern UK country, known for this tradition, released a sophomore album. A track from that album won an originality award at a ceremony hosted by a British public broadcaster. A different band, also recognized by this ceremony and active for twelve years, released a third album which became the best-selling independent record in its genre. What is this album's title?

Starting with a mid-20th century Australian charitable organization that supports those with musculoskeletal conditions, find a specific joint disease they focus on that results from the breakdown of a particular tissue. This damage leads to surgical treatments aimed at restoring this smooth, elastic padding. The name for the body's framework, of which this padding is a component, is part of the title of the thirteenth studio album by a certain musical act. Identify this top-selling death metal band, formed in the late 1980s, and then find their fourth and most successful studio album, which was the final one to feature their founding vocalist. In what year was this album released?

Consider a reflective surface shaped by a rotated conic section that focuses energy. An optical flaw common in spherical systems, which degrades image quality and affected a famous space observatory launched three decades after 1960, can be overcome. To achieve similar clarity from the ground, a specific astrophotography method selects only the best fraction of exposures. This method belongs to a broader category of techniques that analyze short exposures to negate the effects of atmospheric blurring, which has enabled the discovery of binary stars. This atmospheric effect is measured by the width of a star's blurred image, with the best conditions found at high-altitude sites. Even without this blur, a perfect circular lens produces a diffraction-limited pattern, described in an 1828 publication, which sets a fundamental limit on image detail. If this detail is quantified as 10 lines per millimeter, what is the count of just the dark lines?

Beginning with a Late Roman territory that was sectioned off from Africa Proconsularis, identify a city within it which later became a titular see. This city existed in a type of administrative division analogous to a modern state. A different example of such a division is the eastern coastal area of a neighboring country, known in antiquity by a name meaning 'five cities'. This area was eventually named after an ancient colonial settlement within its territory. The religious history of this settlement leads to the initial period of a major faith, which saw debates on whether new non-Jewish converts had to adopt older customs. The prominent figures in these debates influenced a succeeding group of theologians. In which two consecutive numbered eras did these theologians live?

Beginning with an 80s peripheral company that created printer interfaces for a home computer which often used cassette tapes for storage, consider a brand of cheat cartridge available for numerous platforms, including the first gaming console released by a major American software corporation. That console belongs to a larger brand with its own game publishing division. This division publishes a racing game franchise with a track-focused sub-series. What city and state serves as the headquarters for the American studio that was established in 2001 to develop this specific sub-series?

Beginning with a Han general who adopted Xianbei culture and controlled an eastern state formed from a collapsed empire, follow the path of power. This general's son founded a new dynasty, which was later destroyed by a rival northern state. This rival's power base was built by another paramount general. After this second general's death, his heir, who used the title "Heavenly Prince," was placed on the throne by his guardian. This involved forcing the abdication of the last ruler of the western state that the second general had controlled. This final ruler had only been made emperor after his older brother was deposed. In what year was this last monarch forced by the guardian to yield his throne?

Starting with the deity known as the "lord of dance" whose famous bronze depiction emerged in a southern Indian state, identify a town known for a major temple dedicated to him. This town belongs to a district whose namesake administrative center, a coastal settlement that saw a battle in 1758, was affected by a 2004 tsunami. Move from there to a hillock town known for large-scale agricultural trade, located near a major cultural city whose airport is 87 km away. This city became the capital of an ancient Tamil kingdom. A community of seafarers concentrated along a gulf in this kingdom's former territory is also found on an island nation across that same gulf. What is the legislative capital of this nation?

Starting in the Indian state that hosts Jain temples on a mountain where a religious figure attained salvation, identify the state bordering it to the southeast. From this second state, find its northern neighbor, a central state sustained by a river that forms a traditional boundary between the nation's north and south. Within this central state, find a railway hub that was once a center of Jainism. Near this city is another municipality that became prominent after its capture by Maratha forces in the mid-18th century. What was the common nickname of the Peshwa who led this capture?

Starting with the world's fifth-largest language family by speaker population, find a specific language within this family spoken by the majority inhabitants of an island. This island is bounded by two waterways; the western one is deep enough for very large vessels, while the eastern one was a land bridge in the distant past. A third waterway, which remained a water gap unlike the eastern one, separates two archipelagos. One of these archipelagos, an administrative regency, is part of a larger island group. What is the name of the volcanic geological feature this entire island group belongs to, which was formed by tectonic subduction?

Starting with a 1996 album by an American band whose title is a synonym for 'detestable', consider its extreme musical style. A technical sub-category of this style was played by a Nordic group formed in 1997, which shares a genre with a German band whose name means 'eater of the dead'. That band once included a guitarist who played with them from 2002 to 2006 and was featured on the solo work of their drummer. Both musicians performed on the German band's second album, which, unlike their first release, featured a full lineup. On that debut album, who contributed some of the bass tracks alongside the band's founder?

Begin with the white matter structure separating specific ganglia, and trace a motor pathway passing through its posterior limb. Beginning with a book of photographs that lists various notable women, consider a French singer and actress from that list who adopted a professional name meaning "Gabrielle of the Lillies". Begin with the Turkic nomads who fled a 13th-century Mongol incursion to a European kingdom, leading to the creation of a special judicial role. Beginning with the historical period of domination by a Protestant minority in Ireland, consider a nationalist politician born into this ruling class. Begin with a successful island rebellion against a French-born king, a conflict linked to a feud between a royal house and a religious authority. Starting with a musician central to an early Norwegian music scene, consider a felony involving the intentional burning of property often linked to that movement. Starting with a RISC microprocessor whose production was halted due to a legal agreement with a computer corporation, consider an early engineer from that firm who founded a project to preserve historical artifacts. Beginning with an index of articles on a major world religion, identify a Protestant branch named for a Dutch theologian. Beginning with the world's most popular sport, where a ball is sent into a specific structure to score, consider the university whose code of rules heavily influenced the game's modern laws. Beginning with the six auxiliary disciplines for studying ancient Hindu scriptures, consider the one concerned with tracking celestial movements. Beginning with the archaeological term for a mound created by long-term settlement, consider a specific example in the Syrian steppe whose research included a nearby necropolis. Starting from a major retail and office development in a European capital's financial center, find the nearby transit system that originated from the world's first underground passenger railway. A Greek essayist, known for his comparative biographies, wrote about a semi-mythical lawgiver who instituted a military-oriented society. This institution's members were appointed by the highest elected officials, who served in pairs. Access to this top office was originally restricted to a specific ruling class. Beginning with a female physician who pioneered university access for women with her small group at a 16th-century Scottish institution, consider a bishop of a northern archipelago who was associated with this school. Starting with the French department formed during a major late 18th-century revolution, consider two of its former communes—the sixth and third largest suburbs of a nearby metropolis—that were later transferred to another department. A proposal was made to a country's leader to elevate a transport-focused department to a cabinet post. Starting with the academic field known as the 'love of wisdom', consider a scholar from this field who also played a first-class bat-and-ball sport for a university.
