What periodical is published by an advocacy group that supports this professor's views?

A concept formalized by a French mathematician has a linear special case, which is generalized on bundles where a certain algebraic structure is attached to each point. The complex version of this structure has an invariant, a class used in a mathematical branch. What operation does a theorem in this branch relate to the homologies of two objects?

An author central to a 1960s cultural movement wrote a novel adapted by a two-time Academy Award-winning screenwriter. An actor from this film was a founding member of an organization which later established a graduate program. What is the founding year of the university that first housed this program?

Starting with a device that controls motor velocity and its typical power delivery system, consider an alternative transmission that bypasses a key gear-based component. What element is cited as forming numerous compounds of the same chemical class as a specific gaseous byproduct of the combustion process found in that alternative system's power source?

A German general was involved in the death of a field marshal who fought a British force during an invasion aimed at a canal. The campaign was near a port city connected to another settlement by two roads, one being part of a coastal highway. When was the largest road project since that highway built?

A 70s probe studied radiation from stellar explosions, which cause the brightest electromagnetic events. An observed 1987 explosion of a massive star produced weakly-interacting particles. In the nuclear decay creating these particles, what energy determines a nuclide's stability?

A 16th-century peasant revolt leader was a man-at-arms. In a major battle involving such troops during a three-decade war, a general from a certain historical region commanded one side. This region later formed a state that eventually split. In one of the successor countries, what river names a city that was once a principality's center?

A former executive for a Los Angeles professional basketball team once acted in a daytime serial. A writer for another serial—which featured a specific actress and was titled like a quest for the future—also scripted a radio crime drama. Who was the lead actor when this drama was adapted for television?

A commander in a 17th-century naval battle against European forces came from a town governed by a port city. A Mongol-led empire later succeeded an imperial dynasty, whose eighth ruler was captured during the sacking of his capital. In what year did this event occur?

The first editor of a Danish historical publication succeeded a literary historian in a professorial role. A woman sharing the latter's surname grew up on a street in a city whose medieval quarter was later ravaged by a great fire. What is the old term for the vendors who named a nearby road?

A music festival used a motto in a vernacular belonging to a linguistic family. The most prevalent Central European language in this family has a mountain dialect related to a regiolect spoken in a state with a northern district. What is the most populous city in this state?

A Portuguese imperial state was created by splitting a larger one. A basilica in the larger state's new capital city features an architectural style also seen in a London villa. This style was inspired by an ancient temple. What is the English translation of the name of the area where that temple stood?

Beginning with a country's highest administrative divisions, find the term for its core region, which contains a vast alluvial plain. A river that formed this plain flows through the capital of a province, where a temple contains a landmark pagoda from the 11th century. What language is its name written in?

An English musician was influenced by a rock band that covered a blues song rooted in folk traditions. The study of these traditions is contrasted with mainstream culture, which includes motion pictures. Name one of the proposers of a theory focusing on the technical elements of this visual medium.

From an Eskimo-Aleut language, follow a grammatical voice to its opposite which promotes the patient. This relates to constituent ordering, exemplified by a rare word order in a Cariban language. In an example of a structurally optional element described after this, what park is named?

Starting with the birthplace of an Australian rock music author, trace the path to an Italian town once dependent on mining a hard fossil fuel. This fuel, through a conversion process and subsequent reaction, produces a specific gas. Since when have the observed changes linked to this gas's accumulation been unprecedented?

The force binding atomic nuclei is a residual effect of an interaction that confines elementary particles. A type of these particles, with a lateral moniker, lends its name to an online aggregator and is classified by a model. What two-word term describes the content-passing process of that aggregator's technology?

A travelogue describes the region of a Gaelic monastic island. Its author later compiled biographies of poets. What year did the bumping race format—used in a specific competition at the university one of those poets attended—begin at that institution?

A Scottish political leader was part of a party whose name is linked to a group that opposed those making formal requests to the government. Such requests can be escalated to a nation's final judicial body for appeals. In what year was an act passed to create one such specific court for criminal cases?

If a nonpartisan election selects an official who presides over an adjudicating body, itself a type of institution governing social behavior, a concept analyzed by a field studying cultural power dynamics, what phrase was once used to describe a historical example of such cultural imposition by one empire?

A Nobel laureate's daughter worked for an organization giving a top science prize. Later, a computer scientist was part of an institution founded by a Renaissance ruler. This ruler is followed by a king called 'the Wise', who received land from his grandfather. What was this grandfather's royal house?

A poet's linguistic manifesto was published a decade after a royal edict covering legal affairs, including interment with artifacts. Such artifacts are found in prehistoric burial sites of an Iron Age people that succeeded an earlier civilization. From what culture did that earlier civilization develop?

A late 17th-century English financial decree was partially nullified by a type of law revision act. A later act of this kind also affected a Crown dependency where a certain linguistic family's influence began. What term describes how map makers recorded placenames of a related language from this family?

An engine, which powered a jet fighter developed from the first of its type to land on a US carrier, is associated with planes having a space-saving wing design used in naval aviation. Within a specific country's naval air arm, what administrative region contains a base for its northern fleet?

A German theorist's work influenced a school of thought that reacted to a philosophical work on knowledge independent of experience. This contrasts with the empirical framework for acquiring knowledge. In what city is the sociological programme that studies this framework primarily based?

A song about a woman in plastic appears on an album overseen by a producer known as the band's "Fifth" member. That band's bassist released a solo track about a relative, whose first name is shared by a sitcom character who appeared alongside another based on the show's writer. What is that writer's birth address?

An 18th-century composer's opera premiered at a venue run by the Royal Academy of Music, a company with a rival. This rival later merged with another at a hall known for hosting foreign comedic troupes. What was the start year of the famous artistic quarrel involving those troupes and the original composer?

Starting with a media company licensed by an independent US agency, a category of entities with a specific self-financing model is found. This model is used by a UK mapping body that employed an officer who attended a military school. What was that school's common moniker?

An author wrote about an ancient civilization whose medical text mentions a similar papyrus. These texts belong to a field advanced by discoveries in an oasis city. When was the term for the preserved bodies found there first used to describe accidentally desiccated ones?

A political authority, created by a 1994 self-rule accord and its scope defined by a later US-negotiated memo, administers cities in a de jure state. After a UN resolution upgraded its status, this state joined an organization that includes non-independent members. What standard gives codes to such territories?

Starting with a duck domesticated in the Americas, consider another variety farmed in an ancient North African civilization. A ruler from this civilization's 26th dynasty governed a land whose native population includes an actress. What is the birthplace of her actor-comedian husband?

The author of a famous 18th-century economic work popularized a system opposing government interventions like financial aid. In a Southeast Asian kingdom that exemplifies the opposite state-led development model, what is the minimum number of annual holidays its labor laws require private firms to grant?

A pathological thickening of a heart chamber is often an inherited condition. The study of inheritance, which looks at how genetic material is exchanged, is fundamental to a field that studies genetic differences in populations. What year was a key, four-armed structure involved in this exchange first proposed?

Starting with a sign-reversing operation for numbers whose opposites yield zero when combined through a two-element calculation, what is the name of the 'undoing' axiom for the set of all whole numbers, including those representing opposites, in a specific mathematical structure?

The deity depicted by an ancient wonder belonged to a faith that modern movements are reconstructing. A humanist who translated certain wisdom texts and a Byzantine philosopher were pioneers in this faith's scholarly revival. This philosopher cited a priestly group; who wrote the inscription with their first mention?

An author's early novel was abandoned in a city where the main newspaper stopped printing at the start of a major global conflict. A large front in this conflict exemplifies a military operational area. What is the capital of the West African nation, a top producer of a precious metal used to fund such warfare?

The study of language's link to societal hierarchy, a concept analyzed by a certain German thinker, informs a field focused on political phenomena. Following from a theory on competing interests to a book on corporate law, what is one of the two possible effects on a firm's value from influential private gains?

A rock group, named for a song by an artist from a specific label, released music on collections. One format, a 4-track tape for cars based on a continuous loop design, evolved into an 8-channel version. Its digital successor included copy protection whose concept was revived by what agency?

In the island group containing the relatives of a certain parrot is a territory whose capital houses the government offices. The head of this government is appointed by a monarch's agent. What is the listed address for the head of an international body, from a list of dwellings like this agent's home?
answer: 3 Sutton Place, Manhattan, New York City

question: A secondary school is in a coastal region containing a town where population data, like in a nearby designated place, is collected via a systematic count. What year was a research method first proposed that protects the confidentiality of this data, a concern addressed by a legal field?

A village is part of a parliamentary constituency whose primary town contains the nation's oldest purpose-built prison. In one country, a law protects the former occupants of such places from job prejudice, particularly for groups warranting the highest judicial examination. What is the legal review standard between this highest level and the default one?

A filter uses a hollow tube for a wave whose equation involves a vector field from moving charges. A medium's ability to store the field from these charges relates to a time-varying field that can generate the vector field, just like an actual current. What device measures this general current?

Within a major language family, an extinct Baltic tongue was influenced by a local Finnic one. A dialect of the official language of the Finnic tongue's nation was shaped by another dialect from a region near a large sea. What is the peninsular mainland of the country enclosing that sea?

A land force with musketeer precursors had high-ranking officers. A different army, formed during a revolution, sought a new personal sidearm through a competition. A specific 1870s model of a handgun with a rotating cylinder was used by underground fighters. Who formally named this group?

The administrative island for a Viking trading post sits in a landscape shaped by long cold periods. A boundary for that period's precipitation shares its name with a cipher submitted to a European project, which also reviewed another cipher family. Who analyzed the foundational concept for this latter cipher type?

A member of a synth rock group, fronted by a certain vocalist, later joined an industrial rock band. Following a specific year in music, an iconic Latin singer's prize-winning duet received an honor for regional music. In what year was a related, more specific version of that award discontinued?

A modern unicameral legislature shares a name with a historical assembly that evolved into a permanent session. The sovereign of this body's realm, whose power was structured by a major decree and often came from a specific noble family, presided over an entity that dissolved in what year?

The scientific study of ice covers the breaking off of large frozen masses. A specific, named fragment broke off its continent's largest frozen platform in 1999. A catalog of these platforms uses a certain region as a starting point. What ocean is this region, which makes up two-thirds of the continent, adjacent to?

A flag with unequal stripes is derived from the same source as another nation's, which later had an armorial element added. This element is on a shield, which when denoting a union, places the husband's arms to the bearer's right. What related field is mentioned in the study of such devices?

Start with the cultural realm based on representations, then a theorist who viewed literature as a 'symbolic action', and a contemporary medical professional whose mid-20th-century poetry collection inspired a musical work for chorus nearly three decades later. What was the birthplace of an English composer of religious music for such ensembles, who was once a boy in one?

The builder of the first US-made module for an international orbital outpost appears on a global ranking of top companies, which has a domestic-only counterpart. Unlike these revenue-based lists, another popular ranking uses four metrics. What is the motto of the magazine that publishes the latter?

A politician, later a head of government, attended the founding of a cathedral named for a celebration on a religious calendar. A political law contrasts his nation's multi-party system with two-party ones. What districts are essential for the specific electoral system that this law favors?

Starting with the term for an operation's number of inputs, consider the specific logical connective with only one argument. This, and other connectives, are studied in a field dealing with basic statements and their indivisible components, which represent the primary bearers of truth. Name one candidate for this general type of entity that is expressed orally.

Starting with a Henan city at a river confluence, travel to the city west of it, near which a dam for a specific energy generation was completed in 1960. This energy method is also planned for a station in a Ugandan district whose name means "pot". What town hosts the airport southeast of the main town of the district north of the "pot" district?

A long-serving heir to a European throne attended a type of self-governing school overseas. An accrediting body for such schools exists in a large northern nation whose government is founded on a monarchy. What is the primary function of the branch of this government that exercises authority?

A benefactor of a London university's forerunner embodies the spirit of charitable schools that preceded public bodies created by a key education law, later amended to compel attendance. A reformer from one Midlands city was a contemporary of this law. What was the birthplace of a trade unionist who founded a typesetters' association?

A sleeping pad rests on a base, which is part of a structure for a piece of rest furniture. An attachment to this furniture was made of a material with low heat transfer. What is the designation for the collective excitation involved in this physical property in solids?

Light measurement of opposing celestial bodies leads to a novel about a variable star. Its originator also wrote of a lunar family. A critic interested in Iroquois lore leads to a key anthology. What is the birthplace of an associated writer with a pseudonym, whose father was an accountant?

A social media giant's founding engineer attended a school within a regionally accredited southern US university. His field of study, derived from a Latin term for 'cleverness', includes a sub-discipline using industrial computers for automation. In a decentralized version of such systems, what are the distributed components called?

A pianist was a session musician for an Australian band that released a hit collection album. A single from that band's studio album, which made a major US album ranking, is about an industrial tragedy. What composer wrote the score for a film directed by a female artist who often topped that chart?

Starting at the southern end of the world's oldest canal, identify the urban district that holds a transit station where a line splits. An airline uses the successor to this district's original airfield as a focus city. On what date was this airline established?

The county of a certain high school had a militia that resisted a governor. This official later developed a town with a hotel bought by an entrepreneur who ran cross-border broadcasts. Extending this jurisdictional concept to the sea, what is the maximum seaward extent of the special resource zone?

A timeline of a rock subgenre mentions a band that influenced an extreme metal act from Newcastle. After this act's frontman formed an eponymous side project, he rejoined his main group for an album that sought production similar to another band's twelfth album. In what year was the fourth, live album of a previous group of that second band's founder recorded?

A mid-20th-century referendum in an East Asian nation confirmed the status of a socialist state that bordered a smaller puppet state. After being absorbed by a northern power, this smaller state was reformed into an autonomous region and then a republic. What is the administrative center of a southwestern district in this republic's successor?

A British military division is linked to a volunteer army. A battle involving this army for a fortress city, located in the European section of a modern country, was part of a larger conflict. What is the alternative name for the Asian peninsular section of this country?

From a list of a record company's acts, consider an English performer whose name means 'for instance'. He released a type of promotional song recording popularized by a historic quartet. A sales tracking system measures the success of such groups. According to a list of top albums ranked by a US industry body, what month and year marks the start for this system's complete sales data?

A Punjabi city was once controlled by a dynasty from the Ghor region. This dynasty's ruler fought a rival empire, whose namesake region was later governed by the son of a slave commander. What is the elevation, in meters, of the capital city established by the sultan who first employed that commander?

An actress from a sitcom based on a best-selling book later appeared in a comedy co-produced by a major studio. This path leads to a musical drama set in a school named for a politician known as the "Father" of a global organization. In what year did one of this body's charter members join?

The guard of an emperor who followed his adoptive grandfather became an administrative prefecture. One such unit on a peninsula oversaw a southern diocese, part of a larger prefecture for Celtic territories. A moth is named for a region here. Excluding this region's nation and a Balkan state, where else is it found?

An agreement amended the foundational law of a political union with a rotating council leadership. This law contains a procedure implying total accord, a concept used in parliaments to expedite formal proposals. What state adopted the procedural manual that governs these actions for most legislative bodies of its kind?

A theory on 'sensing ideas' informs our understanding of environmental interpretation, which relies on systems with specialized organs. An institute for these organs is in a nation that saw a province established from lands annexed during a series of territorial divisions. In what year did the last of these divisions create a new administrative area?

A magnetic process in atomic nuclei leads to amplified vibrations, a state found in stringed instruments. An old instrument of this type with extra plucked strings resembles a family of fretted devices, which is ancestral to a modern group. When was this modern group, whose members use a component to anchor strings, developed?

A comedian was a frequent guest on a morning radio duo's show and another country music program. In the state capital city housing the administrative hub for a major public university system, what athletic conference do the teams of this system's flagship university, which has a women's soccer stadium, compete in?

In the report that publishes an inequality-adjusted development index for a nation whose oldest medical faculty predates its law school, what year was projected for the economy of three rising countries to surpass that of a group of established industrial nations?

An ancient sage influenced an ascetic movement whose spiritual goals are detailed in texts. A 19th-century professor of the language of these texts attended a college whose campus now hosts a school with a very large quadrangle. What was the name of this school's original architect?

From a community with a long toll-free ferry, find the nearby "Queen City." A ski resort near this city lies in a mountain range spanning a US state's northernmost region. In a county in this region named for a tribe, what is the fleet size of the fare-free transit system serving its largest city?

A governor of the most populous U.S. state co-created a program for a major river delta there. This politician previously led a southern city, where a future council member, who would briefly become the city's acting head, earned a master's degree from an institution in what state?

From a language's standardized form based on its capital's dialect, bypass the variety from the area of Canton to find a language spoken on a southern island. This variety belongs to a family named after a river. What endonym for speakers of this family's southern branch includes its name?

A field studying divinity is taught in institutions that offer engineering curricula for a specialized area of information transfer. In the broader field, this requires a medium for waves, whose direction can be altered, sometimes in a reverse sense. What is a key component, not a polymer, of the engineered material that achieves this?

Starting in the Greek city known for Saint Andrew's martyrdom, which hosts a namesake public university, consider the term for this university's grounds. This term's etymology traces back to a "field" at the colonial-era institution that later became an Ivy League university. Within this university, one residential college established in 1982 is paired with another that shares its predominant architectural design. This architectural style, a subgenre of a revivalist movement, was the specialty of a certain firm. What is the name of the partner who continued this firm's work after the other founding member passed away in 1916?

Starting with a South American capital whose name means "fair winds," consider the concept of its defined boundary, a legal term for municipal corporations. This concept leads to a larger US administrative subdivision, a type which a famous city is uniquely partitioned into five of. Now, identify a city type that is not part of such a subdivision, and find the state, named for an English queen, that contains its most populous example. Within this state, locate its highest point, which is part of a larger mountain ridge. This ridge belongs to a range that also hosts a national forest, primarily of second-growth trees, in a neighboring state. During which geological period did the parent mountain system of this entire chain first begin to form?

Starting in a West African country whose name means 'Warrior King', consider its official language as a system of special legal status. This contrasts with standards that exist in practice but are not officially law. This concept of tradition guiding practice is foundational to a legal principle where a past case binds future ones, which in turn defines a judge-made legal system. An influential 18th-century treatise on this system shaped the laws of a new nation born from a colonial revolt. What is the nickname for the historical core region of this nation, which originated from a set of colonies known for their cash crop economies?

Starting with a sportscaster who won two championships in the 1960s and later worked for a major sports media brand, follow the chain to a collection of regional networks this brand owned, which were later acquired by an entertainment giant and then divested. One affiliate from this collection, based in a Texan suburb, broadcast games for a women's professional basketball team. This team drafted a player who held a national high school record for consecutive free throws and who attended a public university founded two years prior to its state's admission. This university, with ties to a national laboratory, is associated with a publisher focused on Appalachian studies. In what year was this publisher established?

Start with a Boston-produced television program about US history. One of its documentaries, which focuses on the Civil Rights struggle, aired on a public network whose parent corporation was established by a legislative act. Another media organization, established by Congress and known for its drive-time radio news, syndicates to stations often owned by public universities. A former chancellor of the system governing one such southern university, who also became the ninth commander of a special operations command, succeeded the eighth commander. This individual had taken his post from the seventh commander. During which military operation did this seventh commander's unit become the first aviation unit to use night vision goggles in combat?

In the sixth novel of a fantasy series, a young wizard prepares for a final battle with the help of his mentor, a character who exemplifies the classic literary archetype of a sagacious elder. This archetype is also embodied by a legendary enchanter from British folklore, whose prophecies were collected in a Latin work that was later integrated into a larger historical account. This account, in turn, inspired a poet's verse history written around 1155. This verse history is part of a body of literature which is one of three great medieval story cycles. What military commander from classical antiquity is named as a key figure within the third of these cycles?

Starting with a New York university that originated from a 19th-century seminary, consider a team sport played with a hoop. From there, find a women's collegiate team based in Berkeley, whose home court was funded by the owners of a famous denim company. The playing surface of this team's arena is named after a coach who led the men's team to a national title twenty-six years after the venue was first constructed. Now, think of a point guard who played at this venue, later became a head coach, and won a professional championship with a Dallas team. This player shares a position with an earlier legend, drafted first overall in the final year of the 1970s, who won a championship in his rookie season. In that championship series, his team defeated a Philadelphia team despite their star center's injury. What was the nickname of a small forward on that victorious team, who was also a three-time All-Star?

Begin with a London-born songwriter who, with a partner, created hits for an English rock group from Yorkshire famous for a song about a person residing next door. Consider that group's seventeenth studio album, then find the American songwriter who composed a Grammy-nominated song about mature men's emotions for a country artist who has sold over 75 million records. That artist released albums via an independent label on Music Row, which signed a Pennsylvania-born performer who became the youngest to single-handedly write and perform a number-one country hit. For the second single from this performer's fifth studio album, which satirizes media perceptions, what was its radio release date?

The star at our solar system's center is mostly a certain state of matter, formed from a gas of charged particles. This state is created through a process where atoms gain or lose electrons, forming an entity whose hypothetical charge in a compound can be described by a particular state. A different method for classifying covalently-bonded compounds was developed to bypass the limitations of this state concept. This classification method falls under a general formalism that includes a rule for predicting the stability of certain cyclic, planar structures. What is the classification for organic compounds that do not exhibit this special stability?

A political process for a North American country's full sovereignty was finalized by a European legislative body. This body later passed an act in the 21st century that allowed for a specific gender to fill vacancies among a group of religious figures. This led to the appointment of the first diocesan bishop of her gender, a woman who studied linguistics and language pathology. Following a major global conflict that occurred before her birth, a universal health service was founded. The branch of this service in the northernmost country of the island had a predecessor. This earlier medical service was established following a report named for the first chairman of its administrative board, who was also a prominent figure in the distilled spirits industry. What was the full name of this chairman's second wife?

Starting from a general index of musical history, focus on the events of a year in a Southeast Asian country that precedes the year a certain British rock band released their sixth studio album. In that country's capital, an idol group was formed, named after the city. This group has a Taiwanese counterpart, which was announced at the same time. This Taiwanese offshoot is a sister act to what main Japanese idol collective, whose producer also created a famous horror franchise? Among the many groups for which this producer wrote lyrics is one whose original name was inspired by a location within a certain special ward of Japan's capital. What is one of the three original wards that merged to form this special ward in 1947?

A US Army codebreaking division, established in 1930, later began a program to decrypt messages from a Soviet interior ministry. This ministry was known for carrying out a widespread campaign of political repression, which included mass operations against certain populations, such as one targeting people of a specific Baltic ethnicity. The history of this ethnic group mentions their flight as refugees during a major war, an event similar to the flight of people from another neutral nation into a neighboring country during the same conflict. In a major city of that refugee-hosting nation lies a seaside district that was once a fishing hub. What is the approximate year this district's name was first recorded?

Starting with a family of plant viruses known for causing yellow mosaic disease, find the genus within this family responsible for damaging important crops. From that genus, identify the specific virus transmitted by an insect that primarily harms a red fruit often used in salads. This fruit, a subject of genetic engineering, can be stressed by high amounts of dissolved salt in its environment. Considering the type of naturally occurring water that lacks high concentrations of these salts, and which often fills large, land-locked basins, what is the term for the geological depression resulting from past eruptive activity where such a basin can form, sometimes creating a body of water with exceptional clarity?

Starting with a woody herb whose Latin name translates to "dew of the sea", identify a key intermediate in the biosynthesis of one of its principal components. This intermediate is a type of small molecule resulting from metabolism, a process whose pathways depend on biological catalysts. Consider an antimicrobial example of these catalysts that targets a polymer by hydrolyzing the bond between an acid residue and a glucose derivative. This polymer, also called murein, provides structural strength to the cell walls of a vast domain of life. What term describes this entire domain of cellular organisms?

Starting with the Canadian awards for Christian music, consider a singer-songwriter from that nation who served as a worship pastor in a fellowship in British Columbia. This musician produced a live album, recorded in an English capital, for a UK record label. That label, which is the music ministry for a church movement, later released a children's music series. A song from this series was featured at a major annual teaching event, which now takes place at a resort in a Lincolnshire seaside town. What is the classification of the natural phenomenon responsible for transporting sediment along this town's coast?

An American newspaper established in the mid-19th century produces a daily audio news show and a weekly investigative docuseries. This series is delivered via a continuous media consumption method. A related method, allowing playback before a file transfer completes, often uses a protocol managed by a ubiquitous, open-source web server software. The majority of this server software's installations operate on a specific type of OS made from a software collection. In a list categorizing package management systems for this OS, what is the final specified system family under the heading for pre-compiled, binary packages for Unix-like operating systems?

Starting with a spoken word game where players add letters but avoid completing a word, with losers collecting letters of a five-letter term for an apparition, consider a related concept for a contest whose outcome can be perfectly predicted. This leads to a decision rule in that field for minimizing the worst possible loss, which shares its name with a topographical feature. This principle is used in a non-probabilistic decision-making model. That topographical term names a rocky point on a remote southern island, identified by maritime workers in the mid-19th century. This point marks the edge of a bay named in the same year after a captain's vessel. A headland overlooking this bay was later resurveyed by a national polar research group. What was the founding year of this research group, which conducted its first expeditions to that very island?

Starting with the medical term for a woman's death during or shortly after pregnancy, consider a compilation of notable individuals who suffered this fate. One person on this list was a nurse, celebrated on a magazine cover for her work fighting a West African viral outbreak with an international medical aid organization. This organization embodies the type of recipient for a public service prize named for two philanthropists. One of these namesakes was an advertising magnate whose firm promoted a tobacco brand that shares its name with a 1964 jazz album. The musical style of this record was the specialty of a renowned pianist and composer who was awarded an honorary music doctorate in 2009 by what institution?

Starting with a statistical method for testing a proposed relationship between data sets, consider the threshold probability, often set to five percent, which determines significance. When many of these inferences are made simultaneously, a specific statistical problem occurs. One technique to counteract this, named for an Italian mathematician and developed by another researcher, is often used. The probability value at the core of this process is common in many fields, including sociology. Erroneously rejecting the 'no relationship' hypothesis is a type of error known as a false alarm. An alternative method to the one named for the Italian is designed to control the expected proportion of incorrect discoveries. In certain fields, what is the alternative name for the initial problem of making many simultaneous inferences?

Starting with a lengthy narrative poem in an early Scottish dialect about a monarch's fight for independence, identify its author, who also wrote a lost work on the genealogy of a particular royal house. From this house, find its first monarch, who was the grandson of the poem's subject. Next, consider this ruler's eldest son from his second marriage, a prince granted a noble title for a region in southern Perthshire one day after his father's coronation. Who was the third individual to hold this title, a man who first appears in records witnessing a charter issued by a king nicknamed 'the Rough'? Finally, determine the birthplace of this long-reigning king's only son, who later finalized a treaty defining his kingdom's border.

Starting with a mythological figure who shares her name with four others, consider the one who had a son with a divine hero. This hero fathered an individual believed to be the eponym for a geographic region. Within this modern region, locate its second-largest town. From there, travel via an old route to a municipality at the base of a legendary mountain. This town guards passes into a wider historical area whose ancient kingdom once dominated its peninsula. In what year did the first major war between that kingdom and a republic from a neighboring peninsula end, as formalized by a peace treaty?

Starting with a choreographer whose uncle was a pioneering filmmaker, consider the type of academic institution that might archive such a director's work. This institution would use a security system with a magnetic strip to prevent theft, which is a specific instance of a broader technological method for asset protection. The detection gates for this method operate on a physical phenomenon involving amplified oscillations at certain frequencies, a behavior that can be described by a class of mathematical functions which repeat their values at regular intervals. This emblem was first adopted by the man who was the first to hold that county's earldom. This noble also governed a region within modern-day France. In that same country, identify a major port city that is the center of a metropolitan area including smaller, dependent communities. Using the term for such a community, what city in Pakistan contains a locality of this name?

Begin with the UK's senior naval service, which vied for supremacy with a continental rival. A prolonged battle in that 17th-century conflict resulted in the death of a vice-admiral, who was the younger brother of a royal favorite. This favorite's uncle was a royalist soldier and a co-founder of a North American province. This soldier's faction was defeated in a civil war battle and was forced to retreat to a Hampshire city. That city's cathedral is dedicated to a former bishop known for a weather-related superstition. What is this saint's feast day?

An illustrated codex is named for a book dealer belonging to a particular West Slavic ethnic group. A list of notable people of this ethnicity mentions a historian and diplomat, whose student also became a leading academic. That academic may have studied an association of nobles formed to defend their commonwealth's independence, an event which coincided with a major war where one empire's victories over another created a complex diplomatic situation. To manage this and prevent a different war, a certain monarch engineered the division of the previously mentioned commonwealth. What price was fetched at a 21st-century auction for a portrait of this very monarch?

A Dutch master of a board game won an individual medal at a global team competition held in 1966. The game played there is an ancestor of a Chinese variant, which itself is in the same family as a Japanese game known for letting captured pieces re-enter play. This re-entry rule was later adopted by a Western variant whose name implies instability, and by another version created in 1997 that was dubbed the "variant of the decade". What is the acronym for the international organization that standardizes the rules for the original game?

An annual tennis event is held in a global Middle Eastern business hub, for which a topical guide exists. This guide details a historic commercial district bordered by a creek, which contains a small port named by its founder after an Egyptian city damaged in a mid-20th century crisis. This Egyptian city forms a transcontinental metropolitan area with its twin, a regional concept whose socio-economic connections are often measured by recurring travel patterns. Based on the definition of this travel, what is the precise term for the starting location of the journey to one's workplace?

An Indian actor, born in the same year as a key figure in this puzzle's conclusion, worked under a filmmaker known for unconventional themes and strong female leads. In one of this director's early 1970s dramas, depicting a woman forced into a difficult profession, a future superstar made his adult debut. A part of this superstar's name is shared by a defender for a top-tier club in a Gulf nation nicknamed 'The Boss'. This club won the 30th edition of its continent's premier tournament, earning a spot in that year's global club competition. The football governing body in this club's home country was established after the sport arrived with oil companies. A man from this nation, who served as president of the continental confederation, was later banned from all football activities. On what date was his initial ban annulled by a sports arbitration court?

Starting with a major indigenous group in North America, consider one of their bands in a central Canadian province, which resides on a type of land legally set aside for them. Another band from the same group, near a large northern bay, uses a seasonal route over frozen water for transport. This route is a winter substitute for a different water-based travel service, like one used to reach an island in a Great Lake that served as a spiritual center for a related people. This island contains a historic burial ground that originated from a religious outreach effort established by a European in the 1830s. What branch of this faith has predominantly undertaken such work?

Starting with the solid aggregates of minerals that are transformed by extreme temperature and pressure, consider the geologic alteration process that can result in paired belts. The scientist who first theorized these paired formations also studied the chemical compositions found in magma that constitutes a major part of the planet's landmasses. These landmasses are often formed by volcanic chains accompanied by a deep depression. When a similar depression is created for civil engineering purposes, what is the term for the reinforcement method that prevents cave-ins using wood planks?

Starting with a 16th-century Scottish scholar educated in a coastal town situated between two river mouths, identify the adjacent tidal basin, a notable nature reserve. In which council area, formerly known by a different name until 1928, is this basin located? Within this area is a village where an 11th-century monarch, the last of his dynasty and known as "the Destroyer", died. This king had rivals in an English kingdom that once controlled a southeastern Scottish region. A prominent town in this region, which has an Anglo-Saxon name, was eventually granted special trading rights. During which sovereign's reign was this status officially conferred?

Starting in a historic Scottish region culturally distinct from the Gàidhealtachd, consider a U.S. Representative with ancestry from there, who attended university in a city in the Lehigh Valley. This city's former union station was co-built by a company known as the "Route of the Black Diamond" for the mineral it transported. A different company was also chartered to build a railroad from mines near a namesake settlement to a canal. This settlement lies in a historic corridor within a wilderness once called "Towamensing" by Amerindians. In which county is this borough located?

A radio station founded in the mid-1970s broadcasts from a city known for linen production. In this city, a hospital with a prominent orange tower is run by a trust created in the late 2000s. This trust belongs to a national healthcare system established after a major global conflict, a system championed by a Welsh politician from his party's socially progressive faction. The political ideology of this faction, named for seating in a late 18th-century revolution, was subscribed to by a Trotskyist group that infiltrated a major British party. What was the name of this group's newspaper, launched in the mid-1960s?

Starting with a nuclear incident in an East Asian nation caused by a massive wave, identify the electric utility serving that country's capital, which had previously closed another facility due to a seismic event. The shaking of a planet's surface is a general term for this event, and a specific measure of its regional activity involves dividing the planet's interior into layers. This planet, third from its star, has a tilted axis that creates seasons, which are marked by an astronomical event sharing its name with a musician's debut album. A Brazilian percussionist, who collaborated with this musician and died in the year associated with the aforementioned seismic events, also worked with an Argentine saxophonist. What is the given first name of this saxophonist?

Starting with a Canadian arctic island notable for its single woody plant species, consider the geological epoch that began after a mass extinction event left many environmental roles unfilled. The study of these roles, which describes how an organism responds to resource distribution, is linked to the search for wild food, a behavior analyzed using financial-style models. This connects to a field of anthropology studying human economic behavior. A key sociologist in this area, a proponent of a specific network theory, is a leading figure in the study of how society affects technological innovation. At which academic institution in a major European capital did his famous French collaborator hold a centennial professorship?

Starting with a biological classification level between family and genus, whose names are governed by certain rulebooks, consider the specific set of rules for naming organisms like fungi and algae. This practice is an example of creating a unique identifier. From this general concept, narrow your focus to a six-character alphanumeric code for identifying periodicals, and find the public university system associated with the code's inventor. This system is affiliated with a type of state-funded college operating within a private university. At the specific Ivy League institution that contains four of these colleges, what is the founding year of its specialized school devoted to hospitality management?

Starting with a right-cancellative morphism in category theory, which is an analogue of a specific type of mathematical mapping, we find that the term for this mapping was coined by a French intellectual collective. A member of this profession from ancient times is credited with applying deductive reasoning to geometry. A later polymath in this field, a pioneer in the study of optics, had his work celebrated by a global, year-long observance. This event was led by a UN specialized agency whose mission includes promoting collaboration in the study of human societies. This area of study covers the idea of respecting differences, which is interpreted by some as the blending of varied groups into a unified whole. What is the two-word term for this concept of unification?

Starting with an American automaker established in 1975, known for a single iconic car model before its 1982 bankruptcy. A new Texas-based company, founded by a mechanic from Liverpool, later acquired the original's branding. This new enterprise could leverage a 2015 U.S. law aimed at manufacturers with limited annual output, which directed a specific agency within the Department of Transportation to establish a program. This agency's mission to reduce vehicle crashes is thematically linked to the work of a foundation dedicated to traffic safety. Such a foundation would undertake systematic work to increase knowledge, the findings of which are often disseminated in scholarly journals. These publications rely on a process where work is evaluated by people with similar competence. What two-word term describes this process's function as a form of control by qualified members of a profession?

Starting with an Asian economic center known for its free port trade, consider the concept of foreign investment it champions. This led to systems like the largely duty-free Latin American factories that grew from a border industrialization program and were later formalized by a decree in the late 1980s. This decree permitted the creation of industrial sites, which, when they are a town's primary employer and landowner, form a unique type of settlement. Following this, identify a major US steel company, once controlled by a famous tycoon's financial heir, that operated this way. What was the full date of the tragic conflict at this company's mining camp, for which the heir was blamed?

An ancient, undeciphered script was used for religious writings at a Bronze Age site considered Europe's oldest city. A construction method found there involves a woven wooden lattice. A modern guild celebrates a related craft that joins large timbers, often using a specific joint made of a tongue and a hole. This type of joinery was used to construct a full-sized vessel for an ancient Egyptian ruler's afterlife, a ritual that echoes the funerary customs of certain northern European peoples. The largest burial ship of this latter type was unearthed in a modern coastal county. What is the name of this county's administrative center, which is also considered the oldest city in its nation?

Start with the Spanish runner who set a personal record at a global indoor athletics competition. A different, continental cross-country event from that same year took place in a landlocked South American country known as the "Heart" of its continent. One of this country's official languages is named for an indigenous population that was the subject of evangelization efforts by a scholarly religious congregation established in the 16th century. This congregation was a key actor during the religious schism that led to new artistic traditions. Within the movement that broke from this congregation's church, which specific branch was steadfastly opposed to having art in its places of worship?

Begin with the UK's oldest armed service. A theory on rising military costs uses this service's historic warship expenses as a case study, along with a specific two-person American stealth bomber. Consider the general term for this bomber's payload, a category that includes weapons which, in an early 20th-century war, needed special gear to avoid hitting propellers. One such weapon is a 30mm autocannon that replaced the 2A28 Grom and armed a second-generation amphibious fighting vehicle. This vehicle could use technology to see non-visible radiation in low-light. Besides near-infrared, what other type of radiation is mentioned as an example?

Starting with a list of contenders for a legislative body whose names followed a specific transliteration system, which was official in its territory for several years after 2002, consider the major post-WWII global organization with which that territory has a complex relationship. This organization sponsored a two-part summit focused on bridging the digital divide, a key aspect of the technological revolution that began in the mid-20th century. This revolution enabled the global "network of networks," where users navigate via references pointing to other data. If a dispute arises from such data, it can be brought before an institution that adjudicates on various types of matters. Besides civil and administrative matters, what is the third category this institution handles?

Starting with the first non-European to lead a major global organization, consider his predecessor, a Swedish economist who was awarded a posthumous prize. In the year this predecessor died, an economic body was formed that now publishes a bi-annual analysis of its members' financial performance. Many of these members belong to a continent where a former political divide is reflected in wealth. Within this continent, a geopolitical group of three nations lies on the eastern shore of a certain sea. One of these three fought a defensive campaign for its sovereignty after a major world war. In which city was a contemporary warlord, who adopted his surname from a prince and had a musical education, born?

In an English city's main shopping area, a Dominican priory was established, in whose cemetery the son of a principality's last sovereign ruler was interred. This ruler, along with his younger sibling, was once sent as a hostage to an English monarch. The sibling's grandfather, a powerful figure who governed for over four decades, wed an English king's natural daughter. A 19th-century academic who edited medieval chronicles detailing such lives also served as a vicar for over a quarter-century. In what city was this scholar a university registrary?

Starting with the Hindu goddess of wealth associated with a mythological sea, consider a film named for that sea which cast a specific supporting actor. This actor's wife later appeared in a film adaptation of a work by a renowned English playwright. The original play, one of the author's shortest, derives its humor from a central theme of people being wrongly identified. This theme, when applied in a legal context, can be a defense strategy that suggests a witness's testimony is a result of a distorted recollection. What year did the premier researcher of this psychological phenomenon begin her initial research project?

Starting with the mid-13th century English assembly that initiated a constitutional crisis, identify a prominent nobleman involved who was placed under the guardianship of a man that served as a high-ranking judicial officer for a particular king. This king is implicated in the disappearance of his own nephew, a former heir-designate. A court favorite of this same king, known for his dramatic rise and subsequent fall, held the lordship of a territory whose archaic name is now used for a market town. This town is situated just north of a mountain range whose highest summit had a former name referencing a legendary king's seat. What is the metric elevation of this summit?

Starting with a framework for aligning technology services with business needs, which often relies on a formal commitment between a provider and a user that can define a system's reliability using the predicted time between inherent problems, what is the name of the record label that released a live album whose title describes a physical discomfort that could be caused by a simulated version of the knowledge-gaining process that neuroscientists say helps us learn from success, rather than the state of not meeting an objective which the aforementioned time prediction is based on, where this simulated process is experienced via a cancelled home console headset that tracked the user's head's physical changes?

Beginning with a common three-to-four-year undergraduate qualification, consider a distinct undergraduate award with a postgraduate-sounding name offered by a country's oldest universities. The founder of one of these institutions, a prominent church leader, had an uncle who was a high-ranking cleric in a city whose archiepiscopal title was eventually abolished by that nation's established church. This national church later had its constitution defined by a set of articles designed to facilitate a union. A parliamentary measure gave these articles legal recognition, settling long-standing disputes about the church's spiritual independence. In what year was this measure enacted?

An entertainment company founded by four immigrant siblings pioneered technology that synchronized audio with moving pictures. This innovation led to the first full-length, all-talking crime drama, which featured an actress who had made her on-screen debut as a child in a silent, multi-reel cinematic adaptation of a famous French novel. The format of this adaptation, a series of shorter cinematic works, was later used for a popular American comedy series chronicling the adventures of a group of children. One of the most famous child actors from this series, who appeared in over 100 installments portraying a character named after a type of cereal, was born in what city?

Starting with a former department of a French empire, identify one of its cantons that lends its name to a town known for its maritime construction industry. A historic vessel, once the command post for a celebrated admiral, is now preserved in a special basin found at such construction sites and holds a ceremonial title as the lead ship. This naval term has been metaphorically adopted by the broadcasting industry. A non-profit supporting this industry in a southeastern US state is affiliated with a national media organization. What is the title of that organization's flagship afternoon news program?

Starting with the monarch whose reign saw the legal union of two kingdoms into a single sovereign state, consider the political group that had initially supported her deposed father. This group's rivals consolidated power after a general election that, due to a new law, occurred seven years after its predecessor. This outcome fueled a conspiracy, led by a high-ranking church official, to restore a previous royal house. Such an act of criminal disloyalty against the state is conceptually similar to a large-scale revolt on a Caribbean island. This historical event provides the setting for a novel about a captive girl given a new name by her masters. The actual uprising that inspired the book was led by people from what specific region?

Starting with an 8th-century compilation designed to clarify archaic terms in a specific late-4th-century Latin biblical translation, follow the path to a 16th-century movement that rejected the artistic traditions of that translation's church. This movement spawned a major branch of Christianity, from which a non-confessional form later appeared in the 20th century. An indigenous fellowship related to this form, founded in 1970, established a college on the site of a home where young women were forcibly trained in domestic work until the late 1960s. In the nation where this home was situated, what was the name of the electoral district first won in 1998 by a man who would later serve two non-consecutive terms as the country's leader?

Starting with an English legal professional who became a senior counsel in 1968, consider the type of non-inheritable title he held which is granted under a mid-20th century act. A man who later led the country in the 2010s was a member of the same political system. Find the political party he once led, which has had two female leaders. The first of these leaders appointed only one woman to her cabinet. This appointee attended a specific American university during a global conflict. The page for this institution describes a romance film from 2007 featuring a supporting actress whose father was a choreographer. In which country, apart from India and Sri Lanka, is the primary language of this actress's films an official language?

Starting with a French television channel that airs content from a major non-profit scientific society, consider the commercial joint venture through which this society manages its media. A majority stake in this venture was transferred during a corporate acquisition that also involved a partial interest in a video-on-demand service. This streaming service is now primarily controlled by the acquiring entertainment conglomerate, a company known for working with an English actress who rose to prominence on Broadway in the 1950s. What was the announcement date for the national list of commendations that recognized this performer at the turn of the millennium?

Starting with the German nobleman who served as a military attaché in North America before becoming his country's Vice-Chancellor, identify the international agreement he signed in the 1930s. The other signatory to this treaty held the high-ranking office that presides over the oldest dicastery for the sovereign entity founded in the 1st century. This entity operates under the oldest continuously functioning legal system in the West. In the second comprehensive codification of this system's laws for the Latin Church, promulgated in the early 1980s, a specific rule denies communion to those under certain penalties. According to a grammatical note about one such penalty, what is its required adverbial form when used with a verb?

Starting with a medical condition identified by an intestinal width of 9 cm on a specific imaging test, follow the connections: this diagnostic technique, pioneered during a mid-20th-century global conflict, is used to study causes of evacuation difficulty. A closely related symptom to this difficulty is a feeling of incomplete emptying, which has a neuropathic component. This nerve-related aspect can be associated with an unpleasant, abnormal sense of touch, a common example being the sensation of 'pins and needles'. This familiar feeling is a type of abnormal dermal sensation. Turning to a brief neurological dysfunction now defined by tissue imaging rather than time, what is the typical duration of its clinical symptoms?

Starting with a celebrated 20th-century boxer who won Olympic gold and later held a professional title that was rarely split in his era, follow the path to a regulatory body that, in 2016, gained authority over a different combat sport. This newer sport's name was first documented in a 1993 review of an inaugural event held by a promotion that grew into a global enterprise. This organization awards its champions with a special prize, an accessory whose first historical precursor was given by a king in 1810. What is the term for the professional boxing division with no upper limit, where the initial athlete competed?

Starting with an international system of measurement that defines a fundamental unit for time, consider the single-unit adjustment applied to civil time to align it with solar time at a particular meridian. This civil time is part of a broader specification for measuring duration. A modern time standard, based on planetary rotation, continues the mean solar time of that meridian's location, which was officially chosen at an international conference in the late 19th century. Using the mean solar time at the observatory on this line as a reference, what is the specific offset, in hours and minutes, for a particular South Asian nation's time, which is cited as an example of a non-whole-hour deviation?

Starting with the institutional act of religious censure that can lead to a formal division, like the one between Eastern and Western religious bodies, identify the resultant church, the second-largest of its kind. Within this body, locate an autonomous branch whose missionary history is tied to a diocese from a city. This city later became the administrative center for a temporary voblast composed of fifteen smaller districts. These districts are subdivisions of a larger administrative unit, which is a primary territorial division in a former, highly centralized Eurasian state governed by a single political party. How many standard time divisions did this state encompass from east to west?

Starting with the last major offensive by a Central Power on a key WWI front, which was intended as a diversion but marked the beginning of a final Allied advance, find the specific section of that front in the northwest of Belgium held by that nation's troops. This defensive line protected a city whose tower is part of a UNESCO collection of 56 structures symbolizing civic independence. Another tower in this group belongs to a municipality known for its agricultural university, which is housed in a former Benedictine abbey founded in the mid-10th century. A different Benedictine abbey near Metz became the center of a reform movement after it was given to two men for restoration; what is the name of the man who came from the abbey's namesake town?

An English rock band's seventh album was the final one with its classic lineup. Their next studio album was the first without a key co-founder. This band, noted for their two songwriters and prominent use of a specific electric piano, utilized an instrument whose sound comes from striking metal reeds. This sound possesses a perceptual quality that allows ordering on a frequency scale, a specific example being the note a semitone above C. Such notes are organized in theoretical models where proximity represents relatedness. What type of geometrical figure is cited as a way to represent these models?

Starting with the 44th U.S. President, consider the political convention where he delivered a famous keynote speech. At that event, a politician was nominated for vice president. This individual represented a state whose capital, named for the founder of a lost colony, hosts a large annual agricultural exposition. The state where this fair occurs derives its name from a monarch whose attempt to impose uniform religious practices on a northern kingdom led to a series of conflicts. In what year did these conflicts begin?

Beginning with a financial instrument where one party promises to cover another's obligation upon default, consider the more comprehensive legal term for this transaction. For such a transaction to be valid as a simple contract, it requires a specific concept of exchanged value. This concept is the "satisfaction" part of a legal method for discharging a debt obligation. An early 17th-century case involving a defendant named Cole established that partial payment could not fulfill this "satisfaction." This precedent was affirmed nearly three centuries later in a leading case on pre-existing duty. The same principle was applied in a more modern case where a company tried to pay its tax arrears in installments. What is the name of the educational institution from which one of the appellate judges in this modern tax case graduated?

Start with the American leaders who established a new government in the late 18th century. Consider their opponents who remained loyal to the British Crown, one of whose leaders was the son of a famous Patriot. Many of these opponents fled to a Canadian province whose name is Latin for "New Scotland." A filmmaker, who has directed projects in over twenty countries, was born in this province. A film about this country's mounted police was made a decade before this director's birth. A contemporary double-talk comedian appeared in films that same decade, including one released the same year as a motion picture based on a play whose rights were held by three studios. What is the birth year of a Swedish actor, often compared to a famous female compatriot, who was professionally active during this period?

Starting with a list of a specific family of nocturnal insects found in a large North American country, consider a species from that list whose common name alludes to a "rustic shoulder-knot". This creature is part of an order of insects that contains an expansive family including tiger and tussock moths. Within this family is a tribe of minuscule moths, some of which were historically misclassified into another family known as "snout moths". This latter family belongs to a superfamily that once included a different family, now recognized as its own superfamily. In what tropical realm is one of the two genera of this distinct family, known as "teak moths," exclusively found?

Starting with a lunar time-keeping system from the Indian subcontinent, follow the path to an annual soul-purifying ritual performed on its New Year's Day. This ceremony is conceptually linked to a circular diagram representing the cosmos, which is used in an esoteric Buddhist tradition also known as the "Secret Mantra" school. This school is a form of a wider spiritual system, meaning "loom," that utilizes mystical diagrams literally called "machines." A specific version of this diagram, formed by nine interlocking triangles, surrounds a central point. According to one text, this point has a dual nature; what celestial body is associated with its red aspect?

Starting with the followers of a specific monotheistic religion, who are divided into many denominations, consider a schism that began in a North African province. This movement was rooted in the empire's final and most severe persecution of those believers. During this oppression, a scholar martyred in a coastal city of Palestine was known for being an avid collector of books for that city's famed theological library. This collection contained a massive six-column scriptural comparison compiled by a theologian the scholar defended. This work is cited as the first example of a book showing the same text in several languages, but since it only used two, what more precise term is suggested to describe it?

Starting with the Anatolian-founded empire that conquered the continuation of the Roman state in the east, identify an emperor of that predecessor state who favored a new religion after a famous vision. A North American social fraternity, which has an operational body sharing a name with this leader, was founded at an Ohio university. A subsequent president of this university, who was also a minister, fathered a notable female poet. This poet's sister married a military officer who was a colleague of her husband. What was that officer's full name?

Beginning with a historical German territory that relocated its capital after a fire, consider the German town in a conurbation south of this new capital. This town sits across a river from a larger nation. That nation's sphere of influence in Africa, a concept shaped by a chief adviser who served its first two leaders under a specific republican system, is a key part of its history. What ex officio princely title is held by the head of state in that nation's governmental system?

An American DJ collaborated with a rock band whose frontman was born in 1970. That band's debut album, produced by the lead singer of a Boston-based new wave group, achieved a high rank on a major US music chart. This chart's rankings are partly based on data from online streaming services, one of which uses a specific set of access control technologies to protect its media. Similar to how these technologies restrict copyrighted works, another practice involves tracking and maintaining a certain kind of permission for software. What is the term for these permissions?

Starting with a group of diseases involving abnormal cell growth, which can be caused by certain environmental pollutants, identify a specific fibrous silicate mineral known to be one such pollutant. This mineral was historically used to strengthen a type of ceramic ware that originated in a particular Fennoscandian country. In this country's largest lake, which consists of many basins, find the central one that gathers most of the system's outflow. This area is the habitat of an isolated, endangered subspecies of a certain aquatic mammal. This creature is related to another freshwater subspecies living in the larger lake that receives the first lake's water. Among the few species that dwell exclusively in freshwater, what is the common name of a different subspecies, with a population of less than 300, landlocked in lakes in northern Quebec?

Starting in a Kowloon district described by a record-keeping organization as the world's busiest, find a historic shophouse. The building's original owner, who helped found a major bus company, was born in a Chinese city known as the "First Home of the Overseas Chinese". A pioneering Hollywood actress of descent from this city starred in a 1939 film where she searches for her father. The actor who played her primary antagonist in this film was the nephew of an Irish judge. This judge held his country's highest judicial office, which also came with what other ceremonial title?
answer: Lord Keeper of the Great Seal of Ireland

question: Starting with a failed coup in an island republic, thwarted by an intervention codenamed after a cactus, consider the geographically dispersed nation where it occurred. A Canadian-developed STOL utility aircraft, used by a U.S. military parachute team, is frequently found in this nation. This aircraft is a primary vehicle for the world's largest seaplane operator, which provides services from an airport in the nation's southernmost atoll. This airport was initially built by a European naval force and later became a station for that country's air arm, a branch of a larger armed organization. The land-based component of such an organization gets its name from what Latin term?

Beginning with a Polish industrial city in a southern voivodeship, identify the historical empire that spanned three continents and whose rise corresponded with the decline of neighboring powers. One of these was a medieval Turkic state whose territory included a modern republic named for an ethnic group. A village with a nearly identical name to this ethnic group is located in an Iranian rural district containing dozens of villages. This rural district is one of three within a larger administrative district that has only one city. This district is part of a county, located on the southwest coast of a large inland sea, which is named after an indigenous ethnic group. The language spoken by this group belongs to what specific branch of a major language family?

Begin with an abstract group named after a geometer describing reflections. Then, consider a second type of group, named after a 19th-century mathematician, where operations are commutative. Returning to the first type, a specific example is a finite reflection group used in a decomposition method named for a French mathematician. This method connects to a paired-subgroup system developed by another mathematician, where one subgroup is a maximal connected solvable subgroup. This leads to the concept of partitioning a group's elements into classes. For the second type of group mentioned (the commutative one), what term describes a class that contains just one element?

Starting with a children's story published in 1900 that led to an iconic 1939 film, identify the story's antagonist who commanded flying primates. This antagonist later inspired a new protagonist in a revisionist novel, with a name derived from the original author's initials. One actress who portrayed this new green-skinned character also played a doctor's fiancée in a Broadway revival. Another performer who played the same role originated a principal part in a musical set over three days. In which largely Hispanic-American neighborhood does this latter musical's story unfold?

Starting with the infectious disease also known as infantile paralysis, consider the process of its complete global reduction, a goal also achieved for a different disease. The last person to naturally contract the milder strain of this now-absent disease was a Somali hospital worker who later campaigned against the first ailment. The milder strain, declared globally gone a few years after this man's case, is an example of the successful global removal of a pathogen. This now-eradicated disease, which left survivors with distinctive skin marks, was combated by a vaccine. The first man to administer this vaccine in North America was a clergyman-physician who attended school with the vaccine's pioneer. In what year was this pioneer, also known for his zoological study of a parasitic bird, appointed as a special physician to a British monarch?

Starting with an American logician who taught at a New York City post-graduate institution, find that institution's founding female president, who was also a pioneer in computing. From her, identify a French actor whose surname sounds like the acronym for the university system that institution belongs to. This actor played a minstrel in a film released during the Nazi occupation of Paris. Find his female co-star, an actress convicted of treason for a wartime affair. From her, pivot to a romantic comedy released a decade prior, which was a French adaptation of a German film. What was the birth name of an actress in this comedy's cast?

Beginning with a South African politician who, for 13 years, was the solitary parliamentary representative for her party opposing a system of racial segregation, consider the head of government she stood against. This leader's life was ended by a man born in a city now known as Maputo. The national archive of the European power that colonized his birthplace was established in a castle tower in the 14th century. This nation's primary library has a specific copyright-related function, a mandatory submission process also central to a North American institution created in 2004 by merging its national archives and library. This body reports to a minister whose family fled their home after it was bombed during an era of state-sponsored terror. In which city was this minister born?

Start in the childhood city of the musical director for a weekend sketch comedy program. A Catholic high school founded in the mid-19th century uses this city for its postal address. The land for this city was part of a tract granted by a Spanish governor in the 1820s to a sergeant. This sergeant's eldest son lived on the land, trading a rendered animal fat from his livestock. The commercial version of this substance can contain fats from a plant with bright yellow flowers whose name comes from a Latin word for a root vegetable.
