This plant belongs to an economically significant botanical family. What is the alternative name for this family, alluding to the cross-like arrangement of its four petals?

Start with the aerospace contractor that built a massive wooden aircraft, whose parent company later created a satellite service. This service utilizes dish-shaped technology, whose effectiveness in directing waves can be illustrated as a directional map. Visualizing such a map is an application of an imaging method that projects the first local intensity maximum. This technique is a subset of a broader field that creates 2D projections from 3D data, often acquired from high-resolution, cross-sectional scans. These scans can be used to study creatures without a backbone, a subject covered by a specific scientific journal. Before this journal split off its humanities section and was subsequently renamed, what was its original title?
answer: Annals of the Natal Government Museum

question: Starting with a 19th-century secessionist state with an agricultural economy, consider the sea fort where its forces initiated a major war. This fort is located in a harbor that later hosted the first-ever sinking of a warship by a submarine. The study of such submerged vessels is a field in which a German-born specialist is a pioneer. This expert's specific archaeological sub-discipline investigates underwater remains, which are often covered by material displaced by the natural process of surface removal. This surface removal is a significant adverse consequence of clearing large stands of trees. As of 2005, what is the minimum per capita GDP, in a specific currency, for countries where the rate of this clearing had stopped increasing?

Starting with the South American capital on a major estuary, consider its larger metropolitan formation, a type of urban sprawl home to one-third of the nation's people. This term for a continuously developed area was coined in a 1915 book. Now, find another example of this concept, a statistical area in Western Australia defined by its labor market. The designation for this Australian area includes a term for a municipality with primary status, which typically serves as the seat of government. Following this, identify an Asian national capital region composed of sixteen cities. Within this specific Asian metropolitan area, what is the primary role of the city that is home to the nation's largest stock exchange and the highest concentration of multinational corporations?

Beginning with a company founded for a traditional Japanese theatre style, whose name combines words for pine and bamboo, consider the man this company hired to head its acting school, who also founded a new theatrical movement. This movement was meant to expand the boundaries of the traditional art form, whose name can be interpreted as 'bizarre' theatre. In this art form, there is a distinct convention where an actor freezes in a powerful pose. This pose is famously associated with a play, whose title translates to "Stop a Moment!", which is part of a celebrated collection of eighteen works. This collection is tied to an acting lineage whose family crest is three nested squares. What was the name of the father of the very first performer to hold this lineage's most illustrious name?

Starting with an unused Parisian subway station intended for a sports stadium, which is an example of the city's many disused transport locations, many of which closed at the onset of a major global conflict. Consider another station on that network, which was renamed to honor a city's resistance during the first battle of that conflict. This engagement, which slowed an invading army, is an example of a tactical concept known by a French phrase for a swift, surprising attack. This type of maneuver is often executed by military units dropped from the air. Such units trained at facilities like a certain air force station near a major northern English city, which was part of a larger system of training establishments. Within this system, two specific units mentioned for training aircrews on patrol and strike aircraft belonged to what overarching command?

Begin with a North American turtle species with two subspecies. Follow the one whose common name reflects its shell pattern, a protected reptile in a certain central US region. Identify the census region situated immediately to the east of that area. From this eastern region, locate its northernmost state. A cluster of islands straddles this state's maritime border. The first documented landfall on these islands by an English explorer was made by a specific naval captain. This explorer was a member of a council for a broader colonial territory. What state within this final territory contains both the largest city and the second-largest city mentioned in its description?

Starting with the algebraic operation in Euclidean space that returns a single number from two coordinate vectors, consider a three-dimensional figure formed by six instances of its two-dimensional analogue. This 2D shape is a quadrilateral with two pairs of parallel sides. If this shape appears identical after a partial turn, it exhibits a certain property whose formal treatment involves orientation-preserving isometries. Focusing on the groups of these isometries that keep a central point fixed in 3D, consider one of the three types related to the symmetries of the Platonic solids. This specific group corresponds to a solid composed of four triangular surfaces, the simplest convex polyhedron. What is the general term for the shape that forms one of these boundary surfaces?

Starting with an archipelagic nation in Southeast Asia that shares a maritime border to its south with another country, consider an island group within that southern neighbor historically known for its spices. This group was administratively split, with its southern region becoming one province adjacent to its northern counterpart. Within this northern territory, identify a regency formed by separating from another group of islands, which is composed of several smaller administrative divisions. The term for these divisions is also used for third-level subdivisions in a particular eastern province. From a list of these subdivisions, find the city on that province's southern coast from which a specific airline launched a new route using a jet with two cabin classes. What was the passenger capacity of the premium cabin on that aircraft?

Starting with the technology that converts images of text into machine-readable data, consider the company that invented the flexible magnetic disk, a firm which also developed a dominant operating system for its mainframe computers in the 1970s. Now, consider a family of personal computers from that era whose hardware design was constrained by emission regulations. The previously mentioned magnetic disk was a primary storage medium for these machines. This medium is an example of a broader category of storage that uses rotating platters, a category that also includes devices utilizing lasers. What property allows these laser-based devices to interoperate with media designed for preceding legacy systems?

Starting with a 1945 film about a torpedo boat squadron, consider the real-life military branch one of its main actors joined during that global conflict. A command within this branch later oversaw post-war operations in a Middle Eastern gulf. This naval force utilized auxiliary survey vessels, which were vital for amphibious assaults such as the five-week battle to capture a strategic island. The opposing imperial army in that conflict had an infantry unit, formed in the late 1930s, that was deployed to a vast geographical region of a large Asian country. What is the name of this region's fertile heartland?

Beginning with a catalog of institutions combining medical services and education, we find an entry for a Brazilian state, leading to that state's eighth-largest municipality by area. In that same state, locate a different city, its 13th most populous, named for a Catholic saint. This city is home to a sports organization founded through the merger of a tennis and a football entity, an organization that once played in the third tier of the state's football league. A separate team in this league was established following a major disease outbreak, taking its name from the monastery where it played its initial games. This team's home venue, with a capacity over 13,000, is shared with another club that originated in basketball. On what date did this second club officially transition to football after merging with two others?

Starting with the field of engineering focused on the efficient movement of people and goods on roadways, consider a mathematical theory about its primary subject where key principles were refined in a specific year. Five years before that refinement, a physicist, known for a three-phase theory on the same subject, was born. His theory's name includes a term also used for transitions between states of matter. Regarding a state with properties between liquids and solids, the orientation of its molecules can be influenced by a vector field which is a manifestation of a fundamental force. This force is quantified by an inverse-square law published by a French physicist. What term did a contemporary English philosopher, who also wrote about this force, give to the gas he is famous for discovering?

Starting with the scientific analysis of language, find the branch that focuses on the physical properties of speech sounds. Within this field, use a quote concerning a set of reference vowels to identify an expert phonetician. In which European capital did this expert study under the uncle of the woman he would later marry? Next, consider this city's iconic wrought-iron landmark, built for a global exposition. This leads to a politician involved in that exposition, who had also served as a volunteer under an Italian unification leader and commanded troops during a siege of his native city. What was the end date, in the fifth month of the year, for the revolutionary government that arose following that siege?

A British royal, the youngest child of a long-reigning queen, was considered for marriage to her late sister's husband, a German Grand Duke. This duke was once second-in-line to the throne, a position for an heir whose claim can be displaced. This type of inheritance status was central to a geopolitical crisis in a small principality, where the potential successor was from an empire that, after a war, had annexed a territory. This territory was composed mainly of a historical region on a major river's west bank, which shares cultural ties with the nation known as "the land of poets and thinkers." A notable 20th-century philosopher from this nation's critical theory school was born in what capital?

Starting with a language considered a variant of another spoken on a notable peninsula, follow the path to its related tongue which has three dialects, one named for a color. This language belongs to a family associated with horse-riding pastoralists of the steppes. A state founded by these people, who first used the title "khagan," is thought to descend from an older confederation of nomads. This confederation included a tribe that participated in the "Uprising of the Five Barbarians" and whose leader was granted a hereditary title by the Jin Dynasty. What was this title?

A hip hop duo, whose female member later directed a documentary about their performance venue, was featured on a compilation album. This album shares its name with an open-mic workshop rooted in a health food center in the southern part of a major California city. In this area, a residential community known for its tree-lined streets, developed after WWI, was designed with input from a landscape architecture firm run by two brothers. One of these brothers, who was also the adopted son of their famous father, worked on projects in a New York city whose name comes from river cascades. This city is the administrative center for a county named after the third U.S. President. Within this county is a hamlet on a river bend, established in 1817. Who founded this hamlet?

Starting in the English city originally known as the "ford of the oxen," find the educational institution where an artist and craftsman taught sculpture. This craftsman's name was later given to the public university that evolved from that institution. This university is located in an eastern suburb of the city where Roman-era kilns have been found. A monarch who ruled over the land containing this suburb, the fourth son of a famous conqueror, fought a decisive battle in a French location. This former commune, the site of that 12th-century conflict, was later consolidated with six others. What is the name of the resulting new commune, which absorbed one of the other constituent former communes as part of this merger?

Start with the French Canadian explorer, the first European to reach a major American river, where he encountered a native tribe. This tribe lived along two tributaries of that river, one of which is named for a vital organ. This waterway and a color-named stream that joins it both have their source in a particular administrative region named for a railroad president. A southern subdivision of this region is classified as an area lacking a formal governmental structure. This classification was later applied to the vast remainder of a historical expanse after a portion of it gained statehood, prompting a name change for the expanse to avoid confusion with the new state. What was the original name of this expanse?

Starting with a Greek historian and rhetoric teacher who flourished during the reign of an early Roman emperor, consider an influential Attic orator who also specialized in this field. A specific polemical text by this orator sought to distinguish his school from those seen as deceitful, the opposite of a concept meaning "accord with reality." This concept's Greek equivalent, literally meaning "unconcealedness," was revived by a 20th-century philosopher who also described how things become meaningfully relevant. This latter phenomenon was also discussed by a Canadian philosopher whose work addresses a school of thought focused on the reflective critique of society. Who described this critique's goal as seeking to "liberate human beings from the circumstances that enslave them"?

An American honor society recognizes students in a profession concerned with optimizing complex systems. This profession can overlap with an interdisciplinary study focused on problem-solving, which uses analytical methods such as imitating a process's operation. One application of this imitation is in non-professional flight practice, a field where a particular company produced early electro-mechanical games. This company was later bought out by an executive who had dropped out of medical studies to sell jukeboxes. His company's first entry into home video game hardware was a console that launched on the same day as a famous competitor's system. In what year was the redesigned second version of this console released?

Beginning with the celebrated quarterback who holds records for the most career pass interceptions, identify a tight end drafted by his long-time team, who was notable for his collegiate one-handed receptions. From the athletic conference where this player was a two-time all-star, find the flagship public university in Storrs, which is acclaimed as the top public institution in its six-state region. Within this region, consider the state whose largest city is Manchester and find its capital. This capital contains the state's only institution for legal studies. To qualify as a lawyer in a specific country mentioned in the description of such institutions, a graduate must complete a compulsory period of practical training. What is this country?

Beginning with an Indian cantonment town named after an officer honored by a Mughal emperor, consider the official count of a population. This counting method was used by an ancient Italic civilization that grew to tens of millions before splitting. The eastern remnant of this empire, whose people still used the original demonym, lost a southern province in a major 7th-century invasion. The emperor at that time, whose father governed an African territory, had a predecessor who also fought the Sasanian empire and formally established that very African territory. This predecessor also campaigned in the Balkans against a people whose first supreme leader became khagan in what year?

A 12th-century romance about a Cornish knight and an Irish princess inspired a Victorian poet who wrote on taboo topics. This poet was an associate of a painter who founded an artistic brotherhood in 1848. The painter's mistress, a woman with "harvest yellow" hair who also served as his housekeeper, was the first model for one of his paintings. The artwork portrays the mythological first wife of the first man, a figure linked to female demons from ancient Mesopotamia. That region's mythology also features a "Queen of Heaven" who, in one epic, descended to the underworld. What is the title of the deity who opened the seven gates for her?

Starting with a Swiss tennis professional whose continuous top-ten ranking ended in the same year a major multi-sport event was first held on a South American continent, identify the host nation of the third-mentioned prior games held in a developing country. At this event, a Southeast Asian island nation won its first medal as an independent country, decades after a specific weightlifter won its first. Two years before this weightlifter broke a world record, a summer competition was held for the first time in Oceania. A Central European republic, formed from three Allied occupation zones, existed during this period. What was this republic's provisional capital?

Starting with a multi-year financial crisis in a European union that began near the close of the 21st century's first decade, consider the French economist born in the early 1970s who authored a famous book on wealth concentration. This book's themes are also discussed by an American Nobel laureate, who shares a writing profession with a prolific science-fiction author that used a pseudonym containing the first name "Paul". This author is the eponym for an officially designated Martian impact feature containing numerous gully-like formations. According to the description of a process that causes such formations to lengthen, what two-word feature is being extended?

Starting in a national park on the coast of a West African country, find a large grass species whose inflorescence bears many small floral units. The non-reproductive covering of the flowers within these units is analogous to a structure in a certain division of plants, known as hepatics, which encloses the female reproductive organ. This division belongs to an informal group of non-vascular plants whose life cycle is dominated by a haploid organism that develops from a single-celled reproductive unit. In certain organisms, what is the purpose of this unit releasing amoeba-like cells into a host?

Begin with the historian awarded a 1989 literary prize for his work on a major 19th-century American conflict. His biography identifies his birthplace, a city known for its many bridges, whose census data is a key component of a general term measuring population per unit area. Consider a specific application of this term used in urban planning, a field of study linked to sustainability. This principle informs an ecological concept about the largest harvest a resource can provide indefinitely. What term describes the opposite practice, which leads to resource destruction? This unsustainable harvesting ignores the environmental limit on how many organisms a habitat can support. What three-word phrase defines this maximum limit?

Start with the Korean leg-fighting expert nicknamed for his spinning attacks. He starred in an action film where the plot involves stolen gold, alongside a co-star who shares part of his name with an 18th-century Welsh diplomat. This diplomat was a contemporary of the final monarch of a commonwealth whose rule was undermined by an interfering empire. A military pact between three nations was later formed to counter that same empire, but it ultimately fell apart. The primary British proponent of this pact had a famous political arch-rival. This rival's father was granted a barony one year after his wife received her own title. In what year did their eldest son, who inherited these titles, pass away?

In a nation where free instruction is ensured by its foundational law, a specific document with over 400 articles details criminal penalties, such as those for homicide. This country's supreme governing text also establishes a self-governing body for citizen grievances, sometimes called the "People's Advocate." A former prime minister who now serves as this advocate once taught at a capital city university founded by a princely order in the mid-1800s. This university was created by transforming a predecessor academy. What is the name of the scholar who initiated instruction in the native tongue at this original academy?

Starting with a public Midwestern university founded in the 1860s and known for its public service, consider its baseball venue which has a capacity of 2,500 spectators. The team that uses this venue, whose most successful season was in the late 1980s, competes in a national championship that concludes with an eight-team final series. In the third-ever instance of this championship tournament, an award for the most outstanding individual was given for the first time. This tournament concluded a season where the victorious team, led by a coach in his seventh season, swept the final series. How many times has this individual award been presented to a player whose team did not win the championship?

An advisory body for one kingdom was absorbed into a political union formed by merging two realms. Within this union, a movement for self-governance led to an act that partitioned the island, creating a larger southern territory. This same act also established a 41-member all-island council, which never convened. A few years later, a commission was formed to delineate the border between the new jurisdictions, a process in which the northern government refused to nominate a member. What was the profession of the father of the man who was the first leader of this non-cooperating government?

Starting with ornamental items that historically functioned as a type of protective talisman, also called a good luck charm, consider a specific variant made from a shaped mineral artifact. The method for classifying these artifacts based on physical traits is one application of a broader cognitive process used for differentiation. A psychologist born in the fourth decade of the 20th century is known for studying this process and the resulting mental building blocks of thought. When these general notions are derived from specific examples, the outcome acts as what kind of term for all its subordinate ideas?

Starting in the central region of a constituent UK country, identify a unitary authority with an extensive coastline. This coast features a long-distance footpath, which is one section of an even larger coastal route around the whole country. From this section, find a different, adjacent National Trail that was established in 1970. A river, which rises in an area once called a "desert," forms a boundary between the counties of these two trails. On the banks of this river, in a third county it borders, is a small village. Within this third county, which was invaded by Normans, locate a castle that was the chief seat of a historic kingdom. What was this kingdom called?

Starting with the principal minister responsible for a specific region within a kingdom, consider a major industrial action against a power-sharing deal that occurred under this office's purview. This action was supported by those aligned with a political school of thought seeking that region's independence from both its parent kingdom and a neighboring republic. Adherents of this viewpoint sometimes adopted the ethos of a devoted nationalist figure, a concept linked to an ideology presenting itself as a "third way" between the dominant economic systems of a global conflict. One of those systems, defined by private ownership for profit, grants workers the right to organize for collective bargaining. When democratic principles are applied to the employment environment, what is one example of a form this can take?

Starting with the mathematical concept of a group transforming a space, consider an example of such a group composed of invertible matrices. Within this, a subgroup's representation theory involves a Lie algebra with a basis forming an sl-triple. This concept is fundamental to another group's representation theory, which is both compact and non-abelian, and where an important lemma regarding irreducible representations applies. This lemma generalizes to Lie algebras, which have a distinguished central element, named for a physicist, corresponding to polynomials where all terms share the same degree. When such a polynomial is restricted to terms of degree two, it defines a form that is central to what branch of mathematics associated with the Killing form?

Start with the Japanese electric utility that, after a seismic event, had to close its nuclear facility in a prefecture on the Sea of Japan coast. From that prefecture, which is part of a historic region, consider a form of Japanese graphic storytelling which includes a genre for a young male audience, exemplified by a magazine first published in the late 19th century. This publication for boys, created by the author of "Koganemaru", inspired a female-oriented counterpart after a war. Now consider a different author, not associated with that magazine, who was orphaned by age four and later penned a well-known short story in the 1920s. That story, whose title character's name is used for an express train service, was adapted into a two-part television drama in 1993. Who portrayed the original author in that broadcast?

Starting in the largest Spanish-speaking nation, consider a mid-century aerial attack on a plaza in its capital. The path then leads to an aircraft model, which was the first combat jet fighter for its country of origin. This plane's creation was guided by a set of official government briefs. Following these briefs, another medium bomber was created, nicknamed for its cramped interior resembling luggage. This type of bomber was operated by a military squadron that was re-formed for that purpose before a global conflict. This squadron later flew a successor four-engined heavy bomber, which originated from a troublesome twin-engined predecessor. What was the official specification code for which this predecessor was designed?

Beginning with a British journalist and horticulturist, identify the educational institution she attended. This institution's fifth public garden is situated in a suburb whose 18th-century expansion was fueled by a new waterway designed to transport coal. This waterway terminates in an urban conservation area, the site of a former Roman fort. From this area, a separate, broader canal travels across the Pennines, ending its journey in a market town. In the late 19th century, this town officially became an urban district within which historic administrative division of its county?

Start with a Canadian territory named for the bay on its western border. Nine communities affiliated with a particular aboriginal group reside on this bay, which is the southern part of a larger arctic sea. One of these communities, whose name translates to 'People of the parting of the rocks,' belongs to this large North American First Nation. Their language, a dialect continuum, descends from a proto-language spoken thousands of years ago. The technical term for a proto-language's homeland is of German origin. Considering a proposed super-family of languages spanning from Madagascar to Pacific Islands, what is the name of a related hypothesis put forth by an individual with the initials P.K.B.?

Starting with the physicist who co-founded a major scientific journal and studied in a specific German metropolis, consider the city's largest art school where a British composer, a former student of a Korean-born musician, later taught. This capital city is also one of its nation's constituent federal territories. Among this collection of territories, find the northernmost one, whose capital city's name is associated with a man-made channel connecting two major seas. This channel provides an alternative to a series of natural straits that also link the same two bodies of water. What is the name of the 19th-century accord that declared these natural straits to be international waterways?

Starting with the method of controlled distribution used by a European island nation heavily reliant on food imports during a major 20th-century conflict, consider the official documents used in that system. These documents are a tool for a broader concept of managing scarce resources, a practice also seen during a 1970s energy crisis. This concept was also implemented by a large Eurasian state, which created a unified system for commodities in the early 1930s. Now, consider a different kind of document, one used in marketing for a financial discount. This document is one of several short-term tactics within a strategy that is one element of a larger blend of promotional variables. What fundamental process defines another element of this blend, where a representative meets a prospective customer?

Starting with an intergovernmental body founded after a global war whose headquarters are exempt from local laws, consider this principle of exemption which can also apply to a foreign country's military bases. Within the government of that country, find the executive department that is the world's largest employer and oversees its military. A component of this department, responsible for aerial warfare, was established in the mid-20th century and is led by a civilian. This civilian oversees the modern air and space service, which has a direct statutory predecessor. In what year did this predecessor organization, which conducted the first military aviation operations on foreign soil, cease its activities?

Begin with the pilot who provided the power for the first human-propelled aircraft to cross the English Channel. Now, consider the Californian research laboratory that constructs robotic planetary spacecraft, and identify one of its founders who was also a pioneer in rocket propulsion. This founder co-established an engineering firm whose incorporation was handled by a lawyer known for being the first to practice space law. This legal expert coined a term for a field related to searching for non-human intelligence, a search which here shares a name with an early 1990s war that was a part of a wider ethno-political conflict over a former autonomous district. What is the capital of another disputed territory that is recognized by the exact same list of nations as this district?

Starting with a Parisian post-secondary school known for its competitive preparatory classes, find the administrative district on the river's left bank where it is situated. This district houses a fine arts institution, once an academy for painting and sculpture, that was suppressed during a major political revolution. A self-taught archaeologist worked to save monuments from the destruction of this same revolution. The legislative body formed in the early stages of this upheaval grew out of a prior assembly representing three social orders. What is the specific name of a modern ruling family, mentioned as an example in a list describing kinship groups associated with the second of those three orders?

Beginning with a British writer who studied transmissible ailments, consider a publication dedicated to the progression of these conditions. When this progression is triggered by microscopic life, it can lead to inflammation in the smallest airways of the lungs, especially in young children. A distinct high-pitched breathing sound is a primary symptom of this inflammation. To differentiate this ailment from others with similar presentations, practitioners use a specific distinguishing procedure. In what type of facility are the tests that support this diagnostic process typically conducted?

Starting with a prominent American landscape design company founded by two siblings near the end of the 19th century, consider the profession they practiced, whose earliest surviving treatise was penned by an ancient Roman engineer. This Roman's principles on proportion informed a particular architectural movement that began in the mid-1700s. An English practitioner of this style was the youngest of five sons, and his older, third-born brother was a noted portrait painter. Their father, a city surveyor, once competed with two others for the contract to design an official mayoral residence. One of these competitors, who trained in Rome but practiced mainly in England, is famous for what place of worship?

Beginning with a fictional magnate who is the primary antagonist of a famous superhero, consider that hero's main vulnerability: a crystalline material from his home world. An unpublished story from four decades into the 20th century, which featured a precursor to this material, was given its name by an author in a book published in 2004. This author also co-wrote a parody of a TV sitcom about an idealized suburban family. In that show, identify the actor who portrayed the husband of the family's matriarch. For the character this actor was most known for playing, what is the nickname of his youngest son?

The authority of the governmental body overseeing the military of a central European nation is rooted in that country's constitution. Within this populous EU member state, there exists an ethnic group of African descent. A pioneering philosopher from this group was, as a child, presented to a duke from the House of Welf. This duke's youngest daughter wed a man who would become a field marshal. During a conflict between the Hapsburgs and an empire to its east, what fortified stronghold did this officer eventually command?

In a Canadian territory where a specific family of indigenous languages is spoken, this linguistic group is thought to be related to another family from a Siberian river region. The people who spoke these tongues may have originated in an area later dominated by a nomadic confederation whose activities are documented in ancient sources. A monumental history chronicling this confederation was initiated by a court's Grand Astrologer and later completed by his son. This historian's work covers the formation of a particular dynasty. What was the birth name of that dynasty's founder, who was born into a peasant family?

Starting with a 13th-century statute that curtailed subinfeudation, a practice involving an "intermediate" lord, consider the type of property owner this lord represents. The relationship between such owners and tenants is governed by regulations controlling rent and eviction. A specific temporary property right under these regulations was required to be in writing by a 17th-century anti-fraud law. A key jurist who helped draft this law, born early in that same century, later joined one of the capital's four preeminent legal societies. In which modern London borough is this society located?

Starting with the man credited with reviving a language spoken in the Land of Israel, consider the large phylum this language belongs to, which also has an Egyptian branch. From this phylum's North African branch, identify a specific language spoken in southwestern Morocco, in which an 18th-century poet known as the "Master of Poetry" composed his works. This poet's tongue is part of a broader family of languages, within which is spoken a distinct language of a Libyan oasis town. A contemporary Dutch scholar, who authored a modern grammar based on this oasis language's materials, was born in what location?

Follow a spur of an Indian mountain range, whose name means "line of peaks," to a volcanic remnant made of a specific igneous rock. This rock, named for a royal color, was used to build a grand palace in the Byzantine capital. An emperor from this palace built a "New Church," later destroyed by lightning. In that city, another chapel within the palace grounds, named for a lighthouse, was the site of a future ruler's wedding. This ruler held a title of higher rank than a king, now officially translated for just one nation's monarch. A later German holder of this title, the only son of his predecessor, ruled during a year famous for its three successive sovereigns. What was the duration of his reign?

The creator of an animated series initially envisioned a setting that would require specialized garments for work outside a vehicle. This work is facilitated by a port that manages the physical quantity defined as a force over an area. A unit of this force, named after a Greek word for power, is defined by an acceleration over a specific time interval. This time interval is the base for measuring the rate of repeating events. Following this chain of concepts, identify the name for a sun-based unit of duration that is equivalent to five years.

Starting with the general term for small U.S. railroad companies, identify a specific terminal railroad founded in 1997 that operates several lines in a western state. One of its segments, a Class III line named for an eastern community, provides a link to the next higher financial classification of railroad. Within this higher class, find a railroad formed in 2014 by acquiring the western portion of a predecessor from a Canadian company. This predecessor line, which began its operations in 1986, was based in a particular U.S. state. On what date was this state admitted to the Union?

Starting with an island nation whose name derives from a day of the week, consider the three-region trade system mentioned in its context, which was shaped by predictable air movements as detailed in a text on historical sailing. An example of these phenomena is a nutrient-rich ocean stream in the South Atlantic, which supports a forage fish species found in the sea containing a large, volcanically active Italian island. The third-largest city on this island, located at a narrow strait, was conquered by a burgeoning republic, an event that triggered a 23-year-long conflict with a rival power. In which year did this naval war begin?

Starting with a journalist recognized for her extensive reporting on a detention camp at a U.S. naval base, consider the foundation supporting excellence in her profession. Now, identify the media conglomerate that established this foundation. The founder of this conglomerate started a newspaper chain with his sister, a notable philanthropist. This philanthropist commissioned a community recreational facility that she donated to the major Southern California city where it is located. This city's location near a national border brings to mind a mid-19th-century war between the two neighboring countries. According to the text, a general mentioned in the history of that war had a vice president who was trained in a different field before entering politics. What was that original profession?

Starting with the area of physics that deals with the properties of matter in "condensed" phases, find the spontaneous process where a system's symmetric state ends up in an asymmetric one. This is a specific instance of a broader phenomenon where small fluctuations at a critical point determine a system's fate, often leading it to a state of lowest possible energy. This state possesses a background energy, a concept explored in the quantum theory that describes how light and matter interact. This theory, in turn, is a type of field theory where the Lagrangian is invariant under certain transformations. The study of such invariances in the quantum world has applications in the standard model and what other branch of physics?

Start with a US record label established in the mid-1970s by a former executive of a major competitor. During this era, a pioneering American female rock singer and bass player became a major star. Her musical style is associated with a flamboyant rock subgenre from the early part of that decade, which in turn drew inspiration from a simpler, manufactured pop style aimed at a younger audience. The most successful song of that simpler style, performed by a fictional animated band, featured female vocals from a songwriter who also sang on another of the band's top-ten hits. This second song shares its title with the group's third studio album. What was this album's peak position on the top LPs chart?

Starting in a town on a New Zealand peninsula, home to an indigenous iwi, consider the broader Polynesian group who settled there after canoe voyages. From the history of their interactions with outsiders, think of the general term for a person sent to promote a faith, a word whose origin means 'act of sending'. This act often involves a process of adapting teachings to local ways, a method used by an Italian Jesuit missionary who arrived in western India in the early 17th century. This individual acted as a spiritual guide, a role described by a Sanskrit term for 'master'. A specific master of this kind authored a hymn which is the 404th section of a larger work. In what language was another heroic composition, found in the 5th chapter of that same work and attributed to the same author, written?

An Indian DTH provider is a subsidiary of a mass media company founded in the early 1990s. Now, consider a separate music broadcaster whose chairman left his management role two years after its founding. This former television executive was later arrested by the nation's premier investigating agency. This agency operates under the jurisdiction of a government ministry which is typically headed by the country's chief executive leader. This leader operates within a parliamentary system of government named after the location of its legislature. In which constituent country was this system of government developed?

Starting with the political principle where the people are the ultimate authority, find a historic document asserting a nation's sovereign status which was sent to a high-ranking religious figure. This letter was a response to aggression from a kingdom whose monarch, known as the "Hammer" of that nation, had earlier won a key battle ending a baronial rebellion. From the city where a later, decisive civil war battle was fought, identify the railway named for it, an educational center, and an industrial hub. This railway became the main partner in a merger creating a larger network, one of whose constituent lines was named for three places in the Welsh Marches. This line connected with another railway, serving one of its namesake towns, that was jointly leased by two major competing companies. In what year did the opening of a major underwater passage significantly increase the importance of this jointly-operated line?

Begin at an Indian city, one of seven holy sites in a specific faith and a deity's traditional birthplace. This faith, sometimes called the 'eternal tradition,' has a term for its adherents. A phrase akin to this tradition's name appears in a major historical text that champions devotion. This devotional concept inspired a movement that emerged in southern India during the 8th century. A prominent philosopher, influential in this movement, followed the example of an earlier theologian. What was the given birth name of this predecessor, the first preceptor of his lineage?

In a model village built for miners in a historic English county, identify the major transport company formed by a mid-19th century merger. Follow it to its primary southern terminal in the capital, then find the nearby underground station that was part of the world's first subterranean railway. A plan to connect a new line to this station was authorized a year after its opening but was later abandoned, partially due to a major financial downturn that began two years after the plan's authorization. This downturn put pressure on the class of industrial laborers, leading to the formation of representative bodies. What term describes the regular fees used to fund these bodies?

Start with a mid-17th-century battle that broke a siege on a fortress. This fortress, whose grounds now house a zoo, was later inherited by a baron who rebelled against a king. The person holding the fortress at the time of a major land survey decades earlier was a Norman landowner who likely died during a religious crusade. This late 11th-century survey documented holdings in every shire, including an eastern county famed for its technology hub. A list of settlements in this county, based on an early 21st-century census, classifies populated zones using a particular term. A national statistics office used this same term for the entire country. What is the title of the guidance document that explains the methodology for this classification?

Start with the wargame company, now owned by a subsidiary of a major toy corporation, and consider a fantasy role-playing game it published. This game's world was first introduced in a board game released three years earlier, which depicted a conflict between a lunar-themed empire and a barbarian nation. The creator of that board game, who also established his own publishing house, co-designed the subsequent role-playing game with an individual who was a founding member of a creative historical society. Their game's rules were later refined into a basic system by the world's creator and another designer. This second designer, who created a sci-fi wargame titled after a divine fire, also worked for a publisher known as a "workshop," which released a game about a rebellion near a specific tree. Among this workshop's four founders, what is the name of the person whose surname is an occupation that processes grain?

Starting with a fictional crystalline substance known for being a specific hero's greatest weakness, follow the path to an animated series about this hero which reflected a major character relaunch. This relaunch was a six-part comic series detailing the hero's revised origins, including his time as a teenager, when he was known by a different name. The individual credited with creating this teenage persona also developed a tough private eye character. This detective debuted in the very first installment of what would become one of his publisher's signature series. How many issues were published in this series' original run before it was first concluded?

Starting with the ritual tassels worn by an ancient Levantine people, find the ancient biblical translation from the same land that was misattributed to an individual due to a printer's error. Within this traditional region, locate a landlocked territory whose control changed after two mid-20th-century conflicts. From a list of satellite television providers for that part of the world, identify a specific mobile operator in a Southeastern European nation that was rebranded in 2002 from a name meaning "dialogue." The official language of this country belongs to the same family as a global language that originated on a certain western peninsula. In which prominent city of a historical kingdom did this global language first see systematic written use in the 13th century?

Begin with a squadron that trains aviators for a Southeast Asian island republic and received two distinguished citations during mid-20th century conflicts. This squadron falls under the same major command as a numbered air force tasked with conventional combat. Now find an operational wing within that command which flies airborne early warning aircraft and is stationed at the same facility where an air division, once responsible for defending several western US states, had its final assignment. That division reported to a major command focused on tactical air power, which was later absorbed. Identify a provisional wing, a modern tactical counterpart, which was to be staged in a transcontinental nation for a 2003 conflict, but was denied access. What is the English translation of the name for a mountainous historical region in that nation's southeast, a name derived from the Syriac language?

A 20th-century Hungarian composer, who pioneered comparative musicology, wrote a set of pedagogical violin duets based on his earlier keyboard pieces inspired by regional folk tunes. Decades later, a DJ from another nation produced a song for a continental competition. This entry achieved a top-five placement in the contest's final, hosted in a major athletic hall completed in 1995. This venue, honorarily named for a famous basketball player, is cataloged on a list of similar large-capacity structures. On what continent are all the venues on this list located?

A Spanish athlete won the inaugural event of a continental professional tour, an organization which later launched a senior division for players over fifty and became independent in the mid-1980s. A southern European national competition, founded in 1925, has been part of this tour since its inception and was won four times by a French professional. This same Frenchman also claimed four victories in another nation's open, a tournament that was also on the tour until 1999. Decades earlier, a North American sports league played its first-ever exhibition games in Europe, visiting both England and the home country of this French athlete. In that nation's capital, which contains the 24th busiest rail station globally, what is the name of the international air-transport hub that is not the continent's second busiest?

Starting with a TV mystery series that counted a famous actress and a notable songwriter among its fans, consider an actor from this program known for his high-pitched voice. This actor voiced a timid animal character in a franchise centered on a honey-loving bear, and a film focusing on this character was animated by a studio in Japan. Such a film's critical reception would be tracked on a website whose name derives from an old theatrical practice of throwing produce. This site is vulnerable to a phenomenon of mass negative feedback, a problem for the general category of systems that collect and average reviews. Focusing on a specific one of these systems created in 1999 that uses a traffic light color scheme, what is the full name of its first listed founder?

Beginning with the liturgical book containing texts for a major Catholic ceremony, consider the variants of this service used before a mid-16th century council made that book mandatory. Within these older rites is the most ancient consecration prayer, which follows a hymn known as the "Hymn of Victory." This hymn was part of a distinct liturgical tradition from the Visigothic era on the Iberian Peninsula. In this region, a pair of "upper" and "lower" monasteries were founded, the older of which is famed as the site where the first written examples of a major Romance language appeared as marginalia on a Latin codex. These notes are named for the saint to whom the monasteries are dedicated. What location does this saint's biography identify as the birthplace of this former shepherd?

In a nation that transitioned from a monarchy to a republic following a referendum, the incumbent holder of the top governmental post won the first election for the new, more powerful presidential role. A later occupant of this new role won an election whose results were announced two days after polls closed by the official electoral body. This body's independence is guaranteed by a 1992 constitution, and it oversees contests between political organizations regulated by an act from the year 2000. One of these major organizations, founded just before the 1992 contests, lost the presidency in the year 2000. Given that elections for the head of state and legislature have been held together every four years since that 1992 contest, what is the usual date for this nationwide vote?

During a series of major European conflicts in the early 19th century, a foreign policy of economic blockade was established. A subsequent decree, intended to enforce this blockade, authorized the capture of neutral vessels that submitted to searches by the primary naval adversary. This naval force belonged to the power that would eventually acquire a vast North American colony from its rival. This colony contained a region whose colonial name, translating to "Land of the [plural native group]", referred to an indigenous confederation. What is the term for a speaker of the language in which that region's colonial name was given?

Starting with an overview of the era following antiquity, we learn of the administrative regions of an ancient capital. One of these regions, named for its geographical features, once contained the city's primary public forum. A modern thoroughfare now runs over sections of this and other forums, including one constructed by the same ruler who first established the city's regions. This specific forum featured a temple dedicated to the deity of warfare. A leafy garland symbolizing this deity's domain was also awarded to victors in poetic contests, a tradition which later inspired an official national literary title. Considering the American who held such a post from 2004 to 2006 and who worked at an insurance company, what is the name of one of his son's daughters?

Beginning with a Norman castle notable for its unusual dual-motte structure, find the ancient waterway it overlooks, which was refurbished under a monarch in 1121. This king, a fourth son of a famous conqueror, founded an abbey in that same year for his soul's salvation. This abbey, now in ruins, was affected by a widespread 16th-century legal process that disbanded such religious houses. Consider a different priory that survived this process to become a parish church, and identify the spa town where it is a dominant feature. This town's prominence grew due to its natural mineral springs, popularizing a therapeutic treatment using water. What is a former name for this treatment?

Starting with the innovator who made the first planned free-fall parachute jump, consider the life-saving device he developed. This device is activated by a handle and cable system, which terminates in a specific kind of fastener. The name for this fastener is also a term for an item given to recognize an achievement. A more complex version of this fastener, featuring a spring and clasp, is known by a name related to large bed coverings when it is of a certain size. This secure design principle was utilized in ancient brooches. A much shorter pin, meant to be pushed by hand to attach items to a board, is considered a type of what general object used in construction? Among the many specialized varieties of this object, what is the most common type called?

Starting with an American actor known as a cultural icon of masculinity, identify his collaborator on a film series about an antihero cop. This Argentine-American composer was born in a South American capital, a metropolis also serving as the birthplace for another major 20th-century classical composer. The latter's work is performed at a summer music venue in the Berkshire Hills, which frequently hosts that region's popular orchestra. The current conductor of this pop orchestra also serves as the artistic director for an international summer institute. In which U.S. state is this institute located?

Starting with a game designer who created a notable role-playing game for a publisher established in the mid-1970s, consider a later company, co-founded by an American expatriate, that was formed to reprint supplements for that game. This co-founder also worked on a prominent fan-made periodical, a type of non-professional work created by enthusiasts. This form of creation falls under a broader publishing method where the author retains full control of the process. This method can be used to produce digital book publications. According to the final description, what is a dedicated device for reading this digital format?

Starting with a governmental body that manages a specific administrative sector, find the collective of its high-ranking officials. What is an equivalent term for this body that acts as a supreme executive organ? From a list of such organs, identify the one in a "Democratic Republic" where, under a particular leader, a significant majority of its members belonged to his political group. Name that leader's ideological rival faction. What is the term for the executive committee used by such parties, a body that also existed in that nation? Finally, in the writings of the theorist who developed this type of party's vanguard role, what is the English meaning of the faction described as being "of the majority"?

Beginning with the ecclesiastical district whose name originates from a Roman administrative term, consider the largest branch of its global church, also called the "Western" one. An early author from a North African province, known as the "father of its theology," practiced the defense of his faith. A modern mathematician who engages in the same practice was raised in a city that is his country's ecclesiastical capital and is near a famed pagan royal center. In this ancient land, what dynasty used a mythical title of sacred authority to signify overlordship over their kin?

Starting with the visual representation of speech sounds, which is distinct from a language's standard written conventions, consider one such writing system used for a specific language and its related dialects that is a stylized version of an older script. This script is an example of a writing family where symbols typically represent consonants, and whose family name derives from the initial four letters of an ancient alphabet. An impure version of this system, which has 28 letters, is the basis for a modern character encoding standard. Within this standard, one block used for compatibility encodes spacing forms of diacritics, while a different block, also for compatibility, encodes ligatures for certain Asian languages. In version 12.0 of the standard, what is the character count of this latter block, which is the last of four listed for the script?

Begin with an ethnic group of Northern European origin known for forming communities in the American Midwest. One such community, a village that is now a historic site, is recognized on the federal government's official inventory of preserved properties. This inventory, established by an act in the mid-1960s, automatically includes all places with a more exclusive designation of outstanding national importance. These more significant sites are cataloged by state. Considering the list for a major metropolis in the state with the most such sites, identify a monument on an island where a military branch established its largest base in 1966. In what year did that branch announce it would close the facility?

From a list of a country's schools, find a town, the center of a namesake administrative division, which once held an internment camp. This division type was part of a former system; in the district named for a lake, find the headquarters of its northern section where a future president studied. This headquarters lies in a county bordering a tea-famous region to the south. The capital of the tea region is the homeland of a Nilotic ethnic community. What modern country is the origin place for the larger group to which this community belongs?

Starting with a Canadian music awards ceremony, find the specific prize for international albums that was won by a vocal group formed in Florida in the early 90s. A singer from this group, who is of German and Puerto Rican ancestry, once competed on a children's athletic television show. The host of that program went on to portray an oafish character in a sitcom that began in the year 2000. An actor who guest-starred as that character's father, and who was the younger brother of another famous performer, had a long-running supporting role on a different show. What was that supporting character's full name?

Starting with the Central European great power formed in the early 19th century as a response to a neighboring nation's empire, identify a generic name for a series of large indoor performance venues found within that nation. This leads to one of the country's major cities, known by a colorful nickname. The urban transit system in this city shares its general designation with the first network to utilize a specific rubber-tired, automatic people mover technology. This technology's second implementation was for an airport shuttle, which connects to a specific lettered line of a major capital's regional express network. An old railway, now integrated into this lettered line, was named for a southern suburb it served. Who was the chief engineer responsible for building this old railway?

Starting with a glossary for a trick-taking card game, consider a specific bid made to explore a higher-scoring outcome. This leads to the concept of an optimal agreement, a term discussed alongside another that shares its name with a standard of performance in a different sport. In that sport, the shared term represents an expected score for a skilled competitor. The main professional tour for this sport also manages a developmental circuit for aspiring players. During the 21st season of this feeder tour, operating under a former name, a certain number of top money earners gained promotion. According to the list of these individuals, what is the total number of players who graduated that year?

An American opera company known for a seasonal cycle of an Italian composer's works also presents "Masterworks Revivals." Consider a composer known as the "father" of his country's national opera, who wrote many art songs using a verse-repeating form whose name derives from a Greek word for 'turn'. This structure is used in a famous song cycle for a solo singer, whose composer was published by an Austrian editor. This editor also composed a waltz used as the basis for a famous set of variations written for the stringed keyboard instrument invented in Italy circa 1700. On the grand version of this instrument, a guide is screwed into its plate to define the speaking length of the strings. This part is typically made from what material?

Starting with biopolyols derived from a certain plant-based liquid, which itself is a mixture of triglycerides, consider the property that measures this liquid's 'thickness'. This property is relevant in the mathematical descriptions of a physical system's movement over time. In a specific reformulation of classical mechanics, a mathematical function contains a system's dynamics. This type of function, which maps from a space to its field of scalars, is also known as a one-form. The collection of all such one-forms for a given vector structure constitutes a corresponding space. To distinguish this from a related concept for topological structures, what two-word name is used?

Starting with the oldest US-based team in a league of six original franchises, consider a legendary defenceman who played for them and is the only player in his position to win the scoring title. A Hall of Fame teammate of his, who also played for that team, later co-founded a Florida-based club after his 18-season career in the premier North American league. This league's champion participated in a final series where the victor was the last non-league team to win the trophy. The victorious team's league had, the year before, merged with another professional league founded by a family of athletes. This resulting prairie-based league disbanded shortly after, solidifying a certain trophy donated by a Governor General as the de facto prize. In what year was this trophy commissioned?

Starting with a type of joint created by angling two pieces to form a corner, consider a variation used in a particular construction trade. This trade, which builds with individual units, employs a binding paste whose name originates from the Latin for 'crushed'. This paste is suitable for air-dried blocks made from mud and organic material. The Spanish term for these blocks also refers to an earthen building material. A paste is used to repair structures built this way and to perform a specific renewal process. What is another term for this process of restoring the external part of the joints?

Begin with a 19th-century German artist known for allegorical landscapes. A Russian peer in this artistic genre attended an academy in St. Petersburg, an institution whose founder also established a university in a different city. This university was created by the decree of a female Russian monarch. The city where her university is located now contains a modern, non-state college focused on preparing professional mathematicians, an institution which hosts a semester-long program for international undergraduate students. What was the founding year of the organization that hosts this program?

Starting with a country's commemorative currency honoring a massive transport plane, find a city named for a 12th-century general, located in an oblast whose capital was renamed for a writer in the early 1960s. In a different nation, a bombing at a minority faith's church killed ten people. The suspected Islamist group, founded in the late 1990s and banned in the mid-2000s, sought to establish a state governed by religious law, a concept promoted by an Egyptian ideologue. An example of such a state existed from the mid-1990s until it was overthrown in late 2001. Its establishment followed a multi-year battle for a capital, where foreign powers armed proxies. Of these mentioned powers, which does not border the country where the battle occurred?

Starting in the capital of a region with a majority Albanian-speaking populace, find a nearby town established as part of a 20th-century state program. This program was described as a sequel to a conflict where four allied kingdoms defeated a transcontinental empire. Within this empire, religious jurisconsults were organized into a hierarchy led by a chief official who issued nonbinding legal opinions. In a particular branch of this religion, what is the title given to the highest-level authority, a "source to imitate," who can make legal decisions for their followers?

Start with a stock exchange founded thirteen years after the commencement of the reign of an English queen, who was the last monarch of her house. This ruler gave a famous oration to her land forces in the same year a historian's final book of a trilogy begins its historical scope. According to a text about diet in that historical period, a specific anadromous fish was considered a luxury food for the wealthy. The process of managing the commercial exploitation of such creatures aims to ensure their continued productivity. If this management fails, what two-word term describes the resulting exhaustion of the natural supply?

Starting with an ancient war between two Mediterranean powers known for its high mortality, which would be found on a list of conflicts catalogued by their death tolls, find a term for mass killing whose name originates from an older form of a certain European language. A dialect of this historical language shares its name with the president of a children's association in a specific Riviera microstate. The diplomatic history between this small nation and a large North American republic mentions the first consular agent sent by the latter—a role related to the high-ranking envoy described in the final document. What was this agent’s name?

Among peoples who crafted facial coverings from materials like driftwood, their mythology included the concept of a "wandering soul." This is found in philosophies like one whose name, meaning 'the way', has multiple English spellings due to transcription differences. The written form of the language for this philosophy has been adapted into the Latin alphabet through various systems, one of which was modified by a British sinologist. This scholar was a professor at an academic institution that had a specific kind of parliamentary seat, for which a special election was held after the incumbent passed away. What constituent country was the first to establish this type of electoral district, which represents members of an educational institution rather than a geographic area?

Starting with the ancient "half-Magadhi" language used by a spiritual leader who attained supreme wisdom after years of austerity, consider the specific ascetics whose knowledge is considered 'indirect' compared to this leader's. A text that categorizes these teachers is the oldest commentary on a foundational scripture whose name means "nature of reality". This foundational scripture details the causes of spiritual bondage, a state that immediately follows the influx of fine matter into a soul. This influx is one of a set of fundamental principles that explain the human predicament. What is the total number of these principles?

Beginning with a pioneering US state conservation program established in 1951, move to a similar initiative in a neighboring state that also protects geological features. The ecological regions within this second state are part of a continental classification system compiled by a global organization that also identifies a priority list for preservation. Each region on their list is categorized into a major habitat type, a term for a biological community adapted to a shared climate. The term for the general appearance of the vegetation in such a community is derived from two Greek words, one meaning 'interpreter.' What is the English translation of the other Greek root word?

Starting with the judicial body of eight officials nominated by the head of the executive branch, consider the sequence of replacement should that leader be unable to serve. Identify the office that ranks first in this sequence, and then find the person who uniquely held both this role and the top office without being elected to either. Next, referencing a catalog of the prior occupations for all who held the top office, and then a more specific list categorizing them by other key government posts like serving in the legislature, identify the leader who was the first to be elected to the highest office while a sitting member of Congress. What was this individual's numerical order in the sequence of chief executives?

Start with an English comedian whose career spanned the years of a major global conflict. That war is the topic of a French documentary series. A director from that same country, whose father fled a mid-century revolution and whose mother was a film editor, shares a parental profession with a prolific editor at a major studio who cut a western starring a rock and roll idol. An earlier western film from the mid-1930s tells of a hero defending homesteaders. An actor famous for playing villains starred as the character Matt Hartigan in a silent film of that genre. What was the Canadian birth province of another prolific actor of that silent film era who appeared in 127 films and died in the same year the homesteaders' film was released?

Starting with a collectible card game that debuted in Japan in 1996, consider a peripheral released in North America in 2002 that could scan its cards. This peripheral connected to a game series that added 135 new creatures and ran on a 32-bit handheld console. That console's successor, featuring a similar clamshell design, introduced local wireless interaction between devices, a function of networks that use radio communication. This type of communication utilizes a portion of the electromagnetic spectrum which is broken into bands, one of which is named for being 'above' another due to an atmospheric resonance peak. What is the frequency range of this specific band?

Starting with a collection of medieval legal annotations that were foundational to an ancient European legal system, identify the officials this system governed. These individuals held a specific form of authority allowing them to sit on a symbolic seat of power. This chair's design, sometimes featuring an X-shaped frame, has an English variant named for a religious institution. This institution's final leader, for whom a chair was supposedly made, was executed during its dissolution. In what year did this execution occur?

Starting with an R&B saxophonist who recorded a pioneering rock-and-roll song with a band recommended by a future "King of the Blues," follow the path to a Chicago record label specializing in that genre. Next, consider a guitarist from the same city who worked with that "King." This blues legend is then associated with a Mississippi city once named for a local bayou. From there, the path leads to another of the "three Kings of the Blues," known for a popular album whose title suggests an unfortunate astrological event. That album's sessions at a Memphis studio were co-managed by a drummer from an in-house band. What moniker, celebrating his precise rhythm, was given to this musician who began playing in his father's band at age five?

Begin in the American census area once designated the North Central Region, and cross into the Canadian province to its north that shares a border with it. From this province's most populous city, established as a temperance colony, proceed to the historic site that functioned as the de facto capital for a provisional government during a rebellion in 1885. The defeated leader of this uprising, now a folk hero to many French-speakers, is connected to a nationalist ideology once named for a specific ethnic group. This group's ancestors were colonists from a European country who settled a vast territory in North America. In what year was this territory formally transferred to other powers by treaty?

A scientific search for intelligent life elsewhere, which began after the advent of radio, led to a "piggy-back" program that analyzes data from large dish antennas. These instruments, often situated far from cities to avoid interference, are managed by organizations like a national observatory funded by a particular US government agency. This agency, a major source of federal backing for non-medical academic research, supports the systematic enterprise of building knowledge, a practice that evolved from "natural philosophy." This older field of inquiry is part of an individual's fundamental cognitive orientation. What is the name of the weekly lecture series directed by a professor who is an expert on a specific form of this orientation?

Starting with a studio album by a Georgia-based band, whose title is taken from a lyric in its fourth track, identify the record label that first released it. A man who managed a famous soul singer until the artist's death co-founded this label with his younger sibling. This sibling's publishing company released a well-known song about watching the tide roll away, co-written by the aforementioned singer and a guitarist known by a military-inspired nickname. This guitarist is an inductee of a Cleveland-based institution honoring influential artists. What is the given first name of another pioneer pianist honored by this institution, who sold over 65 million records?

Starting with the first literary language for a Slavic people, standardized by two missionaries from a historical eastern empire, consider the brothers who created a new script for it. Their pupils' work flourished in a city on a lake, once dubbed a "Balkan Jerusalem." This city was the seat of an autonomous church formed after a conquest demoted its predecessor. An 11th-century leader of this institution, a bible commentator and former royal tutor, is among the foundational Christian writers whose era largely concluded by the 8th century. Their works span many languages, including one whose literature thrived between the 4th and 8th centuries and produced a distinct Bible translation. For this standard scriptural version, what was the nationality of the modern scholar who prepared the texts for five previously excluded books for a 1905 publication?

Starting with the artistic movement born in a New York City borough, consider a female pioneer of its rhythmic vocal style who later appeared on television. The network that broadcast one of her appearances eventually shifted from music videos to a block of celebrity-focused programming. One show in this block featured two musical brothers who were contestants on another dating show, which itself was a spin-off of a series starring a member of a famous rap group. The second season of this original series aired in the mid-2000s. All of these programs belong to a TV genre that documents unscripted situations. In competition-based shows of this genre, what is the typical process for removing participants?

Starting with a river that freezes in the first half of October, identify the larger river it joins as its most significant tributary. An explorer in 1639 ascended this second river and crossed to a third. This third river was part of a water route leading to a major port city which is the capital of a republic. This republic is named for a Turkic ethnic group whose ancestors migrated from the area around the world's deepest lake. This great lake is the primary habitat for an endangered subspecies of fish. What is the full name of the biologist honored by the scientific name of the more widespread species to which this subspecies belongs?

Consider a person living abroad. Their children might attend an institution that adopts a curriculum from an educational foundation based in a Swiss city. In that same city, a school established to serve an intergovernmental organization helped create this foundation. This school's name is often given in a Romance language that was influenced by a Germanic tongue of post-Roman invaders. This ancient tongue later evolved into dialects spoken in the Low Countries. One group of these varieties, spoken in two neighboring provinces with the same name, has a subdivision spoken near a border. This subdivision is part of what more recently named linguistic group?

Start in the national capital of a Southeast Asian nation which is home to its monarch's official residence. From there, consider an Indo-Islamic architectural style known for its large bulbous domes and slender minarets. A city known for this style, which was once named Khadki, was captured by the empire associated with the architecture. The historical dominions this city belonged to exemplify a type of semi-sovereign principality under indirect colonial rule. These principalities were later integrated into a nation whose new central government was established by a supreme legal document, the longest of its kind. A man who presided as speaker over the special assembly that created this document later became the first to hold the same role in the nation's permanent lower house of parliament. This special assembly was first conceived as an idea by an advocate of radical democracy. What is his name?

Starting with a list of an island nation's railways, find a line that was a freight branch of a major artery before its 2004 passenger conversion, connecting to a station with twin towers over 50 stories high.
