A different line, also part of the same railway group as the major artery, operates a limited express service named for a famous peak, which then travels on the network of a company known for its "Romancecar" trains. This company's group includes the nation's first mountain railway, from whose terminus a cable car accesses a scenic crater lake. In what year did the volcano that created this lake last erupt?

Start in the West Asian country also known as Persia, where the developer of one of the world's largest shopping malls considered attracting a future American president to invest. This leader attended a business school within an Ivy League university founded prior to the Declaration of Independence. From there, consider a different public university, home to a student activity center for tandem races, which was named one of the best in its region by a particular college admissions company. This company, not associated with the university of a similar name, was later involved with a private equity firm that finances companies with enterprise values up to $1.5 billion. In what year did this firm add a credit strategy?

A secular armed coalition is described as the military wing of a political party associated with a particular leader. This leader, who chaired a multi-party organization for over three decades until his death, held a title representing the head of the organization's executive body, its highest authority. The largest political party within this organization maintained several militant groups, including one founded in the mid-1990s whose acknowledged head is a figure imprisoned for life. This figure was a leader in two major popular uprisings. What month and year did the second of these uprisings, a period of intense conflict, commence?

Starting with a 6th-century abbot known for his wisdom, consider a church associated with him that was built over the headquarters of a Roman legion. The church's oldest parts date to after an ethnic group, formed from Norse and Frankish contact, conquered the local kingdom. This group's leader swore allegiance to a king from a famous Frankish noble family that had replaced the previous ruling house. The first monarch from this new dynasty suppressed rebellions by several groups, including a confederation of Germanic tribes. In a 3rd-century battle, this confederation was defeated when an imperial army trapped them against a river. What is the final year of existence for this imperial army's medieval continuation, as stated in the text?

Starting with a university that began as a school for girls in its namesake town, consider the historical region where this town is located, a place where Western Europeans later established feudal states. One of these southern kingdoms was eventually ruled by a nobleman from Champagne, who was later besieged as the leader of another empire. The co-leader of this unsuccessful military blockade, whose father was a prominent general, ruled a rump state founded by fleeing aristocrats. What is the modern name of the capital city of this rump state, to which a new emperor fled when his own city became indefensible?

Begin with the science of placing events in their proper sequence, and link it to the academic study of the written past. Focus on the history of a continent where a major pre-Columbian civilization existed, about whom an anthropologist theorized a specific dietary custom was due to a lack of protein. Now, consider another anthropologist, the founder of a contemporary spiritual practice that draws inspiration from indigenous cultures. This act of borrowing is an example of a controversial form of cultural adoption, often impacting native peoples like a specific Aboriginal group from a southern landmass. What is this group's alternative name?

Starting with a Greek historian whose son was a youthful boxing champion at a famous quadrennial athletic competition, consider the designer of the main temple at that event's location. A small, diverted river which runs through this sanctuary empties into the longest river on that peninsula. Near a village whose name alludes to a trio of watercourses, this major river receives tributaries, and their confluence forms the boundary of a modern regional unit. What is the capital of this unit?

Starting with a legal system of hereditary titles, consider two national branches of it that were combined after a 1707 union. Identify the 20th-century act that allowed all peers from one of these branches to sit in the upper legislative chamber, an act largely motivated by a politician who inherited a title, disqualifying him from his seat in the lower chamber. This disqualification led to a special election in his constituency. The title he inherited was originally created for his father, and passed to him only because his older brother died in a major global conflict. What is the formation year of the professional life sciences association for which the politician's son, the current title holder, works as Director of Parliamentary Affairs?

Starting with the geological process of sediment transport parallel to a shoreline, consider the field that defends against this phenomenon. Within this field, think of a structure built to provide safe harbourage from that process. The engineering discipline that designs such structures works near the planet's largest bodies of water. A recessed coastal body connecting to one of these is exemplified in its description as an arm of a much larger saltwater body in northeastern Canada. On the eastern shore of this large body, a northern village was established by an Indigenous group who relocated from a community 160 km to the south to avoid a hydro-electric project. In what year was this new village founded?

An Indian media institute, launched by a key female political figure in the mid-1960s, granted a diploma to a journalist who later worked for a news channel. This channel, once part of a bilingual service operated by a major Indian media conglomerate, was eventually rebranded. The conglomerate belonged to an empire founded by an Australian-born tycoon, a contemporary of the long-serving British Prime Minister known by a metallic moniker. This premier led her country through a 10-week undeclared war over South Atlantic islands. Of the five assembly members representing the capital of these islands, what is the full name of the one whose surname also describes a person who boasts?

Starting in a Northern Italian autonomous region that was part of a larger monarchy until 1919, consider the rifle regiments, whose German name means "huntsmen," recruited from a historic county within it. This county was an estate of a vast, multi-ethnic European empire that contained an ecclesiastical principality granted a special status in 1027. An emperor of this empire, which was dissolved in the early 19th century, famously conflicted with a reforming pontiff over church appointments. During this dispute, the emperor faced an ultimatum at an assembly held in a location that is now a community in Germany. What is the administrative district that contains both this community and a neighboring "double city" located where one major river flows into another?

A non-theistic philosophy diverged from a theological one that emphasizes individual faith, an idea which contrasts with a belief in a divine master plan for nations. These nations, as complex societies, utilize political systems where leaders are often chosen by a decision rule requiring more than half the votes. This rule is explicitly distinguished from another method and is a less strict version of a criterion involving a preferred subset of candidates. This subset criterion, in turn, generalizes a fundamental principle for a single winner with over 50% of first-preference votes. What is that other, distinguished method, which is also listed as compliant with this fundamental principle?

Starting with the 19th season of a nation's highest football league, identify the team that retained their championship. This club also defended their title in an annual knockout tournament that same season. Looking at the general history of this tournament, a runner-up from the Soviet era came from a city whose name ends in '-pol'. Now, shift focus to a club named after an alternate name for a different city in the same region. This city forms a municipality with a suburb, where a census identified a South Slavic ethnic group as approximately 5% of its inhabitants. What is the Proto-Turkic word, meaning 'to mix', from which this group's ethnonym is possibly derived?

Starting with the world's largest airline by fleet size, find its largest hub, which is the fourth busiest airport globally by aircraft movements. A subsidiary of the first airline's parent group, which operates regional services under a bird-of-prey brand, is headquartered in the same metroplex and flies to a nation that is the most populous Spanish-speaking country in the world. A 16th-century conquistador's expedition brought large portions of this nation under European rule, leading to the downfall of a native empire. The capital city built on that empire's ruins, now the largest metropolis in the Western Hemisphere, is served by Latin America's busiest airport. A competing major airline, a founder of the world's largest airline alliance, is headquartered in what city?

An evolutionary model explaining sex ratios was detailed in a 1930 book. Consider a later biologist from the same field, a Harvard PhD who theorized on parent-offspring conflict and later worked at a public Californian university overlooking an ocean bay. This institution offers a broad education, a model also championed by a bilingual university in Japan that partners with the Californian system. An American accrediting body for this educational style, co-founded by a former US education secretary, shares its focus with the subject of a Renaissance painting. This artwork was commissioned by a Florentine banker who was uncle to a famous ruler. What year did this banker pass away?

Beginning at the ancient Athenian civic building located in the corner nicknamed for its many sculptures, consider the type of art piece that gives the area its name. A fusion of two deities into one such sculpture represents half-siblings, one embodying 'day-time' strategy and the other 'night-time' stealth. The son of the latter deity, who also bore a name derived from his great-grandfather, comes from a mythological period chronicled by a Sicilian historian in his universal 'library'. The second section of this author's work ends with the death of a great Macedonian conqueror. A later Latin writer is known only for summarizing the work of a Gallo-Roman historian who wrote about that era. Who employed the father of this original historian as a secretary and interpreter?

Start with an ancient ruler whose court poet described his domain stretching from a northwestern river to a southeastern region. A naval vessel of the 'Black Swan' type, named for a river in this sovereign's historical lands, participated in a global conflict that pitted two major alliances against each other. During this six-year war, nations employed a high-level strategy involving all instruments of power. This form of planning informs the guiding principles for how military forces conduct campaigns. While these principles standardize common tasks, some objectives require unconventional methods, which are executed by specific units. These units, whose activities are defined by a major transatlantic defense organization, can be tasked with neutralizing submerged obstructions. What is the name of the military engineer who used contained explosives to clear a sunken warship at a British anchorage?

A political party held its first direct leadership election following a national loss to a candidate who became the first head of state from his party. This new leader, a lawyer, governed a republic under a supreme law whose implementation was stalled by civil war, leading to emergency provisions passed by a national legislative body. That body, formed after a dynasty's fall, was unstable during an era featuring a lawyer-turned-military-leader who governed a southern province. This figure's era saw an earlier, provisional version of the supreme law, which outlines a system of governance. In one such system, the executive relies on the legislature's support. What is an alternative name for the parliamentary process that occurs when this support is lost?

Consider a business computer first sold in 1969 whose successor models included one designated by the number 32. That successor, launched in the mid-1970s, outsold its predecessor, which had introduced a programming language with the Roman numeral 'II' in its name. The multinational corporation behind these machines, which also invented the magnetic stripe card, shares a high national honor for technological progress with the co-founder of a rival company. This person was also the majority shareholder of an animation studio that was later acquired by an entertainment conglomerate. This conglomerate owned the speedway that hosted the inaugural event for a new racing series in 1996. A driver known for competing in that series, who also won a 24-hour endurance race that same year, had competed in a single premier stock car race in 1992. At what venue did that race take place?

Starting in a Canadian territory named for the large saltwater bay it borders, identify the vast administrative region it belongs to. The northern part of this region was once known by a name that also refers to a large peninsula found within an indigenous homeland. Traveling much further north, you will find one of the world's coldest hamlets, located on a large northern island. This settlement is part of an administrative division that also contains the largest island in the initial saltwater bay. The size of this specific island, whose indigenous name translates to "land across the water", places it on a global list. In the text describing this list, what landmass is given as an example of being both an island and a continent?

A federal agency that produces data on the American populace provides information ranking a northeastern "Granite State" as one of the least populated. In this state is its fourth-largest city, whose name derives from a Brythonic term for "waters" and which acts as the governmental seat for its local region. This type of administrative region, used in 48 states, has exceptions, such as cities not within any county's territory. The most populous of these exceptions is in a state whose adjacent, namesake division emphasizes education. This division hosts an institution that was founded as the state's first school for training teachers. In what year was this institution established?

Starting with a conceptual model of computation involving a tape and symbols, consider a hypothesis about computable functions named after two mathematicians, including the model's namesake. The same person's name also denotes the property of a data-manipulation system that can simulate the initial model. A scholarly publication, whose title includes a word for this property, is an example of a type of periodical used to advance science. These periodicals can be subject to an economic issue involving escalating subscription costs, which is countered by a distribution model that offers free online access. For a publisher founded in the year 2000 that operates on this model, what was the name of its first director?

Starting with a media group that operates two television stations in an American midwestern state, one of which broadcasts a digital signal. This digital technology became standard after a nationwide transition away from older signals, freeing up part of the spectrum. This led to a government sale known as "Auction 73". This type of sale, a method for governments to allocate scarce resources, was later emulated by a neighboring country for the same frequency band. A global list of mobile networks using these frequencies directs readers to a separate document for technical details. What is the numerical identifier for the standards specification mentioned in the description of this final document?

Beginning with the London district named for a company that started by making waterproof clothing, identify the Australian city where the company owner's personal book collection was relocated. Within this city, there is a public square named after a royal who held a specific, displaceable title for an inheritor to a throne at the time of its naming. Following this theme of succession, consider a modern Asian emperor born within a palace moat, and identify the medical facility where his consort, the eldest daughter of a senior diplomat, was born.

Starting with the period of a commercial entity's dominion over a South Asian subcontinent, which began after a key battle, consider its largest administrative subdivision centered in a specific region. This subdivision was later partitioned, leading to the creation of a noncontiguous province that existed during the reigns of two monarchs. This province was part of an empire under direct crown rule, a period embodied by a long-reigning female sovereign who adopted an imperial title related to that subcontinent. This type of ruler, who reigns in her own right, is contrasted with systems governed by a certain ancient legal code known for excluding women from inheritance. Invoking this principle, the only surviving child of a 14th-century French king was barred from his throne. Who did this woman, who instead became queen of a different realm, eventually marry?

In a mid-1960s special election in a rural Scottish area, the opposition party's standing was thought to be enhanced by its leader, a former Prime Minister who held that office from the upper legislative chamber before moving to the lower one. When a vacancy arises in this lower chamber, a special election is held. Consider a case where over a dozen such contests occurred simultaneously in one region in the mid-1980s, prompted by protest resignations from several parties, including a "Popular Unionist" group. The founder of this party later passed away, triggering another special election in his constituency, a place where a different, centrist party often had strong results. In what year was this centrist political party founded?

A U.S. soccer club takes its name from a word in a global Romance language which originated on a specific peninsula. An older form of this language was used for a notable epic poem around the start of the 13th century. A specific dialect of the language's modern form was historically spoken in a North African port city where an ancient seafaring civilization once conducted trade. A rugby team, named for this civilization, was established to play a match against a visiting naval warship. During a prior conflict, this same vessel accepted the surrender of a 700-person garrison in what settlement?

Beginning with a secure facility established in the mid-1970s for the treatment of certain male offenders, consider the category of person defined by the state act that governs this facility. A federal law, created as a subsection of a 1994 act following a specific crime, mandates public notification about such persons. Now, focus on a township situated just east of its state's capital city. Within this township is an unincorporated community, and both are located in a county whose seat is that same capital. This county also contains another township named for a person who lived there. All these places are part of the world's largest metropolitan area by urban landmass. What is the first of the five largest cities listed in that state within this vast area's description?

Start with a television producer who shared a particular award for unscripted programming in two consecutive years in the mid-2000s. Nearly a decade later, the award he won was divided into two distinct categories. Consider a documentary series about the perilous work of fishing crews in a northern sea, a show that portrays the state of existence outside of online interactions. This state also titles a webcomic started near the end of the 20th century which, despite its basis in reality, includes fictional elements like combat between giant robotic suits. The term for these suits is also an acronym for a student empowerment organization. What English word, symbolic of a spark, is phonetically represented by this organization's name?

Begin with the global body founded for peace after the 20th century's first major war and find the judicial institution that succeeded its court. In the Dutch city serving as this institution's home and its nation's seat of government, locate a 13th-century hall on grounds purchased by a Count. This noble fought against the people of a territory north of Bremen. A religious censure suspending a person's communion could be used in such a dispute, potentially leading to the final concept in this path, which is a formal break within a denomination. What single noun from this final concept's definition describes such a separation?

Starting with the official state philosophy of a peninsular nation emphasizing self-reliance, consider an ideology from a neighboring state that was codified in a leader's speech on "people's democratic dictatorship". This ideology, which identified the peasantry as the revolutionary vanguard, was re-imposed as dominant during a decade-long sociopolitical movement. During this movement, a popular song with a title using a nautical leadership metaphor was often sung. Another tune, with lyrics by a farmer, became the de facto national anthem. This was later followed by a patriotic composition, sometimes called the "second national anthem," used as opening music for state radio news. What is the worldwide circulation of the official newspaper associated with these media outlets?

Starting with an 11th-century naval campaign against a North African city, which received aid from a religious authority in Rome, identify this leader's predecessor, who was a central figure in a major controversy regarding the formal installation of incumbents. This installation process is often part of a larger ceremony where a ruler is officially seated for the first time. The object central to this ceremony is a special seat, such as the one named for a large feline and used by a Tibetan leader. In contrast, another such seat is named for a mythical, fire-breathing reptile and was occupied by the head of an East Asian state. What is the specific, two-part title created in the 3rd century BCE for this particular type of sovereign?

Starting with the demographic state where a new generation is less populous than the previous one, consider a government's financial reward, first implemented in the early 20th century, to address this issue. This policy is an example of a pro-reproduction belief system that often opposes conception prevention. Focus on a method that counters this belief, a medication combining two types of hormones. One hormone used is a synthetic progestogen, sometimes called norethindrone. Another medication in the same class can be used for emergencies after unprotected relations, while a third is sold under brand names such as Ovral. In what year was this type of combined oral medication first approved for use in the nation where it is now taken by close to 12 million women?

Starting with a U.S. tax-designated entity that can be structured as a flexible business form, note that this form provides its owners liability protection similar to a corporation without legally being one. When such a corporate body operates outside its original jurisdiction, it is given a specific designation. If this entity is controlled by a parent company—a structure also found in the American railroad industry—and is state-run, it is subject to a system of rules. These rules are managed by a governmental body, which often oversees markets characterized by a lack of effective rivalry, such as one with a single dominant firm. In a simpler, related market model where sellers' decisions are interdependent, what number of firms holds dominant control?

Beginning with a British macro economic historian, identify the American university he attended as a graduate student. A professional school within this institution, established in the late 19th century and a leader in its specific healthcare field, is the subject of a specialized academic journal. This journal, founded in the 1950s, is indexed in a database that first became available online in the mid-1980s. This database is accessible through a technology provider whose former main product was also offered by a competitor. That competing service was powered by a search engine utilizing a data structure that maps content to locations. What is one of the general-purpose mainframe database management systems that used this architecture?

Start with a 1931 French film portraying pessimistic working-class life, and identify its male lead actor. This actor later starred in a 1938 work of poetic realism whose English title refers to a maritime facility. That facility's name shares its meaning with a port city located in a northwestern historical region of France. This region was the site of a major WWII Allied campaign, initiated with landings on several beaches. At the landing zone assigned to Canadian troops, the opposing forces included a German armored division also known for its service in North Africa. During that prior campaign, on what date of the month did this division's commander launch a successful attack against direct orders?

Starting with a major commercial artery that concludes its eastern journey in a specific administrative division, what was the original designation for the city where this street is found? The history of this division details the founding of a village, established in response to an earlier annexation, which shares its name with a local public college. This college is an example of a type of post-secondary institution that is a required step for university admission under the province's unique educational structure. This system was solidified during a period of intense socio-cultural transformation, an era whose efforts are often associated with the government of the province's 19th premier, who was born in the city in question.

Starting with the linguistic situation involving "high" and "low" language forms in a single community, consider the variety typically used for public purposes. This is an instance of a specific form of language, or lect, which itself displays internal variation in pronunciation or word choice. This variation is different from the concept of conformity to a language's rules, which is judged during the cognitive act of interpreting sentences. During this act, a specific negative-going brainwave can signal a rule violation. This brainwave is a subtype of a general electrophysiological response to a stimulus. What is the three-letter acronym for this general response's magnetic counterpart?

Starting with the American IT company founded in a garage, consider the major Texan city that was the primary site of catastrophic flooding from a costliest-on-record tropical cyclone. The record for rainfall from this storm was set in a smaller city settled by immigrants from a Northwestern European country. In that European nation, identify the province which recognizes a secondary official language. The primary national language spoken there is also the official language of a Caribbean country, formerly part of the Netherlands Antilles, that occupies the southern portion of its island. What is this country's capital?

Starting in the U.S. state that contains the United Nations Headquarters, identify the government body responsible for vehicle registration. A former head of this body, who also served as a county's chief financial officer, leads to a major bank headquartered in the state's largest city, known for industry consolidation. An executive who oversaw this bank's 1996 merger also ran the company that absorbed a trust specializing in industrial accounts. A vice president of this trust later became president of another financial company founded in 1866. This second company connects to a British shipping line that prioritized comfortable passage over speed. What was the name of this line's chief rival, with which it eventually combined?

Starting with a southern African nation's third-largest river, find the dam constructed upon it in 1981. This dam is in the continent's southernmost country, which fully encloses a smaller kingdom where a particular Nguni Bantu language is spoken. This kingdom is a member of a global organization, whose population-focused agency is supported by a US-based NGO. The main offices of this global body are in the most populous city in the United States. What single word describes the forward-deployed, screening role of certain soldiers, a role metaphorically similar to this city's position as a global cultural leader?

A British politician born in the late 1950s, whose electoral victory from the second decade of this century was nullified, was a minister in the UK department for immigration and security. This department's head is part of a cabinet supported by a distinct office. A man who led that supportive office's civil service also served as a diplomat, a role connecting to the foreign ministry of a European power whose name dates to a confederation preceding an 1870s empire. The modern successor to this empire uses a currency union's special coins, of which five nations have issued one annually since the mid-2000s. These polities are analogous to the special administrative territories of a North American country, which can be organized via an organic act passed by what legislative body?

An Australian author of fiction novelettes was born in a coastal city nicknamed the nation's 'sugar capital'. One of this city's largest suburbs, where cane and tropical fruits are grown, belongs to a greater administrative region formed by merging three older jurisdictions. One of these was a shire whose main industry is also sugar. This shire amalgamated with another, located further south with a coal export industry, and a city once limited to the southern bank of a river. In a suburb just south of this city's center, the flat terrain was ideal for a specific facility. What is the name of this facility that now occupies the suburb's south-eastern half?

Consider a political party that opposes the consociational power-sharing system established by a major 1990s peace process agreement. The second election for the devolved assembly created by this agreement used a proportional representation voting method involving ranked preferences. An electoral reformer, who was a principal author of a continental constitution, was a proponent of this voting style. This jurist later served on the highest court of the island state where a variant of this system is used. This island lies to the west of a sea named after a Dutch explorer. The indigenous population of the landmass east of this sea have their own name for it in their native tongue. In what year did that native tongue receive official language status?

Starting with an awards ceremony for a South Indian film industry, identify an actress nominated for a film whose title means 'Garden Protector'. The media company founded by this actress produced a soap opera that was later dubbed into another language and broadcast on a channel launched in 1995. This channel exemplifies a subscription-based TV service, a model also used by an American entertainment company that began as a subsidiary of a larger media corporation. This corporation was itself a spin-off from a cable group. A different collection of regional sports networks was acquired by an entertainment giant, but a government department mandated their sale. To which broadcasting entity were these networks ultimately sold?

An ancient coastal town, described by a specific Roman historian, was home to a temple for a Greek deity. This historian chronicled the story of a major European capital's fabled founder, whose maternal grandfather was a monarch usurped by his own brother. The usurper compelled his niece to join a sacred order of priestesses, which is referenced in the title of a live album by an avant-garde musician. The birthplace of this musician is a large district of a modern capital, which historically grew from a settlement whose name translates to 'fort of the men of' which English county?

Starting in a Maryland town whose major street bisects the northeast and southeast quadrants of the adjacent national capital, follow this street as it crosses a river via a bridge approved in late 1949. The finances of the government that approved this bridge are regulated by a legislative committee that exercises the power to manipulate actions by controlling funds. This power can be used as a form of suppression, a practice that a certain digital rights organization, founded by a trio in 1990, works to prevent online. This organization scrutinizes technologies such as a system where decryption keys are held by a third party. According to the text, what is an example of a formal authorization that would grant this third party access?

Starting with an American company that operates the registry for a domain designated for governmental entities, consider how this setup is unique compared to other nations, such as a large northern country that instead uses a second-level domain. This type of domain is managed by a registry, an organization whose operator is sometimes called a network information center. An entity of this kind was responsible for domain allocations until a transfer of responsibility in the late 1990s. A key computer scientist, known for his comprehensive influence on internet standards and his role administering its numbering authority, is credited with a famous software design principle. What is the alternative name for this principle?

Starting with a collection of 56 historic towers recognized by a global cultural body, consider another designated site: a high-altitude African capital praised for its architectural style. This style is an example of a wider artistic movement whose principles were also adopted in a southern European country. A French poet and art critic of this period gave a name to a colorful, abstract offshoot of a more famous art movement. The late works of which artist, whose retrospectives followed his death, were a primary influence on this more famous, parent movement that deconstructed objects into an abstracted form?

Starting with the oldest Roman settlement on a European peninsula, consider its pre-Roman inhabitants, who produced artworks like a fragmented stone bust of a woman. This piece has similarities to another artifact discovered near a city known for its medieval liturgical play. In a separate example from this performance genre, the text from a heavenly being is indicated by a specific manuscript convention. What is the geological substance that provides the Latin origin for the name of this convention?

Starting with a catalog of laws from a national parliament formed in 1922, consider a statute from nine years later that addressed the status of children born outside of marriage. This statute was a product of that legislative body, which has two chambers, including a 'lower house'. The eligibility to serve in such a chamber is governed by rules, including a minimum age for candidacy. This rule is often protested by groups advocating for the rights of young people. One such web-based group, founded in the mid-1990s, focuses on preserving the online liberties of minors. This group combats the widespread control of online information, a practice that intensified during which series of regional protests?

Starting in the European capital known for its arts scene, find the major orchestra that bears the city's name. Next, consider a German conductor and violinist associated with this orchestra, who co-founded an ensemble specializing in a historical musical style. From that early 17th-century musical era, identify a virtuoso composer famous for playing that conductor's stringed instrument. This composer's instrument is featured in a specific type of composition for a soloist and ensemble. Among the composers known for this genre, find the German Romantic who wrote three such works. This composer's early teacher was the dedicatee of a concerto for a keyboard instrument, written by a different prominent composer. In what year was this final concerto completed?

Consider the followers of a monotheistic religion founded in the 15th century in the northern Indian subcontinent. A 20th-century political leader from this faith was instrumental in creating a committee to manage their shrines. A political party he guided controls not only that body but also a similar organization in India's capital, which is headquartered at a specific historic shrine. This shrine commemorates the cremation of a guru martyred by order of a 17th-century emperor. This ruler, whose reign lasted nearly half a century, is noted for establishing a certain religious legal system. A civil code created in the late 19th century was the first attempt to codify part of this legal system for an empire. Who led the commission that drafted this code?

Starting with a financial promise where one party guarantees another's debt, which is formalized in a contract involving a recipient of the obligation, consider the compensation required for this risk. This concept is linked to the minimum rate of return a business will accept for a project, a threshold that increases with uncertainty. This rate is a key input for a valuation method that finds the present value of future funds, a process that is the reverse of calculating a bond's yield from its price. What is the name of the specific rate of return, determined using this method, which makes an investment's net present value zero, and is conceptually similar to a rate calculated on the balance at the end of a period? This rate is contrasted with an effective rate calculated against a starting balance, which itself is distinct from what other lending metric?

Starting with a water pipe whose origin is linked to a Persian dynasty, consider that dynasty's sixth ruler. His royal title shares a linguistic root with another princely designation for rulers in Transoxiana. The lineage of these rulers survived into the era of the caliphate that overthrew the Umayyads, a caliphate whose capital was west of a vast region where many country names share a Persian suffix. The western edge of this region is defined by the world's largest inland body of water. Within a country bordering this body of water to the northwest is a geological feature, sometimes considered a continental boundary. What two rivers give this feature its name?

Starting with a Swiss environmentalist party that first elected a national representative in 1979, consider the broader political movement it represents, whose member organizations often join a global federation established in 2001. The term for this ideology originates from the German-language name of a party founded in the late 1970s. In that country, this type of party won a state's 14th legislative election, forming a coalition with a social-democratic party to govern the state diet. After the 15th election for this diet, the environmentalists formed a new, historic coalition. A politician from the social-democratic party in the earlier coalition received his doctorate in 2006. In what city was this politician born?

A Pacific island's light railway used a locomotive likely from a German engine manufacturer. This company also built a 100hp licensed copy of a nine-cylinder French rotary engine that was fitted to numerous aircraft. A British scout plane, from a firm later famous for seaplanes, used a variant from this French engine family, although its direct predecessor was designed for a different, 80hp French engine. This 80hp motor powered a successful and agile British biplane, which was eventually surpassed by newer German fighters. One such German aircraft improved its predecessor's poor upward visibility by modifying wing placement. In what month and year did the flying troops inspectorate order the first batch of this improved fighter?

Start with a French Christian existentialist who disassociated himself from a famous contemporary. That contemporary was influenced by another French philosopher who was once held in an internment camp. This interned academic's work on German idealism preceded the celebrated lectures on the same subject by a Russian-born thinker who also became a statesman instrumental in forming a major continental union. This union's purpose is related to a global trade agreement which was superseded by a modern organization whose rules are ratified by national parliaments. The text describing the original agreement mentions a politician who served in such a parliament. The year this man first took his seat is the same year an act concerning naturalization in the American colonies was passed. What is the month and day this act became effective?

Starting with a type of ocular opacity associated with a rare genetic metabolic disorder, first described by a German physician in 1917, identify the sugar that cannot be properly metabolized. This sugar, whose name comes from the Greek for "milk", is a component of a disaccharide broken down by a specific enzyme in the β-galactosidase family. This enzyme is an example of a broader class of macromolecular catalysts. A specific instance of such a catalyst, which reversibly hydrates fumarate, has a version that operates within the intracellular fluid matrix. In what organism does the high concentration of molecules in this fluid lead to an observable crowding phenomenon?

Start with an English novel by an East African author concerning the Mau Mau Uprising. The country featured in this story would soon be governed by its first indigenous leader. This leader's first Attorney General was the son of a colonial chief whose family was friends with a paleoanthropologist. This scientist's work supported the theory that the evolutionary process leading to modern people originated in Africa. A key fossil site providing evidence for this is a village that lies within a regional state formerly known as Region 2. In the northern part of this state is a geological depression, and within it, what is the name of the lake that marks the continent's lowest point?

Begin with an Iowa city, a global hub for frozen desserts whose name is an acronym of six women's first names. This city could have a site on the federal government's official list of preserved properties. That list was established by a 1966 preservation law, which also created state-level preservation offices and an advisory council that provides guidance to the nation's bicameral legislature. One chamber of this legislative body can meet as a single group including all its members under relaxed procedural requirements. This functional arrangement, a meeting of a deliberative assembly to allow for open debate, is described in the text for the final entity in this sequence. What is that entity's specific name?

Starting with an electrical component used for adjusting elements like a lamp dimmer, consider a device that disperses the heat this component generates into a certain medium. This medium's name is shared with a GUI builder that produces human-readable computer instructions. These instructions also title a film where a soldier enters a computed reality, a concept explored within a ten-book fantasy series about a character who becomes a hero in an alternate world. Within this saga, the concluding novel of its final tetralogy ends a story that began with the series' inaugural book. In that first book, what is the name of the main character's son, who is taken to live with his mother?

Starting with the private financial media company founded in the early 1980s, identify its flagship radio station, which broadcasts from the company's 55-story headquarters. Now, consider a journalist who anchored a rival network's evening news for a decade. He works for the news division that airs the longest-running television program in American history. This program once interviewed a politician who uniquely served as both vice president and president without being elected to either office. This leader was raised in the city where a high school athletic league was established in the late 1920s. What is the name of that city?

Starting with an epidemiological measure of disease occurrence that is expressed as a rate with a denominator, consider the type of data this part of the fraction represents. An agency of a federal statistical system collects this kind of information on its country's populace through periodic surveys. A journal dedicated to the methodology of such data collection is cataloged in a bibliographic database co-published by a scholarly society founded in the 1930s. This society offers joint membership with another professional association that was established in the 19th century. In what European city is the permanent office of this latter association located?

Beginning with a 20th-century political leader who campaigned for a state with a Sikh majority, identify the northern Indian region he focused on. This region is part of a country for which there is an alphabetical index of related articles. Within that index, find an actress known for portraying a goddess in a bilingual mythological film from 1963. A supporting actor in that same film, who later became a prominent leading man, passed away in 2008. What is the medical term for the cardiac event that caused his death?

Starting with a ceremonial square in an ancient capital that provided a link to a great domed edifice, consider the historic event where that city was captured by an invading empire. A naval gun-boat, named after an elite corps of soldiers from that victorious army, participated in a campaign within a Mediterranean bay. This bay is where a modern underwater archaeologist, who holds a degree in a specific field of study dealing with quantity and structure, discovered submerged cities. This field of study was the specialty of a famed scientist from classical antiquity. What was this scientist's city of origin?

On a Pacific archipelago governed as a special collectivity of a European nation, there is a specific demographic of locally-born European descendants. Historically, such remote territories were sometimes used as settlements for exiles. An example of such a settlement in a South American nation was eventually evacuated, with its inmates being transferred to a nearby city. This city sits on the banks of a major river whose source lies in a neighboring country. This large neighboring nation, a union of over two dozen federated units, has a constitutional rule that its federal district cannot be subdivided into a certain type of self-governing entity. What two-word phrase is used to define this type of entity?

Starting with the Roman plebeian family of a famous triumvir, consider his paternal uncle's birthplace, a region on the Adriatic whose Roman-given name is an example of an outsider's term, contrasting with the native inhabitants' unknown internal name. This linguistic concept of external naming is also seen in a list of German place names for a neighboring country, which links to a sub-list for a specific historical region. In the original list for a particular county in that region, what is the German external name for the town whose modern name starts with 'F'?

Starting with a 17th-century European bi-confederation, consider the Latin exonym for a region inhabited by its multi-ethnic population. The people from this region, who were a major part of a Grand Duchy within the confederation, had their name's origin detailed in a chronicle compiled around 1113. An 11th-century German chronicler, who also wrote about these northern peoples, hailed from a place within a German state that was once a medieval duchy. This state's territory was later part of a socialist republic formed in 1949, whose boundaries were based on an occupation zone established by an international accord. In what month and year was this tripartite agreement on military occupation finalized?

Start in the Hong Kong district once named the world's busiest by a records publication, and identify a mid-1990s film about underground societies that is a spin-off whose title alludes to this district. The actor who played this film's main character also starred in a martial arts comedy series that debuted in the final year of the 1980s. In that series, another veteran actor portrayed twin brothers, one of whom learned a 'Maiden scripture'. Now, consider a separate wuxia series from a decade earlier, adapted from three books by a Taiwanese author. The star of that 65-episode series also played the main character in a television adaptation of a different author's work, which first aired the previous year. In that 1978 production, which performer was cast as the character 'Chiu Man'?

Starting with a large legislative region in a Plains state whose modern form was determined by a mid-20th-century national population count, consider the 24th iteration of this constitutionally required decennial event. The federal agency conducting this count also provides data for a southwestern state that achieved statehood on a day associated with romance in the early 1900s. This agency's data is also crucial for the "Buckeye State," named after a large river. Find the senior federal legislator from this state, and identify the current representative of the district he formerly served, a district that was redrawn following a more recent population enumeration.

Starting with a political association of former imperial territories, consider its main intergovernmental agency, which is housed in a former royal residence gifted by the organization's symbolic head. This title was created so a populous South Asian nation, noted for its system of government where citizens exercise power, could become a republic. In contrast to that system of popular rule is a hereditary one where power is passed within a family. In a specific Gaelic variant of this hereditary succession, a historical account mentions a leader whose eldest son was his designated heir. After this leader's murder, who succeeded him as king?

A Michigan liberal arts college, a top producer of volunteers for a federal service program, was led by its first female president, who obtained her doctorate from a California graduate-only research university. That university is part of a consortium whose founding undergraduate member was later led by a theoretical chemist as its ninth head. His successor, a scholar of literature from a European island nation, studies a body of work that includes the oldest recorded poem in that nation's early language, composed by an illiterate cow-herder. According to the text, who translated this oral composition into a classical language?

Starting with an Indian region that once headquartered a larger division before a historic partition, consider a village within it founded by brothers from another part of the state. This leads to a second village in a separate territory, which is named after the first region's main city. What is the general term for this type of administrative division, which can be governed by an elected body, similar to a historical advisory council of a North American province under an empire? An athlete involved in a rinks event competed for this empire in a multi-sport gathering which later changed its name. This modern event is for an association of nations, one of which governs a Pacific territory of three atolls. What was this territory's former name, prior to being changed in the 1970s?

Beginning with a mental condition characterized by both psychosis and mood instability, we find an album whose title mentions a type of false belief. A hit single from this album borrows its name from the slogan of a fictional corporation in a novel adapted into a film. Consider the industry for home distribution of such films, and a pioneering company that was the first to release them on consumer tapes. This company later became part of a joint venture that supported an analog cassette format, which ultimately lost a market war. In what year did the creator of this losing format introduce its successful family of professional video products?

Starting with a periodical founded in 1967, consider the media company that purchased it in 1984 and was later a party in a legal decision regarding television broadcast regulation. This case was part of a series of notable judgments from the court led by a Chief Justice who was appointed in 1973. This jurist, originally from a city now part of Thunder Bay, had a son who also became a judge. The father's prominent judicial title is granted by a parliamentary statute. What is the minimum number of litigants annually granted permission to appeal to the highest judicial body established by that same statute?

Beginning with the early medieval federation spanning from a pale-colored sea to a dark one, find a principality on a peninsula at its easternmost edge. This principality's site once hosted a fortress built by a semi-nomadic Turkic people. A vast collection of manuscripts, found in an old Egyptian city, details the history of a Middle-Eastern region this Turkic group was commercially connected to. Parts of this collection are now held by a university whose digital library project had an initial theme of "Faith and Science." A sixth-form institution specializing in science, located in an English city, shares its ownership trust with a partner college. This partner college is a specific type of state-funded school. What year did the government policy that established this type of school begin?

Starting in an Australian capital city whose location was determined by a 1908 act requiring it to be at least 100 miles from another major city, consider the phenomenon of unrestricted urban growth that this second, most populous city in the nation exemplifies. A non-profit organization, formed in 1974 to advocate against this phenomenon, promotes a regulatory process for land. A primary method of this process is dividing land into zones with specified permitted uses. A specific statutory instrument in a European country, made under the authority of a 1971 act, defines classes for these uses. This instrument is part of a broader national system whose history cites several influential figures, including one architect and PRIBA. What is this architect's full name?

Starting with the deep-ocean organisms that produce biomass via chemical oxidation near certain fissures, identify the type of divergent tectonic boundary where such fissures are found. From a specific example of this boundary, trace a path to its southern section, which serves as the origin for a chain of over 70 underwater mountains. These mountains, if their tops erode flat before subsiding, are given a specific name derived from a university building named for a 19th-century geographer. What geological formations are the typical origin of these individual underwater mountains?

Begin with a former UK parliamentary voting area created by merging constituencies, one partly named for a firth. A hamlet sits on this firth's southern shore. The firth is a scenic landscape overseen by a public conservation body which advises the country's devolved administration. In the symbolic system this administration might use, the device on the helm can be used in a flexible emblem of allegiance. When combining two such emblems, a method exists that merges the right half of one with the left half of the other. What is the name of the subsequent technique this method preceded, where both complete designs are placed side by side?

Starting with a collection of science fiction tales, consider the literary form they exemplify. A prolific South Asian author, known for this form, made his filmmaking debut with an award-winning cinematic adaptation of his own novel. An actor from this film also became a politician, serving in his country's supreme legislative body. The title for an elected official in this assembly is common to a governmental system modeled after that of the United Kingdom. What is the name of the capital city where the federal legislature of another country employing this same system is located?

Starting with a continental football association that arranges qualifying matches for a major international women's tournament, consider an earlier invitational event that was a precursor to this competition. In that precursor's inaugural edition, one squad played to a draw against a team from a European kingdom. This kingdom's team would go on to win a regional championship for northern European countries on several occasions. A celebrated player from a neighboring nation, also a participant in this regional contest, is noted for scoring her country's very first goal. In a major city in her homeland, a large multi-purpose venue, originally constructed for a men's global tournament, has accommodated various events, including an annual two-person motorcycling championship. In which year was this motorcycling event held for the last time before being merged with another competition?

Begin with the high-precision rifle utilized by specialized combatants from a major Eastern European country during a global war. A military branch from a Southeast Asian archipelagic nation later developed a similar weapon, but adapted it for a smaller, 'rimless' ammunition type standardized by a multinational alliance. After considering the function of the cartridge 'rim', or flange, turn to a different, rimmed ammunition that initiated the 'Magnum era' in 1934. One of the companies that created this round had earlier developed another notable cartridge for their 'New Century' model. In what year was this earlier cartridge introduced?

Starting with a list of royal awards distributed after a major world war, identify an honoree who was both a military officer and an amateur sportsman. This individual participated in the highest-standard version of a certain sport, which is the subject of a famous annual publication colloquially known as that sport's 'bible'. To commemorate this publication's centennial edition, a trophy was created. This prize is awarded for series played in the longest format of the game. Considering the female equivalent of this long-form competition, in what year did the third nation to compete at this level—a team nicknamed for a native plant—make its debut?

Starting in a New York City neighborhood known as a residence for many prominent jazz artists, consider the sole offspring of a celebrated bandleader and composer. Next, find a record label subsidiary, established in the late 1940s, that was later run by a producer who created hits for his vocalist spouse. Following this singer's jazz-influenced style, identify a bebop pioneer and trumpeter known for his uniquely angled horn. A signature composition by this musician serves as a notable example of a musical section where the rhythm accompaniment pauses for a soloist. This type of solo feature is considered a form of an ornamental, improvised passage. In a written score, what is the musical symbol used to indicate this passage?

Beginning with an ancient astronomical text that established a geocentric model of the universe, find the figure whose work eventually superseded it. A stained-glass window themed on this figure's system was designed by an artist who lived when his homeland was undergoing foreign divisions. The first of these divisions resulted in the creation of a district, named for a river, from seized territory. An uprising in this larger region was later organized by a general who had been promoted during an earlier, unsuccessful rebellion. What was the formal title of the leader of that unsuccessful rebellion, a man who also fought in a revolutionary war on another continent?
answer: Supreme Commander of the Polish National Armed Forces

question: What title was given at birth to the young royal who was the titular predecessor of a restored monarch, a monarch who compensated an artist for work started under a previous regime, an artist who studied under the same master as the painter of a scene set on a cape that overlooks the same body of water as a seaside resort destroyed in the same catastrophic event as an ancient city, a city which is a destination on a regional Italian rail line?

A Canadian variety series from the early 1970s was hosted by a man who also emceed a 1969 game show where he met his future wife. That program, which had couples performing stunts, was stylistically similar to an earlier show involving contestants racing to complete tasks before time ran out. The unique features designed to attract attention in such shows are sometimes considered mere novelties. This term is part of the name of a collective specializing in stop-motion animation. The technique was famously used by a visual effects creator, known for animating a battle with seven skeletons, who collaborated on a 1949 film with his mentor. This mentor developed an interest in prehistoric creatures while guiding fossil experts in what geographic area?

Starting with a Gallic organization that handles customs and immigration control at smaller checkpoints, consider the large European zone with a unified travel policy whose external borders it helps secure. The frontiers of this zone are coordinated by a Warsaw-based agency that received an expanded role following a major migration event in the mid-2010s. This event highlighted the issue of unauthorized entry, a situation common for people from a specific African nation with a very high rate of emigration. Within this nation, there exists a community descended from European settlers whose numbers grew significantly after a 1930s conflict with a neighboring empire. What is the English translation of the classical name for the region of that empire, a name derived from two ancient Hellenic words meaning "I burn" and the word for a face?

Starting in the English university city once known as a "ford of the oxen," locate the large parkland northeast of its center. Identify the road that borders this park to the south, home to a major scientific area. On this road stands a chemistry lab which replaced an older facility. This predecessor lab was named for the two institutions it was located between. One institution was founded in the mid-16th century, and its partner was established around the mid-13th century. What is the name of the famous London museum designed by the Victorian architect associated with the older of these two institutions?

Starting with an American journalist who became a bureau chief in a European capital, identify the natural island at this city's historical center. This island is situated in a major river. Follow this river to a left tributary that flows through a particular settlement. This settlement is a type of fourth-level administrative division within its country. In what year was the legal concept for the highest-level administrative divisions in this same country officially adopted?

Start with the alluvial stream that originates in a county named for a Confederate general. This county is part of a large tri-state metropolitan area, which in turn covers a northern region of one of its constituent states. Within this northern region is a county whose name suggests the joining of several parts. This county is in a state whose western boundary is largely defined by a major river. In that state, a coastal city and county seat suffered extensive damage and population loss from a catastrophic weather event. In which month and year did this event, the third major one of its season, take place?

Starting with the rugged plateau on the western side of a major East Coast mountain range, move to its southern part. From there, identify a sandstone plateau section that is separated from the main portion by a long valley. Next, find the river that drains this valley, and then consider one of its tributaries which is formed by many smaller streams. This tributary is included in a state-wide list of waterways. From that list's context, pinpoint an alluvial stream in the western part of the same state whose mouth is at the site of a future major city. In what federally protected forest does this final river rise?

A Soviet director's theories on cinema inspired a style of 'truthful filmmaking,' which was founded by a French filmmaker and anthropologist. This Frenchman's work, creating a genre that blends documentary and fiction, includes a 1958 film about immigrants in an Ivorian city. This specific film genre is also represented by a 2009 production about a man serving a long sentence in a prison located in the Italian port city nicknamed 'the proud one'. This same city was home to a 13th-century statesman and troubadour. What was the name of this statesman's wife?

Start with the ruler who expanded a holy plaza and forged a new aristocracy. His royal house's kingdom was later split among his sons, one of whom was a tetrarch whose story is told in a gospel that is the first half of a two-volume work. The second volume describes how followers of the new faith were turned against, leading to the death of the first martyr, a deacon whose name translates to 'crown'. In his final speech to his judges, this deacon would have invoked the most important prophet of his people. What is the literal meaning of this prophet's Hebrew title?

An educational academy in an East Coast city is designed for students with severe academic or behavioral issues. This institution is an example of a nontraditional school model, which can provide aided education for students with individual needs, such as those with neurodevelopmental conditions. The media portrayals of these conditions are common in the television industry, a field celebrated by a major American award. This award has a specific prize for engineering achievements that improve recording or reception. A certain American company, now a subsidiary, is known for making test and measurement equipment relevant to this field. What two-word term describes the innovative activities undertaken by such a company to create new services or products?

Starting on a road named for the university parkland it runs alongside, head to its southern junction to find a street with a mid-18th-century music hall. At this street's western terminus lies a wider avenue, home to a famous bookshop. The son of this shop's founder was the first in his family to attend university. The founder himself was once rejected for a librarian position in a city that would become the capital of a constituent UK country. According to a 2011 census, what percentage of that country's population, aged three and over, could speak its native Brittonic language?

Starting in a protected area within a southern African province known for its extensive inland wetlands, consider a district whose geography is entirely defined by the water collection area of a major river flowing through it. This river, the second largest in its region to drain into the ocean to its east, is part of a system that transports eroded natural material. This material can be a granular substance, one type of which is formed from the limestone remains of marine life. The formation of this substance is exemplified by a specific group of aquatic vertebrates. What is the general name for this type of creature, which is also included in the final node's list of organisms responsible for the breakdown of hard ocean substrates?

An instrumental blues piece by a well-known quartet shares a four-way writing credit with one of their festive songs. The producer of this song, often called the fifth member of the band, also worked on comedy records. This genre connects to a musical revue performed by a duo as an "after-dinner farrago." This type of theatrical entertainment, which lacks an overarching plot, had its golden age between 1916 and 1932. A cinematic example from that period was an early sound film featuring nearly all of one major studio's stars, including a Swedish-born actress who became an international celebrity in 1927. A term for this actress's profession is the title of a children's game show that quizzed contestants on film clips. What was that show's theme music called?

A prize for navigation, established via a grant in 1786, is awarded by the first learned society in a certain nation. A key figure in that society's home city, who signed a famous declaration and founded a college, belonged to an intellectual movement that spurred a major conflict. This movement drew on a native philosophical tradition, now taught at a colonial-era university that was the first in its country to award a doctorate. This university predates the conflict, which saw patriots protest by refusing to deal with the ruling power. What is the term for this type of refusal when it is officially legislated by a government?

Starting in the North African nation named for its capital, identify the 19th-century pact that established a European protectorate there. This pact was signed by the nation's ruler, who had succeeded his brother and also permitted the creation of the country's first Arabic newspaper. A commercial interest from the protectorate nation, related to a telegraph concession, leads to that country's second-largest city. This metropolis is the capital of an administrative department named for a river's estuary. Now, consider a different major river that rises in the Alps and flows through the historic region that includes this department. Within this historic region, what is the capital of the administrative area that is bordered to the west by the 'river mouth' department and is known for hosting its nation's main naval port?

Beginning with a lengthy waterway in a central European nation, identify the former commune where it originates. This community was merged into a new one, which also absorbed the former commune that became its seat. This seat is located in a type of major administrative division primarily found within the nation's European part. When considering the non-European territories that complete the republic, many of which are relics of a past empire, what is the name of the island group in one such territory that lies to the south of Madagascar?

Begin in a Greek regional unit whose capital is a town famed for ancient rites. Within this unit is a historic municipality, once a district ruled by the offspring of a mythical Athenian king. This king's other son, an archaic "goat-man," is the namesake of a sea. In this sea's southeastern corner, find an island group literally named for the number twelve. This group, along with territories from a former dual monarchy, underwent a cultural assimilation process enforced by a European kingdom. In what year was a specific northern autonomous region, previously part of that monarchy, annexed by the nation enforcing this policy?

Starting with the Allied program created to safeguard cultural property during a global conflict, identify the presidential commission whose chairman also led an investigation into a surprise military strike on a Pacific naval base. This attack drew a nation into the ensuing war, a conflict which saw aerial attacks on an enemy's industrial infrastructure. The economic sector targeted by these attacks led to a societal structure defined by mass production. What is the name of the sociologist who originated the term for the societal stage that succeeds this, in which the service sector generates more wealth than manufacturing?

A Scottish country music station was operated by a media group whose original studios were in a specific city district. This district's underground transport hub was later absorbed into a state-owned system as part of a government takeover. An act of parliament reflecting this policy, passed after a global conflict, formed a public board to manage the nation's solid fuel industry. Decades prior, a commission studying this industry provided a platform for an Italian-born theorist to advocate for such state ownership. The chairman of this commission, who later held a top judicial office, was called to the Bar in 1892 at which legal society?

Starting in the southernmost state of the New England region, locate its capital city where a professional soccer team was founded. This team plays in a facility that formerly hosted a minor league football team from a coastal athletic conference. This conference served as a farm system for a major professional team named after a bird of prey. A shade of a certain color associated with this major team shares its name with an Australian singer who entertained allied forces in a Southeast Asian country in 1968. What is the capital of that country?

A German physicist, whose discovery of energy quanta won him a Nobel Prize, worked in a field of modern physics that explains the thermodynamic behavior of large systems. A pioneering Austrian physicist in that subject was elected to a prestigious scientific society in the same year as a British anthropologist. This anthropologist was an alumnus of a college, famous for educating a key theorist of evolution, that was originally established by a 15th-century clergyman. This college is located in a university city that was granted its modern status in what year?

Starting with the general rulebooks for biological naming, consider the specific committee of experts that governs classification for infectious agents which replicate only within living cells. Within this domain, a family of plant pathogens with single-stranded circular genomes is categorized by a system developed by a specific scientist. This system depends on the nature of nucleic acid strands, a concept vital to the molecules that convey genetic data to protein-making machinery. What is the name of the simpler bacterial structure that degrades these messenger molecules, performing a similar role to the more intricate multi-protein complex found in eukaryotes?

Begin with an academic publisher founded in 1893, which serves a university established a quarter-century later. This educational institution evolved into a multi-campus system after a 1951 reorganization. One of its ten campuses, which joined a prestigious research university association in 1996, exemplifies a broader concept of affiliated schools. Following this concept, find another state's system that includes a specialized division for agriculture. This division's research arm develops new technology for cultivated goods. According to the description of these goods, what is a specific example of one gathered intensively from its natural environment?

Start with a bacterial ATPase that oscillates pole-to-pole with a partner protein, once mistakenly believed to form a stationary ring. These are two components of a three-part system that ensures correct septum placement by inhibiting a polymer structure, and which functions with a secondary negative regulator. Consider the third component, absent in certain genera, which directly prevents a ring's assembly at the cell poles. Identify the protein that forms this inhibited ring and is a prokaryotic homologue of a eukaryotic cytoskeletal protein. This eukaryotic protein, whose polymers are targeted in cancer treatment, can form a two-part complex. An example of such a complex is the enzyme that carries out reverse transcription. What is the general classification for proteins that can function as these two-part complexes to bind directly to genetic material and regulate gene expression after sensing specific hormones?

Follow the lineage from the fourth holder of an Irish peerage title, created in 1580, to his maternal grandfather. This grandfather's son, nicknamed for his long nails, conspired with a man from a prominent Munster dynasty during a rebellion. This uprising was a response to a decades-long military subjugation that concluded shortly before an exodus of native aristocrats. Their departure facilitated an organized settlement of a northern province. What is the original Old Irish name, meaning 'oak grove', for a city located within one of the counties central to this settlement?

Starting with the public university founded as an art school in the mid-19th century, identify its law school, which outranked several institutions in a prominent university mission group. This school's parent institution co-founded a postgraduate legal practice institute in the early 1990s with the oldest university in the English-speaking world. This ancient university's medical school places its pre-clinical students in a science district, which is bordered on its western side by a road named for the adjacent university green space. This road, once home to a notable Irish novelist, leads north to a final arterial route. What is the current designation of this final route?

In a state with over 500 public school systems, there is a city known as the 'Wheat Capital'. A railway, established at the start of the 20th century and bearing this city's name, extended south to a town named in honor of the first U.S. president's residence. A cinema built there in the 1950s was eventually co-owned by a writer of speculative fiction. The subcultures that form around such genres and other interests are known by a collective term. According to a major dictionary's etymology, what is the earliest recorded year of this term's usage?

Beginning with an unleavened food whose ancient remains were found in the Black Desert, consider a nearby country that was later invaded by Seljuk forces. The 34th sovereign of the successor empire to those invaders fought an unsuccessful war with a northern power, which included a battle where troops crossed the Danube River. In the same wider ancient region as a city named for a victory that became a provincial capital, another wealthy urban center served as the capital for the Chaonians. According to a catalog of settlements in this region, find a different town belonging to the Cassopaei people that was a colony of a city-state in the Peloponnese. What was the estimated population that could be enclosed within this final settlement's polygonal walls?

On a plane representing numbers with two perpendicular components, multiplication can be described by summing angles. The standard unit for these angles is mentioned alongside its solid equivalent. This solid unit, used in three-dimensional geometry, projects onto a sphere to define a surface area. The geometric construct it quantifies can have its vertex at the center of a simple closed shape. According to its description, when this shape includes its interior, it is called by another name. A special case of this figure has a radius of one. If you generalize this unit-radius concept to the next higher dimension, what is the term for the object that comprises both the surface and the interior of the resulting solid?

Starting with a principality's domestic football cup established by its ruler in the mid-1970s, consider its national team, which, despite representing a sovereign state, is not part of the main European football association. This team was a founding member of a board for unrecognized nations, an organization that includes another team representing a de facto state formed after a military invasion.
