Following the ethnic group opposing this invasion to their nation's capital, a city known as the birthplace of democracy, identify the reformer who established its isonomic institutions. During which year did a foreign king first try, and fail, to stop these reforms?

Begin at a 19th-century fort built by an Italian noble house, now a museum. A transportation hub on a French island is named after a historical figure connected to this fort. In this figure's birthplace, a citadel was built by a maritime power. This power was resisted by a local patriot who wrote a constitution for his island republic. The maritime power he opposed, nicknamed "the Superb one," also once ruled a Greek island, which is famous for its main export. This export, a resin known as the "tears" of the island, is a key ingredient in a chewy, stretchy frozen dessert. The most famous vendor of this dessert is a popular attraction in a souq in what ancient city?

Consider the physicist credited with inventing the first operational laser, a feat for which he received many awards. One type of scientific honor, a medal from a Philadelphia institute, also recognized a Dutch-American Nobel laureate for his work in laser spectroscopy. This laureate's academic career as a professor typically necessitates obtaining the highest university degree awarded for research. In some European nations, however, a different, higher qualification is required for university teaching and access to a professorship. An example of such a position is a specific prize and professorship given by a notable college of environmental design at a California university. This college, which has a department for landscape architecture, is associated with a distinguished practitioner in that field. What is the name of the regional design style this professional helped establish in the period following a major mid-20th century global conflict?

Starting with the UK by-elections caused by the mass resignation of Unionist MPs over a political accord, identify a participant who was also a classical scholar. This scholar mastered an ancient Italic language that is central to a global religious institution headquartered in the city where that language originated. A theological doctrine, named for a presbyter from an Egyptian city, challenged a core belief of this institution's largest branch. The chief defender of the mainstream view against this doctrine was a 4th-century bishop of that same city who was exiled multiple times. During one of his exiles, an adherent of the challenging doctrine was installed in his place. In what year did this appointee's tenure end?

Starting with a type of organization that recognizes peer excellence, find a specific society for students in a discipline focused on process optimization. This field, which aims to improve productivity, was pioneered by a figure who also worked as a business performance advisor. This advisory practice, which promotes "best practices," leads to a list of formalized guidelines whose description instead discusses a political text from 1920. The author of that text, a revolutionary who led a soviet government, is associated with a type of single-party state. This state's description leads to a public education system located in which American commonwealth?

Starting with the insect family known as "teak moths," identify one of the plant families their larvae feed on. From this plant family, find a genus named in honor of a Spanish queen consort, and then another genus with about two hundred fifty species. Next, consider a species from that second genus which can survive for many years. Contrasting with this multi-year lifecycle, find the term for a plant that flowers only once before dying. Finally, what is the botanical family name of an evergreen plant that exhibits the opposite reproductive strategy and is known for columnar stems that lack secondary growth?

Starting with the birthplace of a 19th-century Serbian academic who served as a dean, identify the country where this village is located. Within this country, find the city on a major river that was the final capital for the ruler of a medieval despotate. This state was a vassal to a Holy Roman Emperor who led a crusade and founded a chivalric order. This emperor's close friend, an aristocrat of Polish origin, was appointed to a high administrative office in a region, now part of Romania. What was the title of this office?

Beginning in the European capital where the largest enclosed residential district for a specific ethnic group was established during a major global conflict, an article about post-uprising executions in that district's ruins mentions an Australian athlete who relocated to that Asian country to join its premier football league. A domestic cup competition associated with this league is broadcast by a local sports division partnered with a major US sports network. This US network historically televised a specific combat sport through a long-running weekly series. What secondary school was attended by a professional in this sport who won a reality competition series and was raised in an eastern area of a major Californian city?

Starting in a city nicknamed for being the country's sugar hub, find the electoral division it belongs to, a district named after the leader of the world's first parliamentary socialist government. A special election held in this division was triggered by the death of its representative, a former manager at a sugar mill. The seat was subsequently won by a candidate from the nation's oldest political organization. This organization is one of two dominant groups featured in an article listing all the country's political entities. The other major group is a coalition led by a major centre-right party established in the mid-1940s. What is the well-known name of the electoral malapportionment scheme introduced in 1936 by a major conservative party from a southern state that operated between 1932 and 1974?

What modern monarch is informally known by a title that originated within a system of nobility whose members sat in a legislative body that developed from a council of landholders and existed until an early 18th-century political union? This nobility system was replaced by a new one after that union, and then superseded again by another system following a subsequent union about a century later. The title in question is of the highest rank in this system, a rank first introduced into the country in the 14th century. A key early holder of this specific title was a noted soldier, author, and a founding member of a prominent chivalric order. The title itself is tied to certain estates and is used in a customary toast in its historic region.

Beginning with a failed coup organized by four retired generals to stop a European nation from abandoning its North African territory, identify the organizer who was the most decorated soldier in his country's army. This general's military service was with his nation's land-based forces, which included an armored unit formed during a major 20th-century global conflict. The same nation's military also featured a corps of "African Hunters," who acted as the mounted equivalent of their infantry. This unit is an example of lightly armed cavalry, a type of troop popular with armies from Central Asia. What is the late medieval country where a specific, widely adopted class of these light horsemen historically originated?

Start at the Cornish village famed for diving due to treacherous nearby rocks. These rocks, whose name means "church stones", are in a bay named for a port town. In that town is a church whose foundations were laid by a man who held a baronetcy. This politician was a member of a legislative body that met after the Long Parliament dissolved, and which enacted a law of general pardon for crimes committed during a civil war. This law was a result of a proclamation made by a returning monarch. What is the full date of that proclamation?

Starting with the 19th-century industrial process that uses limestone to produce a common alkali, note that a chemical oxide derived from one of the process's key ingredients sounds like a surname. This surname, which is also an ICAO airline designator, belongs to a man whose son founded a state during an era of three competing powers. A rival leader, aiming to restore a fallen dynasty, eventually conquered an expansive province which had been governed by a father and then his son. This territory became the basis for the rival's new state, which was intended as a successor to the old empire. In what year did the son who had inherited that province surrender it to this rival leader?

Starting with the fourth prime number that is also a "happy prime", identify a 1940 romance film whose title uses this number's name and stars a German-American actress. A major film company from this actress's home country operated until the end of the era of a certain far-right political party. A journalist who co-founded this party's precursor was commissioned in his work by an occultist society named for a mythical northern country. This society sponsored the party whose leader's racial doctrines were studied by a think tank that was an appendage of the SS. Who established this think tank?

Start in the largest settlement of a major Mediterranean island, which serves as the headquarters for a specific type of administrative entity defined in its nation's mid-20th century constitution. Considering the non-European category of these integral administrative divisions, identify the one on the South American mainland that hosts qualifying rounds for a major national sporting competition. Within this territory, whose land is mostly covered by primeval rainforest, lies its capital city at the mouth of a river sharing its name. In what year was the initial wooden fort, which protected this capital, first constructed?

Starting in a Canadian region containing four provinces, find a prairie province within it known for its numerous lakes. Consider the practice of cultivating plants, which evolved into large-scale monoculture in the twentieth century, and the subsequent movement that championed farming without synthetic chemicals, a method influenced by a philosopher who founded an esoteric spiritual movement in the early 1900s. This thinker's work often referenced a number symbolizing perfection, which is part of the name of a global girl group. A member of this group was born in Hubei and joined the main group's second generation in the eighth month of 2013. In which city did this member's sub-unit, which trained in a peninsular East Asian country, hold its debut showcase?

Beginning with the UK's policy of managing food imports during a 20th-century war, consider the producer-run board that controlled a specific dairy product and ran a famous 1980s advertisement. This ad featured a slogan questioning the identity of a sports team and starred a young actor born in 1980. The next subject is a long-running children's television drama set in a hospital. From there, consider another children's series about a secondary school, whose creator also devised a soap opera set in a fictional suburb of Chester. This soap is broadcast on a free-to-air channel aimed at a young adult demographic. What does the initial in this final channel's name stand for?

Starting with the process of defining future policies for moving people and goods, follow the chain to the human-made setting for daily activity that includes such systems. This setting is the focus of a technical process that designs land use, which in turn is examined by an academic field that studies the history of city development. Consider a subdiscipline of geography that also examines urban life, and then a sociological discipline that provides input for the land-use design process. From there, identify a Canadian-American scholar in that sociological field who once led his profession's national association. What was the name of the small pastoral community in his colleague's country of birth, where that colleague, a member of the same school of thought, was born?

Starting in the London district known for its Elizabethan theatre, consider the area that was the next stop south from the original northern terminus of the city's inaugural deep-level railway. This railway later added a station that became the site of a major mid-1970s transport disaster. This station is served by a spiraling underground line that stops at a station built over a historic mass grave. This location also serves as the eastern terminus for another line, whose identifying color on the map shares its name with a cryptographic algorithm. For which European telecommunications company was this algorithm developed, and in what city are its headquarters located?

Starting with the city gripped by an "expressway fever" in the late 20th century, follow a road to a neighboring province whose name translates to "north of the river". This province is traversed by a mountain range that forms the eastern boundary of a plateau known for its highly erodible soil. An agricultural method involving step-like platforms, ideal for this erodible terrain, is often used in the world's longest continental mountain chain. Within the central part of this chain, one can find dry valleys subject to a rain shadow effect. These valleys are located in a landlocked South American country. What is this country's largest city and principal industrial center?

Begin with a Japanese idol collective named after a Tokyo district, known for being accessible to fans. One of its members first failed to join a sister group before becoming a trainee for the main one. This member's group was featured on a TV variety show, which later launched a spin-off for that same sister organization from another city. This type of musical act mirrors a format popular in America in the late 1950s. A song considered an early example of this format's sound was recorded in October 1957 on a label owned by a certain producer. This producer also discovered a New York-based rock and roll group who released a major international hit in January 1956. What was this latter group's full name?

Starting with a media critic who founded a watchdog group and taught at an institution, identify the communications school at that college named for a media executive. A screenwriter known for a classic sci-fi anthology series also wrote and hosted a supernatural TV movie that functioned as an initial test episode for a full series. A Canadian show about a succubus, which would have begun with such an episode, was produced by a man who earned a degree from a Hamilton university in a specific field of large-scale exchange. This field's name derives from a Latin word formed from "together" and a second root word. What is the English translation for that second root?

Consider the political party whose name translates to 'Soldiers of Destiny', which formed after a split from another Irish republican party. Find the person who became president of this latter party in 2018, and identify the capital city she has represented. From this city's C-shaped orbital motorway, determine the national primary road that acts as a trunk route toward the republic's second-largest city. In this second city, what was the opening year of its oldest purpose-built theatre, a venue that once hosted a famous silent film comedian?

Starting with an Anatolian mountain from which a specific ancient river flows, identify the mythological nymph whose name means 'she who comes from' this mountain and who had a child with the river's divine embodiment. This nymph's name is also associated with the highest peak on a Hellenic island, a legendary divine birthplace. The body of stories containing these figures was studied by a Scottish anthropologist who proposed a three-stage evolution of human belief. Contrasting with the academic study of religion, consider a specific rite for the very young, also known by a term from the Hellenic word for 'child'. Now consider a different procedure, a surgical removal sometimes used to treat chronic infections in the urinary tract. What is the medical term for a condition that involves a narrowing at the exit point of this same bodily system?

Starting with a U.S. charity dedicated to military reform, note the section of the tax code defining its non-profit status. A provision named after a mid-20th-century senator restricts organizations with this status from endorsing candidates in the formal group decision-making process that is central to representative governments. An early example of such a government's legislative body, led by an Earl, met in an English university town and produced constitutional reforms to resolve a dispute with the reigning monarch. What was this monarch's alternative name, which refers to his city of birth?

Starting in the Indian city historically called Rāmdāspur, travel to the state it's located in, a region named for its five rivers. Within this state, find a city situated on a major historical road, whose name may derive from a demon king. Identify a daily express train that serves the first city and has detachable coaches bound for a different town, one named after a goddess. At this town's station, the starting point of a UNESCO-recognized narrow-gauge railway, consider a UK-based association for hobbyists who model such railways at a 7mm-to-the-foot scale. What is the name of the person who published a revised set of standards for this hobby in a specialized magazine in the 1990s?

Starting with a societal concept synonymous with 'ethnic pluralism', consider a contrasting metaphor for assimilation which is mentioned in this concept's description and is often associated with a 1908 play. Following a Romance-speaking ethnic group from a European peninsula often associated with this assimilation model, we arrive at their capital city, known for containing the world's smallest nation. Within this city's famed seven landforms, move from the southernmost one to the centermost one, which housed imperial residences. What is the original Latin name for this central landform, from which the modern term for a monarch's grand home is derived?

Beginning with the truce signed in a French forest that ended a world war's hostilities, identify the subsequent peace accord which was recorded by the secretariat of a new global body. The charter for this body was influenced by a US group led by a man who would later serve as his country's tenth chief justice. A French statesman who supported this international body also promoted a system of progressive taxation. The principle behind this fiscal policy was first implemented as a federal tax in a North American nation to fund a domestic war, with collection handled by a federal revenue service whose leader is appointed by the head of the executive branch. Who was the president that appointed the aforementioned tenth chief justice to his judicial position?

Starting with a lower court in a specific constituent country of the UK that handles minor offenses, consider the type of detention facility to which it might sentence a juvenile. A real-world example of such a facility was at the center of a judicial kickback scandal in a US state. The indictment for that case came from a specific type of legal body that screens criminal charges, a body used in a legal tradition that originated in the country where our path began. In that country, identify a prominent heritage conservation organization. This body is a type of entity regulated by a government department that oversees similar groups. What is the two-word term for the financial classification of these groups, whose primary goal is philanthropy rather than profiting individuals?

Starting with an annual football competition where a victor during the Soviet era shares part of its name with the final venue, consider the sport played by a club from that nation's capital that won the first five domestic championships after independence. This country's national team later competed in qualifiers for a major continental tournament, which is a general term for a top-level competition among athletes of that continent. A specific version of this championship, focusing on a racket sport, is now held annually except in years when a certain multi-sport event is scheduled. What is the post-renovation seating capacity of the stadium which hosted the opening ceremony for the second edition of that multi-sport event?

Starting with the second-longest river on its continent, which features a floodgate complex to prevent it from changing course, consider the general purpose of these adjustable gates in controlling water flow. An example of such a barrier, operational since the early 1980s, protects the floodplain of a ceremonial county in England that contains over thirty districts. One of these districts, the UK's smallest county, is the city's historic core and is itself composed of smaller electoral units. In a different system within a northern country of the same kingdom, what is the total number of unitary authorities?

Starting with the study of animal flesh eaten as food, move to the scientific discipline that examines this sustenance. From there, consider the global organization representing this discipline's professionals, once led by a Canadian biochemist who also held a director-level post at a United Nations agency focused on ending hunger. Within a region this UN agency serves, a specific coalition of religious conferences was established in the early 1960s. Identify a founding member nation of this coalition, which is also home to the continent's highest peak. What was the population of a well-known ethnic group that inhabits the northern part of this country, as recorded in a neighboring nation's census during the final year of the 2000s?

Starting with a 2D mathematical system defined by a distance from a reference point and an angle, consider its 3D extension that utilizes a reference plane and axis. From the branch of mathematics that uses these systems to study infinitely small changes, identify an Enlightenment Era scholar who succeeded Euler as a director of mathematics in a Prussian academy. This scholar's major work on mechanics was published in a city where, a few years later, a new republic was founded during a period of revolution. Within this republic, a powerful executive body was formed by a national assembly to protect it. Following an influential lawyer and politician associated with this body, we arrive at a historic regional center. What river's valley is this center connected to on its eastern side?

Beginning with a New York museum focused on art from a specific Caribbean island's community, consider an indigenous group represented in its collection, who were the first to be met by a famed 1492 voyager. A type of shaken idiophone used in their cultural sphere has an ancient counterpart from a North African civilization, an instrument associated with a goddess who transformed from a lioness to a domestic feline. This deity was part of a widespread veneration of these animals, whose remains have been found in funerary goods at a particular Middle Kingdom cemetery site. South of this necropolis is a temple dedicated to a local goddess; what is her name?

Start with the concept of a ruling family line. A specific house from this tradition established its capital in the "City of Jasmine" after an internal conflict. Following a second period of civil unrest, a ruler from another branch of this family rose to power. His authority was cemented by a victory in a late 7th-century battle, which secured his clan's control over the region containing their capital. Much later, a major revolt against foreign rule occurred in this territory. In a more recent conflict, a rebel battalion named for a hero of that revolt was formed, comprised mainly of members of a particular religious community concentrated in a specific southern province. What is the name of the historic region that this province is part of?

Beginning with a social network whose name originates from university student directories, consider a high-ranking female executive from that company who was featured in an annual compilation of influential people. This type of publication, a portmanteau using a numbered structure, is a form of a more general written work. Such works are often found in periodicals whose expenses are partly covered by paid promotions placed alongside editorial content. For the largest physical format these periodicals come in, what is the paper size designation for a full spread in certain Oceanic nations?

Starting with a magazine known for launching a famous film director’s career and covering a pivotal civil rights-era murder confession, follow the historical connection to a series of marches that prompted major voting legislation. From there, identify the broadcast network whose news division was formed after a government body forced a rival to divest its predecessor. This rival company, nicknamed for a colorful bird, exists in a market structure that contrasts with the economic concept of a single commodity supplier. This market position enables a pricing strategy based on willingness to pay, which is related to the economic surplus that software firms study. Among the factors affecting this surplus, what is the term for a product's ease of use?

Starting in a kingdom where a government can be removed by a legislative vote, which can trigger a nationwide election, consider the parliamentary act that standardized the timing for this event and defined the period of legislative shutdown preceding it. Following this shutdown, which is preceded by a short period to finalize pending business, the nationwide vote selects a primary legislative body, differentiating it from smaller elections for single vacant seats. These smaller elections have a unique spelling in a neighboring island nation. In what year did the constitution of that neighboring nation establish the office of its head of state, a figure who is part of the overall legislature?

Starting with a politician born in the late 1960s who advocated for his country's departure from a continental union during a public vote, this process led to a domestic law. This law nullified previous legislation from the early 1970s, thus severing ties with the union's legal framework and impacting a rights charter proclaimed at the start of a new millennium. An earlier, unratified constitutional agreement had also intended to give this charter legal force, replacing a foundational treaty from a Dutch city which established the union and a shared currency. That currency was preceded by a system from the late 1970s meant to reduce exchange rate variability. What provision in the foundational treaty from the Dutch city first outlined the obligation for members to adopt this shared currency?

Begin with the country associated with a specific fixed-term, guaranteed-return investment. From there, identify the professional basketball league in which this country is represented by a single team. This league's sport was played in high school by a man who later became the CEO of a brand identity consultancy. An organization based in this CEO's birth city, which originated as a war relief group in the 1910s, is known for sponsoring prestigious theatre awards. A two-time recipient of these awards also won a major honor for a television performance. A talk show airing on multiple networks during that same period follows. In what city was a revolutionary political group, founded in the same decade this show premiered, established?

Starting with the English publisher known as the progenitor of literature for young people, consider an illustrated book format that gained popularity in the Victorian era. This format shares its title with a musical composition by a rock group, which also released a multi-disc compilation album with the same name. The song itself is the third track on the group's sixth studio album, which was the final recording by the original quartet. One member of this quartet played a plucked string instrument tuned to a lower range than a standard guitar. According to the description of a musical notation convention applicable to an instrument with similar tuning, what phrase describes when the sounding pitch is in a different register but shares the same note name as what is written?

Start with a type of watercraft guided by wires between shores. An example of this has operated since 1905 within a US county established in the 1730s. This county contains a town with the world's largest processing plant for a specific livestock, a facility exemplifying an industrial farming method. This method is associated with a neurodegenerative disease in cattle, where infectious proteins concentrate in certain tissues from the head, designated as high-risk. In a different mammal, a crescent-shaped sensory ganglion also resides in the head, occupying a dural cavity. What major artery is located medially to this ganglion?

Beginning with the scientific study of language change over time, consider the branch concerned with comparing languages to find a common origin. From the primary technique of this branch, used to infer ancestral properties, identify a major group of modern tongues that evolved from a shared classical precursor. Now, consider a regional dialect of one of these tongues, spoken in the northernmost part of its country and known by a local name. This local name is central to a popular comedy film about a public servant punitively transferred to the area. The film's setting is a town whose name derives from "green hill", where legend says a king's son founded a small monastery. What is the general term for a complex of buildings housing a religious order under the governance of one person?

Starting with the list of golfers who graduated from a developmental tour based on earnings, we find a specific golfer mentioned in that year's qualifying school list who had already secured his card. This American golfer would, a few years later, top the money list of that same developmental tour after it was renamed. The graduates from the tour finals one year after he achieved that feat competed in a season that marked the tour's centenary. That season introduced a new tournament which, after relocating, became the first non-major tour event in its new state in decades. This state previously hosted a major where the winner successfully defended his title. What was the name of the golfer who finished in third place at that major, five shots behind the leaders?

Starting with a prolific Anglo-French writer who served in parliament after becoming a naturalised citizen, identify his "friendly enemy," an author known for creating a priest-detective. A 20th-century American theorist, known for shaping a post-war political movement, gave special importance to an 18th-century Anglo-Irish politician, considered a predecessor to that author. A modern historian analyzing that politician's era described its power structure using a specific term for rule by a small elite. That term, often associated with specific social connections, is also the title of a 1980s sitcom about a generational culture clash. What is the name of the Manhattan educational institution from which the actress who played a recurring love interest on this show graduated?

A winner of an early 1920s election for a statewide congressional seat in a former territory had previously been a clerk for the national mail service. This organization, reorganized into an independent agency by a 1970 law, had earlier mandated adhesive prepayment, replacing a system where the recipient paid. This postal reform preceded the secession of several states into a confederacy. The expansionist aims of this confederacy were echoed in a prior proposal for a vast slave-holding empire, a plan championed by a secret society. What was the political party that included the faction uncompromisingly opposed to this society's goals, demanding the complete elimination of slavery?

Starting with a 15th-century statute that required a certain parliament's proposed laws to be approved by the monarch's representative, follow the path to an individual who held this representative post and was born around 1465. This person received property from an English ruler known for his marital annulment efforts, which caused a schism with a specific Pope. During that pontiff's reign, a decisive battle in an Italian war resulted in the capture of a French monarch. The captured sovereign's mother, who acted as regent, was the daughter of a Duke of Savoy. What was the first year of the reign of the royal house to which her son belonged?

Beginning with a British phonetician who studied under a Parisian linguist, identify this linguist's father, an economist who was a co-recipient of a major international peace prize in its inaugural year. This economist's uncle served as a government minister under two different French rulers. This minister's brother, a naturalist specializing in plants and geology, served as a sub-secretary in a government cabinet established in 1847. The Minister of Justice in that same cabinet was born in a coastal administrative division of a northern French region. In which department within that same region is the final commune on this path located?

A French king from a cadet dynasty signed a decree granting rights to a Protestant minority. Near a key seaport stronghold for this group is a fortification where the final scene of a 1967 adventure film was shot. The star of that film, a screen symbol of his era, was a colleague of an Austrian-born actress who also found success within that nation's film industry. This industry, noted for its pioneering movements, is home to a major studio complex built in a renovated power plant. On what date was this facility inaugurated?

Beginning with the year a West African nation won its sole medal in its debut at a multi-sport event, identify the city that hosted both those games and a subsequent, nicknamed "little," event for wheelchair athletes. In a suburb of this Scottish capital, which originated as church lands, there is a nearby parish church founded by a Norman knight. This church possesses a tall, self-supporting structure, a type of which is specifically designed to house sounding instruments. What is the Italian term for this kind of structure?

Starting with a political figure who led a paramilitary offshoot of a major party and was later imprisoned, find the legislative body whose powers were defined by a specific set of accords. One of the key architects of these accords, a university lecturer, met with a finance minister also known by his Arabic kunya. This minister later became prime minister but resigned after his party's defeat in a legislative election held in January of a particular year. This political transition illustrates the need for a temporary ruling body, exemplified by a short-lived government formed in Europe at the end of a major global war, following the suicide of the previous leader. Who served as the "Leading Minister" of this brief administration?

Starting with the secondary team in a global rally competition run by a French firm, identify its factory-backed parent organization, which won a famous desert rally multiple times in the 1990s. From there, pivot to that organization's home country's domestic championship, an event won three times by a man who was once an ambulance driver. This driver went on to win the premier international series, which has a complementary championship for young talent. That junior series was initially for cars of a specific formula, with its first champion driving for the same manufacturer as the starting team. What is the maximum permitted width for the top-tier car specification used in the main international series, a standard introduced in 1997?

A central prayer in a monotheistic tradition contains a four-letter divine name. The first letter of this name, the tenth in its Semitic alphabet, is the ancient ancestor of a dotted Cyrillic character. This dotted character is often equivalent to another Cyrillic letter that originates from the Greek letter eta. The Greek letter's shape, in turn, names a type of mathematical set, a countable example of which has a size represented by a number series named after a Hebrew letter. Following this concept of infinite sizes, what is the name for the collection of elements, also called the continuum, which is more numerous than the aforementioned countable set?

Starting in New York City's largest and most ethnically diverse borough by area, navigate to a neighborhood bordered to its southeast by a large housing cooperative. This cooperative is adjacent to a community to its east, notable for a historic enclave that housed many prominent African American entertainers, including a jazz pianist with a royal title. From this area's musical legacy, consider a D.C.-born composer and bandleader who was a pivotal figure in the same genre. A contemporary of his was the aforementioned noble-titled musician. The work of these artists influenced a subsequent genre that originated in African American communities in the 1940s. What was the name of the high school band formed by the disc jockey who promoted a blend of this genre with others under a new name?

Starting with the rate of electrical energy transfer, which is distributed through a grid, consider the part of this system responsible for the bulk movement of energy. From the physical property that is the inverse of this system's opposition to current flow, identify its associated unit, which belongs to a widely used international measurement framework. Within this framework, find the base unit used to quantify the amount of a substance, a concept central to describing chemical compounds. Among one class of these compounds, composed of ions, what is the name for the type that is neither acidic nor basic?

Starting with an engineering field that scales up biological laboratory findings, consider the discipline it stems from, which is concerned with transforming materials. This parent discipline designs vessels where chemical transformations occur, but if an unintended transformation creates by-products, a specific method is required for their isolation. One device for this purpose uses stacked, angled plates. A related device, operating on sedimentation, is used in various industrial applications. What theoretical study, which is part of the curriculum for the broad field covering these applications and making them more efficient, focuses on maximizing outcomes?

Begin with a music style popular among Mexican-American communities in a southern US state. This style often features a twelve-stringed instrument that is used by a Norteño-Sax band formed on the vernal equinox of 1978. This band’s first chart-topping Latin single exemplifies a broader radio format which includes many traditional Mexican genres. An awards ceremony honors artistic achievement in this broader format and the initial Texan style. This ceremony had a specific award for the initial style that was active for over a decade, as well as a separate, three-year-running award for the broader format. In what year were these two specific awards discontinued and merged into a new, combined category?

Beginning with the victor of a reality competition offering a $250,000 prize, trace the path to one of that show's creators. This producer went on to co-found a 'celebreality' production company, which was later acquired by a Dutch media giant. That media giant's portfolio includes docusoaps, like one chronicling stylists in a northeastern state, which aired on a network that was later replaced by a channel for a metrosexual audience. This replacement channel was carried by a satellite service provider based in California. What was the initial launch date of this satellite provider?

Beginning with the mythological trumpeter whose burial was mandated by a prophetess as a prerequisite for a hero's journey into the underworld, find the epic poem that solidified this prophetess's legend. The author of this poem is famed for creating his civilization's national epic. Following this genre, consider another national epic, detailing a conflict in South America, whose final part was published in the same year as an influential English handbook on poetry and rhetoric. What was the original name of the constituent college attended by the handbook's author, before it received a new royal charter in 1505?

Starting with the general term for an animal park, whose common abbreviation originated from a scientific collection established in the 1820s within a royal park in a European capital, consider a similar institution founded decades later in a German city by a merchant. This merchant, who also served in a national assembly, later co-founded a railway named for an empress. An extension of this railway was planned for a city located in an alpine valley, which has hosted multiple winter global sporting events. What is the name of the highest-ranking national club competition for the most popular sport in the country where this city is located?

Start with a 6th-century abbot from Glamorganshire. This saint's home county bordered a historic one to its east, which is traversed by a large linear earthwork. This defensive structure once separated a Welsh kingdom from the territory of an Anglo-Saxon people whose name meant 'border people'. Within the modern region that was this Anglo-Saxon kingdom's heartland, lies a county famous as a great playwright's birthplace. In this county's largest town, there is a medical facility named after a notable female author. What is the full name of the trust that manages this establishment?

Beginning with a Norse kingdom in Ireland established in the 9th century, whose history is documented in certain annals, identify a legendary king listed among the rulers of an eastern Irish kingdom. This king was killed in a duel by a warrior who fought one-handed, but the king's preserved brain was later stolen by a rival fighter from another province. That thief, in turn, had a famous rivalry with the duel's victor, a hero belonging to a northeastern confederation of dynastic groups. The mythological cycle that chronicles the exploits of these people is centered on a royal capital near a modern city that is now a major religious center. What is the name of the administrative county of which this religious city is the main town?

Starting with the artistic technique used to represent an image on a flat surface as seen by the eye, consider an Italian painter who experimented with this technique, had a sculptural style, and was the son-in-law of a founder of the Venetian Renaissance style. This founder's most famous son revolutionized his local school of painting with a sensuous and coloristic style. One of this son's masterpieces, an altarpiece for a church named after a biblical figure known for his patience, was inspired by another painting that was later disassembled. The fragments of this disassembled work were documented by a versatile Flemish artist, who was also a painter of a particular type of figure. What is the German-derived term for these accessory figures added to a scene to provide scale and interest?

Starting with a list chronicling destructive natural events, identify one such event that was an act of environmental warfare used to halt an invading army during a major international conflict. From the nation defending itself in that conflict, find a military officer who was honored for crushing an internal revolt and later went to a certain city for exams. That city, now a national capital, contains a multi-tiered pagoda commissioned by an empress. This structure was erected during the final imperial dynasty ruled by that country's majority ethnic group. A prince of this dynasty, who was also a musician and mathematician, is known for his work on a system of musical tuning. In what year did he mathematically describe this system?

Starting with the study of logical content where statements can have the same truth value, consider the connective meaning "if and only if". From there, identify a different "if-then" connective, symbolized by a forward arrow, which has a natural language counterpart. A specific type of this, where the "if" clause is false, was analyzed by a philosopher who earned his undergraduate degree from an institution named for the founder of Methodism. This university competes in a "Little Three" rivalry. In that same state, what city is home to the second-oldest college, an institution founded as an alternative to another prominent university?

Beginning with one of the three foundational global traditions of reasoning, consider a specific philosophical system from that tradition that posits a prime number of distinct truth predicates. This system is an example of a broader category of propositional calculus that moves beyond a simple binary system. This general field was a key research area for a Czech scientist, born in the fourth decade of the 20th century, who later led an organization named after another famous logician and contributed to an infinitely-valued logic formally introduced in the mid-1960s. This logic is often applied to address the paradox of the heap, which challenges a semantic law asserting that every proposition is strictly true or false. This law is related to another classic law of thought, whose name serves as the title for an episode of a crime anthology series. Who directed this installment?

A historian of a major American internal war received his doctorate two years before a federal humanities agency was founded. That agency's highest honor, a lecture series, was established seven years after its own creation. A recipient of this honor, a scholar of Christian history, was born fifteen years before the founding of a theological seminary where he held a leadership position. This seminary was established in America's most populous city, which is also home to an international organization's headquarters, a complex finished fourteen years after the seminary's inception. These headquarters are exempt from local law. What is the term for this exemption?

Starting with a 30mm cannon created to replace an earlier gun, follow the path to that predecessor, which served as the main armament on an initial model of a Soviet vehicle family whose name translates to "infantry fighting vehicle". A US program from the mid-1960s with a similar designation sought to develop successors for its own armored vehicles, including an experimental scout vehicle meant to succeed a reconnaissance carrier. This carrier, designed for information gathering, was eventually replaced. The military practice of information gathering, when conducted using aircraft, has a history that began when a post-revolutionary European power first deployed a specific lighter-than-air craft. In which battle was this craft used to gain intelligence and affect enemy morale?

Starting with a clinical scoring system that assesses bleeding risk in patients with a particular cardiac arrhythmia, find the anatomical heart chamber that shares its name with a European research institute. This institute, focused on gender equality and a specific social movement's history, is thematically linked to an international commemorative year from the mid-1970s. That observance was established after years of work by a UN functional commission, which later controversially elected a Middle Eastern monarchy as a member. The appointment of this nation, whose gender parity was ranked extremely low, was scrutinized by non-governmental monitoring organizations. One such watchdog group shares a focus on international law with a former Attorney General of Canada. In which city was this former legislator born?

Starting with a percentile-based role-playing system first published as a booklet in 1980, identify its well-known horror-themed derivative based on a famous author's mythos. This game's genre inspired a survival-focused video game subgenre, which includes a 2002 sequel to a cinematic work set in a remote polar outpost. The alien infiltration theme of that film is also central to a 1956 black-and-white movie adapted from a novel about extraterrestrial seed pods. A later cinematic version of this novel, set on a military installation, starred a lead actress who trained in drama and dance at what London institution?
answer: Italia Conti Academy of Theatre Arts

question: Starting with a list of an electronic musician's live shows, consider the city where one of his earliest performances was held at an opera house. In this capital, locate the nation's largest exhibition center, which resides in the city's most populous administrative district. Within this district is a modern hospital that opened in the 21st century, near which is a transit station serving as the western endpoint for a particular line. This line, connecting the city's southwest to a southeastern town, includes an above-ground stop named for a nearby university. This stop belongs to an extensive urban rail system famous for its Art Nouveau-influenced entrances. How many numbered and bis lines comprise this entire system?

Beginning with perennial plants that are not a distinct taxonomic group, consider an order of flowering plants classified under a 1981 system. This was superseded by a molecular-based taxonomy, whose fourth version was published 18 years after its first. In the immediate predecessor to that version, identify an order of four families within the malvid group. A genus from southeastern Africa was placed in this order after its original, polyphyletic family was deemed a "dumping ground." The concept of a name-bearing genus that defines such a family has a similar counterpart for the species level. In which specific branch of biological naming, as opposed to another where it lacks this status, does this species-level concept have formal standing?

Beginning with a category of woodwind instruments played in an upright position, consider a rim-blown example from the Middle East that is thousands of years old. An Ottoman variation of this ancient instrument, significant in Sufi ceremonies, is part of a broader class of keyless flutes where sound is produced at the tube's upper edge. From this class, identify a longitudinal bamboo instrument adopted in Japan during the 7th century for use in Zen practices. A specific playing technique for this instrument, which raises a note's pitch, also modifies its tone quality. This sound quality is defined by physical traits, including a particular envelope. What type of spectrum is this envelope a curve of?

Identify the founder of a prominent US-based LGBTQ lobbying organization, who was also the first lobbyist for same-sex rights in a particular midwestern state. The history of this cause includes an 18th-century event where a North American province pardoned certain prosecutions. This type of administrative area is analogous to a historical collection of territories on the Italian peninsula ruled by a religious figure. This collection was adjacent to a duchy of five cities, which, like another duchy centered on a more famous city, was part of a larger imperial lordship. The capital of this lordship had previously been designated as the seat of power for a Western empire by a specific ruler. What was this ruler's date of death?

A language spoken in southwestern Morocco is native to a people who are part of a larger ethnicity that established an 11th-century imperial dynasty. The first military leader of this dynasty came from a tribe associated with another involved in the Saharan salt trade, which in turn may be the same as an ancient group known to Romans for a famous purple dye. This ancient group belongs to a larger ethnic population indigenous to North Africa. What is an alternative name for the medieval territory on the Iberian peninsula once governed by these people, which reflects the dominant religion of its rulers?

Begin at an Oxford college on Catte Street known for its iconic bridge, then consider a younger college of the same university, the most recent to teach both undergraduate and graduate students. From there, move to a Danish designer remembered for his contribution to architectural functionalism, a contemporary of a German peer who founded a famous school of design. The uncle of that school's founder ran a major Berlin architecture firm with a partner. The profession practiced by this partner, whose title derives from the Greek for 'chief builder', is supported by a professional organization in the United States. In what city is this organization headquartered?

Begin with a Dutch-German entertainment company whose name reflected one of its holdings, a record label. This label, a British subsidiary of a German firm, is now part of an American music corporation owned by a French conglomerate. A major competitor to this corporation was previously part of a media giant that also published a famous news magazine. That American publisher had a UK division which, after rebranding, traced its origins to a market including a company started by a pioneer of popular journalism. In the field of this pioneer, consider a London evening paper that took its name from a fictional one. In which literary work did this fictional paper first appear?

Beginning in an Italian city known as a "granary," whose name is linked to pits for storing grain, consider a 17th-century seismic event in the same region that generated a massive series of waves. This type of wave can be caused by an astronomical collision, an example of which was observed over a Eurasian nation in 2013, producing a light brighter than the sun. This intense light can cause a visual impairment, a form of damage to the eye's light-sensitive layer. This damage can be concentrated in a specific central area, which is the subject of the final node, a condition involving fluid collection and swelling. What is this yellow central area called?

Starting in Germany's largest state by land area, find its third-largest city, which hosted a mid-16th-century treaty. This treaty established a principle allowing a ruler's chosen confession to become the state religion, but a special clause prevented a type of ruler who held both secular and spiritual authority from converting their entire territory if they changed faith. This ruler had a monastic equivalent with a rare title, an example of which existed within a specific Imperial subdivision of the Holy Roman Empire. Another city within this same subdivision, distinct from the one that held the treaty talks, became the permanent seat of the Empire's legislative body from 1663. What region is this final city the capital of?

Starting with the supreme legislative body governing certain Crown dependencies, use the term for these self-governing possessions to identify a specific one near the French coast. From this island, part of a larger archipelago, find a neighboring island to its west. This second island is split into administrative areas; its description names another such area on a different island, which serves as that island's main town. This town is close to a country on a major landmass. On this landmass, what was the capital city of an empire that was the continuation of an older one in its eastern territories and existed for over a thousand years?

Begin with the English church containing a "middle way" school of thought and identify the 6th-century mission it traces its history to, led by the first holder of a major Kentish archbishopric. This prelate received a papal 'little book of answers' concerning the new church founded by his mission. The mission occurred during the final years of an era of Germanic expansion, a period when a different ruler of the West Saxons held a title of overlordship. This ruler's tribe, based in the upper Thames, has a name phonetically similar to another tribal kingdom, suggesting a shared origin. This second kingdom later became a client state after what specific conflict?

Beginning with the enzyme that synthesizes new genetic strands, consider a specific version of this enzyme found in eukaryotes which is supported by a protein complex that loads clamps onto the genetic material. This complex is a pentamer. Following its components, from the 36 kD subunit, to the 40 kD subunit responsible for binding an energy-carrying molecule, to the 37 kD subunit that forms a core complex with the prior two, to the 38 kD subunit that links the core to the final component, what is the descriptive term for this last and most massive component which activates polymerases?

At a Massachusetts music venue that is the summer home for a major orchestra, find the associated music academy established by that orchestra's artistic head. Consider the general title for this leadership position, a role which also applies to military-style ensembles composed mostly of a specific metal alloy. A particular style of this music, influenced by Turkish marches, is popular in a certain Balkan country. This nation fought a short, decisive war against its neighbor, which resulted in the international recognition of its semi-independent state, a principality established by an 1878 treaty. That same treaty also created another autonomous territory within the same empire. What was the capital city of this latter autonomous territory?

Beginning with the primary songwriter of an American musical duo formed in 1956, identify his partner who earned multiple instances of a certain music industry prize. From that prize, find its most prestigious category, which was won by a soundtrack album that topped the charts for 24 weeks in the late 1970s. The main performers on that album were a trio of brothers. Now, turn to a British singer who ranks third in all-time single sales in his home country, just behind a famous quartet and an American "King." What is the specific North West London area where the bass guitarist for this singer's backing band—a musician whose nickname came from his speed as a sprinter—was born?

Starting with the last surviving dialect of a language once spoken between two German rivers, which declined under pressure from a neighboring West Germanic tongue that did not undergo a major consonant shift, consider the general scholarly term for any form of a language. This term includes specific regional varieties, one of which can be defined by social standing, while another, known as a 'style,' is a set of linguistic variants with social meanings. This underlying concept of linguistic variation becomes a subject of study when tied to hierarchical social categories. Besides sociologists, political scientists, and social historians, what other group of scholars analyzes these social categories?

Starting with a major port city on a river that forms a state boundary, consider the transit system founded in 1980 for the county to its northeast. This system's buses connect to a light rail network with a maintenance yard named for a female athlete who hails from the industrial city located across the river from the start. That city is in a state, known as a national microcosm, whose largest metropolis hosted a professional gridiron team in a mid-1980s league. What is the name for the ten-event contest within the collegiate sport that this team's Hall of Fame head coach competed in?

Starting with the chief minister who leads a government department for a specific region within a kingdom, follow the path to the devolved government established by a major political settlement. Within this government, find the department focused on economic competitiveness. This department's concerns overlap with a contributory insurance system for workers. This system was created by a foundational act that was a precursor to the modern welfare state. Before such a state system existed, what four-letter acronym describes the mutual associations that provided similar services and are still found in the developing world?

Starting with a high school athletic league in a north-central state, consider one of its charter member cities that departed after 87 years. This city, whose name comes from a native term for "spring river," was home to a lawyer who moved there in 1883. This politician served in the lower house of the governing body for the state. This chamber is the more populous of two that form the state's entire legislature. This legislative body governs a state that shares a northeastern border with the northern of two major peninsulas of a neighboring state. This northern peninsula is bounded on its south by a set of narrow waterways. What was the historical name for the region around these waterways, as called by the native Odawa people?

Starting with a list of detention centers, find the military conflict during which a facility holding over 3,000 people was set up in an Italian colony. The leader of the native resistance in this conflict, nicknamed the 'Lion of the Desert', was a key figure in a specific Sufi order. This order was prominent in a North African country; from there, identify an isolated settlement historically part of that country but now in a neighboring nation, known for its ancient oracle. The Berber inhabitants of this settlement speak a distinct language, also used in a smaller nearby oasis with a population under 400. This smaller community lies on the edge of a vast natural depression. What is the modern governorate where this depression is located?

Consider a creation revered for its outstanding quality and profound artistic vision. This acclaimed creation possesses an intrinsic characteristic – the perceived artistic quality – that was once legally defended in relation to a significant written work. This particular written work, a cornerstone of its literary movement, was serialized in an overseas periodical. The distribution of this serialized work in its host nation relied on a prominent government agency responsible for mail delivery. This mail agency draws its explicit legislative authority from a specific constitutional provision of its country. Early discussions about this legislative power included debates on whether it should encompass the transport of a particular type of widely distributed periodical. This widely distributed periodical is typically sold at a specialized retail outlet, which can often be found within larger commercial complexes. This retail outlet, known by a specific regional term, operates in a sovereign country situated off the north-western coast of a major continent. What is the name of that major continent?

An Indian actress received a regional accolade from a prominent film publication, the same award category for which another performer was later nominated for a role in a film about building a house. That film subsequently won a national award as the best feature in its language, an honor bestowed at a ceremony considered the country's counterpart to the American Academy Awards. Shifting focus from that nation's cinema to a nonfictional film practice, consider a Soviet pioneer of this genre. His national context gave rise to a term for political messaging formed from a portmanteau. What is the second word of this portmanteau?

Starting with the process of cultural assimilation where non-native societies adopt the values and writing system of a major East Asian power, consider the officially recognized, non-dominant populations within that nation that are subject to this process. From the comprehensive list of these groups, turn to the country's linguistic landscape, which contains hundreds of tongues, and focus on the predominant language family, whose primary varieties are often mutually unintelligible. One such variety, from a southeastern city, had a specific romanization scheme created for it in 1960. This scheme resembled the official transliteration system used to teach the standard national language. A certain phonological process involving r-coloring is common in northern variants of this standard language. In which local dialect is this sound, which can function as a diminutive suffix, most prevalent?

From a list of people sharing a common European last name, identify an activist who campaigned for victims of a stadium disaster in the late 1980s. The club her son supported won the top European prize under a manager named in its history during the 85th season of their domestic league. This club also won a second-tier European competition, which was later rebranded, multiple times. This competition ranks below a more prestigious continental tournament. In a final of this top-tier tournament, a Spanish team won a historic treble. That team then won a global competition, their sixth trophy in one calendar year. In which city was this sixth tournament played?

Starting with a system of church governance where each local congregation is autonomous, consider a branch of this movement in a North American country where one of its ministers was killed in a specific town. Decades later, near this town founded in the mid-16th century, a battle occurred during a major civil war. The commander of the winning conservative forces from this clash later became an interim head of state in opposition to the constitutional leader. This legitimate leader subsequently led the resistance against a European military incursion, a conflict which resulted in the establishment of a new monarchy. On what date did this foreign-backed empire officially end with the execution of its ruler?

In what branch of mathematics is a non-overlapping union described as a coproduct, a concept reached by starting with a glossary for a field studying interconnected points? This field, a key topic in a non-continuous mathematical discipline, defines structures of vertices and edges. Within these structures, a line linking a point to itself is a feature absent in their simplest form. The overarching study of these systems is a main focus of that non-continuous discipline, which handles countable sets and the concept of partitioning a collection into exclusive subsets, thus forming the non-overlapping union.

Beginning with a military branch established in the 19th century that is open to foreign recruits, consider its traditional ceremonial unit, noted for carrying axes to demolish enemy fortifications. This unit is part of the force's most senior founding regiment, which manages its official magazine and museum. Within the ranking system of this army, whose highest honorific title was held by a general nicknamed for his leadership in a lengthy WWI battle, identify the engagement that inspired the strategy for that prolonged conflict. During this earlier offensive, artillery observers played a key role. What year was the quick-firing field gun they utilized, known colloquially by the French word for its caliber, officially adopted?

Starting with a type of puzzle where the solution path reveals an image, consider a known designer of such puzzles, who was born in a Swiss city and later aided in liberating a Greek port. In the nation associated with one of the languages he studied at a prestigious university, there is a town considered the world's capital of a fragrant industry. This town is on a continent that forms the westernmost part of a larger landmass. From there, identify a transcontinental country, whose straits help define that continent's border, and consider its highest executive body. This body's appointment process was changed to reflect a system led by a head of state with active governing power, who heads the branch that enforces laws. In a system separating governmental powers, what is the term for the branch that interprets those laws?

Beginning with the German physician who discovered the organic nature of yeast, find his birthplace, a city located on the west bank of the Rhine. This city was besieged by a reckless duke, the last of his line from the House of Valois. This house was a cadet branch of a dynasty that ruled a Western European kingdom for centuries. Identify the final monarch from the direct line of this dynasty, the third son of a king also known by a "handsome" epithet. This father, nicknamed the "Iron King", had a fierce opponent in an Occitan bishop. The dispute between this king and the bishop contributed to a famous papal bull. During this ongoing conflict, another papal decree was issued that forbade laymen from taxing the clergy. What was the date of this earlier decree?

Beginning with the Spanish literary group that formed to mark the third centenary of a baroque poet's passing, consider an associated writer who was likened to an influential Italian poet and soldier. This Italian figure is a key part of his nation's body of literature, which includes a narrative poem about a young Trojan prince's affection. The earliest mention of this prince is found within a Greek epic detailing a feud involving a prominent warrior. Who was the father of this warrior's mother, herself a sea goddess and daughter of an ancient sea deity?

Starting with the physical law that equates matter with its inherent energy, consider its author's related theory on spacetime, which can be explored through a conceptual exercise. A physicist-philosopher, whose name is now a unit for speed relative to sound, influenced this author. This philosopher came from a region with advanced secondary schools that were common in a historical German state later dissolved by Allied decree. The history of this state's dissolution mentions a land corridor being carved out of its territory. This corridor and an adjacent free city were later annexed to create a new province. On what full date was this new province established?

Begin with a beam type named for headwear, shaped using diffractive optical elements made by a certain company. This company's technology relies on a wave phenomenon first described in the 17th century. That phenomenon is key to a foundational experiment from 1801 demonstrating that light acts like a wave. The concept of a localized wave burst, which is a solution to a wave equation, helps understand these waves. The aforementioned experiment also demonstrates wave-particle duality and the probabilistic nature of reality. This, and the wave property describing a constant phase relationship between sources, are both very important in what specific branch of physics?

Starting with a fundamental science that incorporates one of the most ancient fields of study, what is the name of the body of water that borders a specific administrative area found by following this path: The ancient field's observatory, operated by a university in Padua and founded in 1942, has an annex on a nearby mountain crest. This observation point is near a township that lends its name to a food product with a protected origin designation. The production zone for this item covers several of the nation's first-level administrative divisions, which are themselves subdivided into secondary-level units. These secondary units were reorganized in the 2010s, with some on a large southern island being replaced by new entities. One of these former units, named for its capital, is bordered to its north by what sea?

A Fields Medalist works on a type of equation relevant to a major unsolved problem in fluid mechanics. This problem is about a set of equations named for two scientists, which differ from simpler ones for inviscid flow by being dissipative. The description for these simpler equations instead details a law for the transport of a conserved quantity, expressed as a continuous flow. This concept of flow through a surface, when represented by a vector, is modeled by assigning such a vector to every point in a region. This assignment is defined within a geometric system named for an ancient Greek, which is often represented using tuples of real numbers. What is the name for the mathematical space that acts as this representation?

Starting with the Earth's most abundant metal, consider a compound found in its chief ore. This compound is a key ingredient in an antacid whose brand name was owned by a French pharmaceutical company. This company manufactures a once-daily injectable medication for a common metabolic disorder, which is delivered via a spring-loaded device designed for self-administration. A different type of injector, which forgoes a needle for a high-pressure liquid stream, was also used for similar purposes. What is the medical term for the layer of skin directly below the dermis, where these injections are administered?

Starting with the mythological abyss used as a prison for Titans, consider the ancient Roman poet who described a hero's journey through a similar underworld in his national epic. This poet was a central figure in a literary period named after the first emperor of his time. A friend of this poet, known for his elegies, wrote during the same period. His works often centered on a female companion, a role whose title evolved from a term for a court-dweller. A notable historical figure who held this role, the daughter of a prosperous merchant, later became the concubine of her monarch's Lord Chamberlain. This nobleman was a key supporter of his king's house during a dynastic civil war, in which a pivotal engagement helped secure the throne for his leader. What was the date of this engagement?

Starting with an electronic assembly technique that involves inserting component leads through circuit board holes, consider a specific type of sacrificial component with these leads that protects against overcurrent. This safety device was common during the time of a famous American inventor who not only worked with electricity but also pioneered motion picture technology. Following this innovation, what is the name of the building complex where the headquarters of the media conglomerate that owns the oldest surviving American film studio is located?

Starting from a Spanish autonomous city on the African continent, cross the body of water separating it from its mainland, which contains an underwater threshold. This threshold's formation is tied to a geological crisis that ended when a sea basin refilled, carving out a deep cleft. A U.S. state, admitted to the Union on a day celebrating love, is famous for a grand version of this landform. Near that state's capital, a certain north-south state route passes through a mountain range. What is the common name for the four-lane portion of this road?

Starting with a rock band from a Midwestern state established in the mid-1960s, consider their lead singer, who took his surname to honor a pianist from a specific musical genre. This genre, which has roots in blues and ragtime, greatly influenced a later style known for its danceable grooves, often built on a stubbornly repeating musical phrase. A creative force behind a Southern soul label, and a key figure in this rhythmic style, released a double album in 1971 that included a cover of a song made famous by a highly-charted female vocalist. In what year was this final vocalist born?

In an Ivorian urban commune with a rail link to a landlocked neighbor, find its link to the most industrious town in a French overseas department, which belongs to a group of seven territories in the Antilles. These isles were historically dominated by cultivating a sweet crop for European markets. Now, focus on the third-largest island nation in the Greater Antilles, a former British holding and a key exporter of this crop. Its legislative body features an appointed upper house with 21 members. A politician who once served as this nation's telecommunications minister is a member of that legislature. Though he represents a different constituency, what was the 2011 census population of the parish that is the country's most inhabited and the birthplace of one of its seven national heroes?

Start with a politician born shortly after the mid-20th century who was part of a specific political organization on an island nation. That organization, founded in the late 1930s, is led by the country's first female head of government. This leader, an attorney born in the mid-1960s, assumed power after an election where her party won every legislative seat. This election utilized a "winner-takes-all" system, a form of plurality voting. This method is distinct from another non-proportional system, the block vote. Separately, consider a minor provincial political league formed to advance the interests of agriculturalists. What is the headquarter city for a successor farmers' association from that same province, which governed for a period ending in the mid-1930s and now operates as a farm-supply retail chain?

Consider a clinical prediction rule for a lung artery blockage. A blood test for a certain protein fragment is used to help rule out this condition, which can cause strain on the heart's right ventricle. This strain is a feature of a cardiac disease that, in its chronic form, causes hypertrophy. A memoir whose title metaphorically contains the substance involved in these medical issues was penned by an author who worked for a particular Indian daily newspaper. This newspaper was later led by an editor-in-chief who is the youngest son of a fellow journalist. In what city was this editor born?

Starting with a voting method that uses expressed preferences to select a winner, consider the type of non-empty trail where only the initial and final points are identical. Taking the length of the shortest such trail, note that if this measurement is four or greater, the graph lacks a certain three-sided shape. A theorem, first described by a Hungarian mathematician, determines the maximum number of connections in a graph that lacks this shape. This finding was later generalized by a theorem named for two collaborators. The specific graph structure central to these theorems is formed by partitioning vertices and only connecting those in different subsets. In the branch of mathematics that studies such extremal graphs, what is the name for the graphs with the maximum number of edges that contain none of the non-empty trails mentioned at the second step?

Beginning at a Washington state music event, where a fruit-named tent features electronic artists, consider a Canadian producer of this genre known for his stage headwear. He collaborated with an American DJ who later spent two years on a religious mission in an East Asian island nation. A global competition for this DJ's profession shares an acronym with a Jovian asteroid that maintains a 1-to-1 orbital relationship with its planet. This type of celestial phenomenon is also exemplified by a specific ratio between three of that planet's moons. The largest of these moons was visited by a probe launched in 1977 that finished its primary mission after studying the eighth planet's system. What is the name of the percussionist on a duet album whose title describes this probe's current environment?

Start with a mineral known for its asymmetrically terminated crystals, found alongside ores of a dense, malleable metal. This metal possesses isotopes that are the end products of major chains of atomic disintegration. The decay of a certain subatomic particle is linked to its nature as a specific type of boson. A common measure for the rate of such disintegration is the time required for a quantity to halve. Returning to that specific boson, it arises from the spontaneous breakdown of continuous symmetries. A celebrated theorem links such symmetries to a corresponding conservation law.
